To The Secretary of the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir;-

Replying to yours of May 31st, #64411-1, re Mr. Jackson's report about the boys in the school-room being badly dressed, a word of explanation will throw light upon this criticism. In the month of April there is a great deal of work to be done that the boys cannot be very tidy in their clothing in doing, being a time for a general cleaning up. We calculate during that month to wear the clothing that has been worn all winter, rather than store it up for future use. If there is a month in the year in which the boys appear untidy, that month is April. I may say that, since Mr. Jackson was here, the boys in the school at that time have received a new suit of clothes, which is used during the summer for Sunday wear, and the suits, that the boys have been wearing during the past months for Sunday, is taken for every day wear. We postpone this as late in the Spring as possible for two reasons, one being that we wish to get all we can out of the old clothes, and another is, it is a hard time of the year on clothing. In justice to the general appearance of the boys, no boy was shabby. At the same time, the clothing in the aggregate was far below the average. I do not make this defence in opposition in any spirit of resentment to Mr. Jackson's criticism. He had reasons for the ground of his criticism. The method has another effect upon the boys. It teaches them to wear their clothing as long as possible.

As to the girls milking the cows, there are plenty of cows, but the boys have always done the milking, inasmuch as we have not had a lady member of the staff supervise the work of milking. It is quite possible for the girls to do the milking, and with our improved dairy barn, it is more feasible and easier arranged for than it has been in previous years.

Yours sincerely,

T.F./M.C.E.
Ottawa, June 11, 1915.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, and in reply I beg to say that your explanation with regard to the boys' clothing is quite satisfactory to the Department.

With reference to the inspector's recommendation that the girls be taught milking, I beg to say that, while the Department does not expect the girls to do all the milking, still, it is thought that every effort should be made to allow them to do some milking and thus acquire a knowledge which would be of much use to them in after life.

Your obedient servant

J. D. McLean
Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Rev. T. Perrier,
Principal,
Brandon Industrial School,
Brandon, Man.
To The Secretary of the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your of the 7th re a new mail-bag, we are sending, under separate cover, the old one. As to the lock, I do not remember of ever seeing one on it, so, of course, cannot return it. To the best of my knowledge it has not been here during my time, but such as we have we render up with pleasure.

Yours thankfully,

T. Ferrier

Sir,

I beg to request that you will be good enough to furnish this Department with a mail bag with padlock and keys for the use of the Brandon Indian Industrial School. The bag should bear the words "Indian Industrial School, Brandon, Man."

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th inst. asking to be furnished with a mail bag with pad lock and keys for use of the Brandon Indian Industrial School, and in reply would say that a bag for this purpose with the necessary lock and keys will be forwarded you at once.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Asst. Controller.

Extract from Inspector's Report on the Brandon Industrial School, dated May 29, 1916. Original on 64411-6.

I found on the rolls of the room 23 boys and 23 girls, a total of 46, classified as follows:

| Standard | 4   | 17 |
|----------|-----|----|
|          | 5   | 11 |
|          | 6   | 18 |

Total 46

Most of the pupils of this room have been inmates of the school and this room for a number of years and do not show the progress of the junior room. They know a lot but it is almost impossible for a stranger to get them to read out loud, and this is more especially true of the girls.

Sgd. S. J. Jackson,
Inspector of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, June 21, 1916.

Rev. Sir,-

I beg to inform you that Mr. Inspector Jackson in a recent report on the Brandon Industrial School in speaking of the senior class-room states as follows,- "Most of the pupils of this room have been inmates of the school and this room for a number of years and do not show the progress of the junior room. They know a lot, but it is almost impossible for a stranger to get them to read out loud and this is more especially true of the girls".

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. T. Ferrier,
Principal,
Brandon Industrial School,
Brandon, Man.
June 25th, 1917.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I have pleasure in informing you that after discussing the matter with the Hon. Dr. Roche, we have decided to give the boarding and industrial schools an increase of $10.00 per capita in the grant for the current fiscal year. This will apply only to the end of this year, when we will consider the then position of the schools.

I hope this will be a measure of relief to the administrators of the schools.

Yours sincerely,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. T. Ferrier,
Principal, Brandon Industrial School,
Brandon, Man.
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Joseph Everett, a pupil of the Brandon Institute, son of the present chief of Fisher River, was successful in passing the entrance examination to the Manitoba Collegiate. He can attend the Brandon Collegiate and take up a Teacher's Course, living in the Institute.

Would the Department sanction this arrangement for a couple of years? If so, can anything special be done for his tuition and keep?

Yours sincerely,

J. Ferrier
Industrial School, Brandon.

TF/GF

VERY POOR COPY
Ottawa, August 28, 1917.

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant, in which you inform the Department that Joseph Everett, a pupil of the Brandon Industrial School, has been successful in passing the entrance examination to the Manitoba Collegiate.

In this connection I beg to say that the Department will consent to this boy living at your school for two years in order that he can attend the Brandon Collegiate to take a teacher's course and will allow you the usual per capita grant for that period. You may include his name on your quarterly returns along with the other grant earning pupils.

The Department cannot provide any fees other than the above mentioned per capita grant. This is the same arrangement under similar circumstances made for Indian pupils attending collegiate institutes in Ontario.

Your obedient servant

MARTIN BENSON
Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Rev. T. Ferrier,
Principal,
Brandon Industrial School,
Brandon, Man.

VERY POOR COPY
Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Scott,

For some years we have been trying to get into sufficient stock for a farm of our dimensions. This we have about accomplished, having about one hundred head of horned cattle, thirty head of horses, fifty small pigs with nearly twenty brood sows. I wrote you about sending some of them to Fishing Lake for the winter but afterward concluded that this was not wise. I have had the teams hauling straw from the farmers around to a distance of six miles, wherever we could get a stack. I think we will be able to secure sufficient straw in this way. It is costing me considerably, anywhere from fifty cents to three dollars a load, depending on the distance and the quality of the straw. Over and above this, I have had to purchase in the neighborhood of twenty-five hundred dollar's worth of grain, screenings and shorts and bran. I think this is a much better policy than to send our stock out to have them in a half starved condition in the spring. Our failure of crop and shortage of feed was due entirely to the light fall of rain. The average for twenty-eight years at the Experimental Farm was ten inches including last year. The rainfall last year was a little less than four inches; we are expecting better crops and therefore have not too much stock on the farm. Another reason why I think we should keep our stock up particularly the hogs and cattle, is that great need of food production at the present time and no doubt for the next few years. We are anxious to anything in our power in increased production.

My object in writing you and giving you this information is to let you know that it is impossible to meet these extra expenses to say nothing of the increased cost of management without some special assistance.

Would it be possible for the Department to make a special grant for the purpose of assisting in food production and helping us out financially this year? If this is not possible would it be feasible to give us a loan of two or three thousand dollars without interest until we can see our way towards paying it back? Your consideration to this matter and any advice or suggestions will be gladly received.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL BRANDON

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6255, File 576-1, part 1)
Mr. Scott,

In regard to Mr. Ferrier's request for financial assistance I think we might make him a loan of $2,000.00 or $3,000.00 upon the understanding that it is to be repaid without interest next year if there is an average crop and from stock raised. We should be able to finance this.

Accountant.

Ottawa, January 17th., 1918.
January 25th, 1918.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I have received your note of January 15th, and would like to assist you in some way. If the loan is given, how would you propose to repay it? We usually have some understanding on that point, and the repayments are usually made from the per capita grant. It would be too vague to loan it on the understanding that you would pay it back when you could see your way towards that end. Kindly let me hear from you at once, and I will give the matter further consideration.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. T. Ferrier,
Principal, Brandon Industrial School,
Brandon, Man.

February 14th, 1918.

Dear Sir -

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, in reference to furnishing the Brandon Industrial School with the "Book of Knowledge."

I regret that the Department has not funds to place this work in any of its schools at the present time. You may recollect that a few years ago a similar request from another institute was refused.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General

A. E. McBride, Esq.,
Manager, The Grolier Society of London,
"The Book of Knowledge,"
The Tribune Building,
Winnipeg, Man.

VERY POOR COPY
Extract from report of Inspector Jackson on
the Brandon Industrial School dated May 4, 1918. Original
on 64411/6.

All the buildings are in a good state of repair
but they are very much crowded in the dormitories of the
school. In several of them the beds are within a foot of
one another and there is not much space to walk between.
Thirty eight boys are occupying 32 beds in one room,
where according to the Department regulations of 400
cubic feet for each pupil there should be only twenty six.

The hospital arrangements for this school are
very bad and though I have been reporting about them for
sometime no changes have been made. In the room called
the hospital at the time of my visit were two pupils, one
girl dying of consumption. The Nurse said she might die
any moment, and the other girl has concussion from a fall
in the winter. There are three boys sick in the dormitories.
One of them has been in the Brandon Hospital but is now
recovering. He has still an open wound in his leg from
which comes pus. Another boy is in bed with what he thinks
is itch, and I told the Nurse to send for the doctor and
have him examined. The third boy sick has ptomaine poisoning.
The Nurse reports (though she refused to put it in writing),
that since February, 1917, there were three deaths from
tuberculosis. There were five cases of pneumonia, all
recovered, 36 cases of measles and accommodation for three
only, all recovered. There were 15 cases of grippe, patients
averaging from 5 to 12 days each. All these pupils had to
be kept in the dormitories. Five pupils who came to the
school for admittance were sent home because of unfitness.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6255, File 576-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLICIQUES CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
I would recommend that in future all pupils sent to this school should be examined by a doctor at the point of departure. Seventeen pupils on the roll of the school will be over 18 during the year and are due for discharge.
Ottawa, May 21, 1918.

Rev. Sir,

Mr. Inspector Jackson, in a recent report on the Brandon Industrial School, states that the dormitories are very much crowded and that thirty-eight boys are occupying thirty-two beds in one room.

In this connection I beg to say that the Department does not approve of the pupils sleeping two in a bed and you will be good enough to see that separate beds are provided for all the pupils in your school.

The Inspector also states that the hospital arrangements for this school are very bad, and that there are three boys sick in the dormitories.

It is considered that some better arrangements should be made for the care of the pupils who are sick, as they should not remain in the dormitories.

The Inspector recommends that in future all pupils sent to this school should be examined by a doctor at the point of departure, as five pupils who came to the school for admittance were sent home because of unfitness. Kindly see that this recommendation of the Inspector is carried out.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Aust. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. T. Perrier,
Principal,
Brandon Industrial School,
Brandon, Man.

Ottawa, Ont.

FREE TO BOYS AND GIRLS

Can You Solve This Great War Puzzle?

WHO WANTS ME?

Four Things That Will Win The War

WHAT ARE THEY?

THE 16 Circles above can be made up out of the names of the four things that will win the war. Our bright loyal Canada, on foot or on horseback, helps at least one of these things. Every boy and girl should know all of them. Can you tell what each of these four things represent?

How to solve it.—Black circle represents a letter of the word called for. The number of dots in the circle represents the number of letters in the alphabet. For instance: "A" would be represented by a black circle because it is the first letter of the alphabet. "D" would be represented by a black circle with two dots because it is the second letter of the alphabet. "P" by three dots, "D" by four dots and so on. You must correctly count the dots in each circle and put the letters thus represented by its position in the alphabet and in order. You must also put them into proper rotation to spell the word. This is not an easy puzzle but if you can solve it correctly, you will be entered in the contest for one of the grand Cash prizes below.

Archives Publices du Canada
DUKE DEVONSHIRE DRIVES 4 HORSE TEAM AND BINDER

As If It Were Part of His Everyday Avocation — Premier Norris Also Drives

It was inevitable that the Duke of Devonshire, Governor-General of Canada, and the Honourable T. C. Norris, Premier of Manitoba, could not go among the farms of Manitoba without catching the enthusiasm of the agriculturist and do a little farming here on their own account. The Duke and the Premier have left this morning for Regina, but before leaving, the former visited the Experimental Station, where a job waiting for him at Donald McEwen's farm inter alia. "I do like working the binder," said Premier Norris, but Mr. McEwen failed to take the hint and the Premier will have to look elsewhere for a position. Neither of the distinguished men were on the field for two minutes before they asked to see the machine. The idea of working the mechanical contrivance that does the work of cutting, binding, and stocking grain at one and the same time. Neither had ever seen the machine before, and it spoke volumes for the simplicity of the mechanism when it is stated that the novices carried out the experiment with unqualified success.

Sir James Aikins was not with the party on its arrival from Ninette. It appears that the Lieut.-Governor, with his private secretary, Mr. Coleman, had left earlier in the day for Winnipeg.

Returning from Ninette the ducal party were met at the C. P. R. station at 4.30 p.m. by Messrs. Cater, S. E. Clement, M.P.P., Kenneth Campbell, H. J. Pugh and Ald. M. McKenzie. Taking automobiles, they were driven direct to the farm of Mr. Donald McEwen, where they inspected the mechanical stooker, after which they drove to the Experimental and Indian Industrial School farms, and returned to the city at seven o'clock. After staying overnight at the Prince Edward Hotel, the vice-regal party left for Regina this morning.

At the McEwen Farm

Mr. and Mrs. Donald McEwen received their visitors in cordial fashion and were evidently delighted at the opportunity of entertaining the representative of His Majesty the King at their prairie homestead. The visit had been anticipated with the greater interest because it was known that there were two machine stookers at work on the farm.

The machine turned out to be an ordinary binder with a parachainette to do the stocking attached thereto. The very simplicity of the thing is the surprising part of the mechanism which is certainly not more complicated than the work of the ordinary binder. The binder merely repeats its work. When the sheave is completed, rather than being thrown on the field.

(Continued on Page 3, Column 1)

PUBLIC MEETING TO PONDER PROBLEM HELP FOR FARMERS

Business Men, Farmers, Stookers to Gather in City Hall at 4 p.m. Sunday

The very serious situation that is facing the crops unless prompt action is taken, has resulted in a public meeting being called for...
Duke of Devonshire

(Continued from Page 1)

it drops into a crate that trails along at the side of the machine. When the crate is loaded, the sheaves are bound together with string, lifted up, and the whole chopped.

The machine driven by Mr. James Anderson, son-in-law of Mr. and Mrs. McEwen, had not gone half the round of the field before the Duke expressed his intention of handling the ribbons. Mr. Anderson gave his seat on the binder up to His Excellency, while Premier Norris took charge of the other machine. Both managed their four and five horses respectively as to the manner born and delighted everybody present by their demonstration of the latest labor-saving device to put in an appearance on a Manitoba farm.

"It is a wonderful invention," said the Duke.

"If I only had a couple of days with this, I bet I could make it do some work," said the Premier.

At Experimental Farm

Then came the drive to the Experimental Farm. Here the party were received by Superintendent McKillan who, with Mr. Campbell, imparted some very interesting information respecting the work of the institution. Another pleasant surprise that awaited the Duke was the threshing machine in operation. They were taken the rounds of the cattle sheds, and here it was that the Duke and Premier showed that they were farmers born and bred.

"She is a good cow," said the Prime Minister of Manitoba. The Duke acquiesced.

"She should be a little fuller here," said His Excellency the Duke of Devonshire, touching a domesticated looking animal on the back with a stick. The Premier signified approval.

The sight of milking by machinery did not seem unusual to the seasoned and distinguished agriculturists, but attracted considerable attention among the more city-bred crowd. A Short-horn bull that was calved from a cow brought from Lord Rothchild's farm in England, was examined with interest by both the Duke and Mr. Norris. The party, having made a round of the horses, were taken to the gardens where the possibilities of Manitoba soil were shown at their best.

Indian Industrial School

Leaving the Experimental Farm, the next stopping place was the Indian Industrial School Farm. The visitors were received by the Rev. T. Ferrier and conducted through the various buildings and given the opportunity of seeing the Indian boys and lasses at their respective tasks. Everybody was surprised at the showing made at the farm. The crops were in splendid shape and the beautifully situated and irrigated grounds made them appear delightful places for rendezvous. Mr. Ferrier had collected an exhibit of the products of the garden, and a splendid collection it was. A dish of strawberries was equal in flavor and size to the fruit grown in summer climes at B.C. and elsewhere.

The Hon. Dr. Thornton was particularly interested in the evidence of industry on the part of the pupils. The Duke asked the teachers if they found the children apt pupils, and on receiving a reply in the affirmative addressed a few questions to the children themselves, and was particularly gratified with their bright appearance and ready replies.

A large class of little Indian girls were drawn up outside the building to sing for the benefit of His Excellency. They sang sweetly the strains of the National Anthem.

The Duke, addressing the little girls, thanked them very much. "I am very pleased to know," he said, "that many of the boys from this school have gone overseas to fight for their King and country and for the great cause which is of so much interest to all of us. I know that you will live to be worthy of those brave lads, and to become useful citizens of Canada. I do wish you all success and happiness in your lives. I thank you very much."

A hearty clapping of hands on the part of the children and visitors alike greeted the words of His Excellency.

CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. Scott,

On Friday last we were honored with a visit from his Excellency the Governor General. We had an exhibit of farm and garden products placed on the tables in the dining-room. Our roots and vegetables this year are very fine. He inspected the work in our kitchen, laundry and sewing-room. When he was through in the main building he took notice that we had our stock herded on the hill-side and in the valley, the milk cows in one and the young stock in the other. He walked through both herds and asked me about the calves which were in the stable. He said he would like to see them. After seeing these he wished to see the new barn. We have it all nicely completed inside, so we showed him through. He then returned to the main building and heard the girls sing. After this he expressed a desire to drive down through the corn and potatoes. He asked me many questions regarding the work and stated that he was very much pleased with the work we were carrying on in the education of Indian boys and girls.

I am enclosing you the write-up that appeared in the Brandon Sun believing that this will be of interest to you.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Industrial School, Brandon.

TF/GF

Ottawa, March 17, 1920

Reverend Sir,

The Department has received a communication from Mr. Agent Carter requesting on behalf of Joseph Everett, of the Fisher River Band, for a grant to enable his son Joseph Everett, Jr. to complete his course at the Brandon College. The Chief states that you informed him that you could no longer maintain Joseph in the college.

The Department will be pleased to receive full information about this boy and the course he is taking up and also of the progress he is making.

In your letter of January 6th, last, you asked for his discharge from the Brandon Industrial School, which was granted. The Department considers that it has been paying for his education for a sufficient length of time and cannot undertake to continue the grant to enable him to take a further course at the Brandon College. However, I will be pleased to have your views in order that a reply can be made to the father. He is now 19 years of age, according to the returns, and he should be able to earn his own living.

Your obedient servant

J. D. McLEAN

Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Rev. T. Perrier,
Principal,
Brandon Industrial School,

Dear Dr. Scott,

My object in writing to you is to bring before you the question of pupils for the Brandon Institute.

All the Indian people on the prairies of Manitoba are ministered to from a missionary point of view by the Anglican and Presbyterian churches. The nearest Methodist Reserve is Fisher River.

Until we built the new school at Norway House we secured a large number of pupils from the north end of Lake Winnipeg. About the same year the Elkhorn school was closed and during the past eight years we have always had a sufficient number of pupils brought voluntarily to keep up the attendance. During the past summer and fall the new principal of the Elkhorn school has been recruiting for that institution. Consequently very few new pupils have been brought to Brandon this year.

When we closed the Red Deer school some twenty-two pupils were transferred here with the understanding that they were to be returned when the building was completed at Edmonton. We are preparing to take these pupils back next week. There are also about a dozen of the pupils who should receive their discharge in the near future. This will leave us about seventy-five or eighty pupils with little hope of increasing the number during the year. Denominational courtesy is sufficient reason why we should not recruit on those reserves ministered to by other religious denominations. There is no doubt but that when organic union takes place between the Presbyterian and Methodist churches the problem will be solved by reorganization.

As you are aware, we have accommodation for one hundred and twenty-five pupils. Before the closing of the Elkhorn school, I discussed with you the possibility of taking some pupils from Ontario to our Institute. If this can be done and say forty or fifty brought in, it would be the solution of the problem until union takes place.

I would appreciate very much your favorable consideration of this proposition.

Yours sincerely,

Duncan C. Scott, F.R.S.C., Litt. D.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, December 12, 1923.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, relative to the recruiting for the Brandon Industrial School. I have been much concerned because of the situation that has arisen and I have given much thought to the possible sources of recruits.

I am pleased to note that union of the Presbyterian and Methodist Churches will solve the problem in future years and I am disposed to make a special effort at this time to assist you. My suggestion is that you arrange to have a representative of the Brandon school visit the Protestant reserves from Sarnia to Hud Lake with a view to enrolling the physically fit orphan and destitute children. The Rev. Mr. McFitty can put you in touch with many applicants for admission to the Mt. Elgin Institute. As you are aware, that institution is filled to the limit of its accommodation.

The Department will give you every help, by corresponding with the agents, and will assist in gathering up any children who are orphans and without legal guardians. Destitute children present a more delicate problem, as the full concurrence of the parents would have to be secured. The expenses of your officer cannot, of course, be met by Parliamentary Appropriation. However, if success attends the effort, the Department would be responsible for the transportation of the children themselves to Brandon.

If this course of action recommends itself to you, your recruiting agent should first visit the Department and receive advice and instruction. Following his tour of the reserves, he should report again to Ottawa and we could then arrange for concerted action on the part of our representatives in the agencies. Children could be gathered at some central point and a special car, if the number warranted such accommodation, could be secured from one of the transportation companies.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. T. Ferrier,
Superintendent,
Methodist Indian Schools,
Brandon, Man.

September 29th 1925

W.M. Graham Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir,

In accordance with your instructions, I went down to Brandon on the 3rd inst. to inspect the books of the Brandon Residential School. I found only one book in use in the institution. This book is called, Receipts and Expenditures of Cash. The left hand side of this book's pages shows the receipts of cash. The right side of the folio detailed the expenditures, columned under various headings. There was neither Invoice book, Journal, nor ledger in use. These latter books I feel are needed in this school, together with another Cash Book, that a proper record of the business of the school be kept. I would strongly advise doing away with the one book now in use, and adopting the books above mentioned in its stead. This one book is not adequate to record the business of an institution of the magnitude of the Brandon Residential School. The Invoice book need not be used, although it is a useful book. Invoices can be filed in such a manner that ready reference can be made to them in the Journal and from the Journal to the ledger. Accounts should be opened in the ledger corresponding with the various headings shown on the book in use at present. Accounts should also be opened with merchants and firms from whom goods are purchased on time, that a proper record of such dealings be placed before an auditor at any time. Although there was an amount of $5,702.94 owing to various firms, there was no record of this in any book, but was taken off.
off invoices, the information being supplied by Mr. Ferrier. These items should have been shown in a ledger, and not left haphazard on an invoice file.

I went back to January 1st 1922 and checked all the receipts from that date to Sept 4th 1925. I tested the additions, both in the receipts and expenditures, and found them correct. The receipts during the period under inspection amounted to $136,056.64. I compared this with the bank book deposits, and found that the receipts exceeded the deposits by $22,505.21; the deposits being $113,578.43. The difference was explained by Mr. Ferrier thus. An amount of $2000.00 was paid for cattle by the Mission Rooms. It was charged against the school, and was passed through the cash book, notwithstanding no cash was received. Then $500.00 were received for an old gas engine. This was turned over in payment on accounts, and was not deposited in the bank. The balance was made up of the following entries:

| Proceeds of Farm and Garden | $7000.00 |
|-----------------------------|----------|
| "                            | 1924     | $1000.00 |
| "                            | 1925     | $6000.00 |
| Rebates                     | $6.21    |
|                             |          | $20,005.21 |

This with the other two items explained above make up the $22,505.21, the difference between receipts and deposits.

There is no account with the Department of Indian affairs to show the amount of per capita grant received. The amount showing in the statement, $69,094.61 is not an actual amount taken from an account, as it should have been, but was derived at by adding all the monies received from the Mission Board, and deducting what was actually received from the Church. The balance was presumably what had been received from the Department. I will not vouch for the accuracy of the amount. I had to depend on Mr. Ferrier's information for this. To my mind an account with the Department would be one of the most important accounts in the school ledger, if a ledger were kept, as the Department is the source of revenue, and this account...
account should be carefully and accurately kept.

The credits showing to farm and garden were not detailed, but estimated and added in a lump sum at the end of the year. I had no means of checking these amounts and accepted them as they were. These credits should be accurately detailed in future and not estimated.

The bank account was overdrawn as will be seen from the adjustment statement. It seem customary for the Principal to carry on issuing cheques on the bank even if he has no funds, but his overdrafts are always taken care of when remittances are received.

The statement shows a deficit of $404.99. Accounts Payable amount to $5,702.94. To offset these amounts the Principal has in the elevator 658 bushels wheat, some rye, and more wheat to thresh. This with the grant from the Department for September quarter will nearly meet the indebtedness.

I attach herewith the following statements.

Bank adjustment
Accounts Payable
Financial Statement.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant.

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,-

In answer to your telegram:

I have interviewed the Sergeant of the Police and Magistrate Fraser re the case of Wabbie Scott. The magistrate is of the opinion that the charge should be for house breaking. This would be a clear case upon which he could commit him. He will send him to the Portage School providing they will accept him. If not, he will send him to Stony Mountain for two years. The date of the trial is to be Tuesday, November 9th at 2 P.M. In the meantime, I am writing to his father and to the Farm Instructor and enclose you copies of these letters.

If it were only a case of this boy, I would discharge him and send him home, but this is what he would like and it would place a premium on his conduct for other boys who wish to be discharged. The Sergeant of Police was down at Indian Springs for a boy, Joe Kinney, Agent Ogletree sent here. Mr. Minnelly, the Farm Instructor, requests that he not be sent to the reserve. He was a bad actor when there and hence his presence here.

If the Department has any further advice, kindly wire before Tuesday.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

R.C.M.Police
Winnipeg,Man.

Sir,

Re-Wabie Scott (Indian Boy) - Brandon Man.
Carnal Knowledge.

I have the honour to submit the following in the above connection.

The Rev.Ferrier, Principal of the Indian Industrial School at this point called at this Detachment on the afternoon of the 2nd inst and informed me that he had received word from Ottawa in the above connection and they had informed him that whatever action he took would be endorsed by the Department.

I accompanied him to the Police Magistrate, A.C.Fraser, and the matter was discussed at length, resulting in the decision that the boy as he is 18 years of age be charged with House Breaking and sent to the Penitentiary in the event of him being convicted, this it was thought would be better than a common Gaol sentence as he would have something to work at there. He was deemed too old for the reformatory.

I would now ask whether or not I should continue to handle this case on this boy in a Ward of the Government or whether I should turn it over to the Provincial Police, needless to say the Principal is desirous of keeping the matter as quiet as possible. I would further ask that if the boy is convicted and I still keep charge of the case should I escort him to the penitentiary. The trial is set for 2 p.m.of the 9th November,1926.

I have the honour to be

Sir,
Your obedient servant

CRIME REPORT.

Re-Wabie Scott (Indian Boy) - Brandon Man.

Breaking & Entering.

Previous reports in the above connection were classified as Carnal Knowledge but it will be noted that in this case the heading has been changed to Breaking and entering.

At the request of the Rev.Ferrier of the Indian Boarding School at this point I instructed Cst.Johnson of this Detachment to proceed in Auto Livery to the said School and take the above boy in charge and escort him back to the Police Court, and to have him there in time to appear before Police Magistrate at 2 p.m. This was on the 9th November, 1926.

At 2 p.m. the Rev.Ferrier and Mr.Fraser and myself discussed the question and I recommended that the charge should be Carnal Knowledge. Mr.Fraser however on having been informed that by the Rev.Ferrier that the boy was registered at 17 years of age at his school decided that he would handle the matter under the Child Welfare Act charging Scott with Breaking and entering the Indian Industrial School on the 6th October, 1926 and being guilty of other improper conduct at such time and place. Mr.Fraser acting in his capacity of Judge of the Juvenile Court read the charge which was in the form of a Complaint made by the Rev.Ferrier, and when offered a plea of Guilty, the situation was explained fully to the prisoner and also to an Uncle of the boy who had come to Brandon for the trial from the Indian Springs Reserve, he having been notified by Mr.Ferrier of the happenings. The Judge committed the accused to the Industrial School at Portage la Prairie for an Indeterminate period not exceeding one year. Warrant of Commitment was handed to me.

Cst.Morley of this Force who is stationed here having arrived here on other Police Duties will take this boy to the Reformatory at Portage la Prairie. On his way to Winnipeg, he will leave here on the O.N.R. leaving this point at 4.30 a.m.of the 11th inst.

Receipts will be obtained from Cst.Morley for the prisoner and a further report will be submitted covering same.

Miles travelled by Auto-----10

November 25th, 1926.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Re Wabbie Scott, pupil of this school:

Wabbie appeared before Magistrate Fraser of Brandon on the 9th inst. He was charged with house breaking, to which he pleaded guilty. On his behalf, I requested that he be tried under the juvenile act as he is seventeen years of age on our report. This made it possible to have him committed to the Portage Industrial School. He was sent there for a year with the understanding that if his behavior was good that he be allowed out on parole.

His uncle arrived here on his behalf and was given to understand that he could engage legal advice if he so desired and should the charge be made under the criminal code. When he found out what the boy was guilty of and that the management of the school as well as the magistrate were inclined to be as lenient as possible by having the case in the juvenile court, he concluded that legal advice was not required.

I trust that what has been done in this case will meet with the approval of the Department. It is the first time in an experience of twenty-seven years that I have had to take legal action against a boy for crime. When I consider the large number of boys and girls I have taken into this school for crime of one kind and another, the wonder is that I have had so few turn out incorrigible.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

We have three of our girl pupils who have passed
the Entrance Examination and there are two more coming in
from Round Lake School. Our senior teacher, Mr. Wilson,
is taking up Grade Nine with these five pupils. We are
also sending two of our pupils to take up Grade Ten in
the Brandon Collegiate. May we expect the special grant
of $50 for each of these seven pupils?

Winnie Steinhauer, a pupil of our school, has
passed Grade Eleven this summer. We made application to
get her into the Normal School here but found that the
capacity was filled by students who had made application
previous to last March. She is now enrolled for the
session opening September, 1928. She wishes now to take
up Grade Twelve. This grade is not taught at the Brandon
Collegiate, but is at the Brandon College where we purpose
sending her during this coming year. The fees at the college
will be $90. The regular fee is $75 but other charges which
have to be met amount to $15. Would the Department pay this
$90 over and above the special grant of $50?

We will be put to the expense of taking her in and
out, somewhat special clothing which she will require, she
will have to give all her time to her studies and it is
more than likely that she will have to take her lunch at
the college which will be 40¢ a day. She is an exceptionally
fine girl and a very clever student and she is worthy of
anything we can do for her.

Trusting this will receive favorable consideration,

I remain

Yours respectfully,

Dear Dr. Scott:

It was my intention to have visited Ottawa when Rev. Thompson Ferrier was there recently for the purpose of interviewing the Honorable Charles Stewart and yourself regarding the necessity and desirability of building a new school at Brandon.

The main building is thirty-four years old and far from modern. It is inadequate to carry on the work and has outlived its usefulness.

It has served the Lake Winnipeg District for all these years and still retains a large part of this constituency. Over fifty of its present enrolment are from this district. During the last year, the Nelson River Valley has been opened up and sixteen new pupils have been sent in from Nelson House.

A large number have been taken in from the courts, incorrigibles from other schools and orphans from many places, saving many from lives of crime and shame. The whole work has been carried on with a good degree of success, a heritage that should not be lost.

The Department owns the farm of over 900 acres of land which, with the outbuildings, is valued at $200,000.00, a property well adapted to carrying on the work of training Indian boys for farming, gardening, and caring for livestock. We are in a position to give advanced training in these occupations to boys from other parts. This should be made a specialty.

Pupils from this school have been attending the Brandon Collegiate. Six were in attendance last year. Others would have been there this year if arrangements could have been made to send them. To meet their need a class of grade nine pupils is being taught in the Institute, four of these are from other schools. This work might be enlarged if there was sufficient accommodation in the present building.

The location of this school is strategically situated for visitors. Every year they come from all parts of Canada, as well as from other lands. The usual comment is that our main building is not in keeping with the beautiful farm, lawns, gardens and outbuildings.
Duncan C. Scott, Esq., Litt.D., F.R.S.C.

I believe you have recently visited the school and are fully convinced that the time has come when a new building should be erected. I trust that the next Parliament will make provision for putting up the proposed new school.

Wishing you the Compliments of the Season,

I am,

Very faithfully yours,

[Signature]

GEMr. AMA

Dear Sir:

Your letter of October 1, re fees for Non-Resident pupils was placed before the Board at our meeting last night.

The members felt that the responsibility for these fees should really be assumed by the Department of Indian Affairs, and I was instructed to write you asking that you take the matter up with the proper authorities and with a view to getting them to pay the fees.

The cost of instruction in our Collegiate last year was $87.00 per pupil, although a portion of that cost which we are allowed to charge is only $64.60 per pupil.

It was felt that if the pupils from the Industrial School paid $50.00, which is the amount paid by the Department in the case of other Non-Resident pupils, that this would be a reasonable charge. In the case of ordinary Non-Residents, the Department pays $50.00 a year and the Municipalities pay the balance. In your case, the Board would waive this balance.

There are, as you say, nine pupils in attendance this year, and two others attended last year, which would make a total bill for the two years of $550.00.

Hoping that you will be able to make arrangements for this, I am

Yours truly,

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 23 instant, enclosing vouchers in favour of the Brandon School Board and the Indian Residential School on account of the pupils who are studying in the city. A cheque for $500, for the ten pupils taking graduate work, is being directed to you under separate cover.

The account in favour of the Brandon School Board, for $550, is not being paid until further information is before the Department. I note that the School Board is allowed to charge $64.60 per pupil; that the Provincial Department pays $50 a year and the municipalities, the balance. In cases of this kind, the Department of Indian Affairs pays the same as is charged to municipalities, and I believe what we should allow is $44.60 per pupil per year. Please discuss this with the Secretary Treasurer of the Board and let me have a further recommendation.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I have just received the copy of letter from the Department of Indian Affairs re fees for non-resident students at our Collegiate, and am giving the following additional information regarding the amount for $550.00, which was rendered to you some time ago.

The total cost of education in our secondary school last year was $97.02 per pupil. Part of this cost we are not allowed to charge for, such as taxes, interest on investment, and proportion of overhead expense, and when these are deducted it leaves a cost of $73.52 per pupil. When the Government grant is deducted from this amount, it leaves $64.60 per pupil. It is this latter amount which we are allowed to charge non-resident pupils from surrounding municipalities.

The Department of Education pays $50.00 of this amount, but only when the student comes from an organized municipality in the Province of Manitoba. These Indians come, I presume, from reserves, which do not pay the Municipal Commissioner's Levy, and consequently do not contribute to the funds from which this $50.00 is paid. Probably some of them come from outside the province, and if so, the Department in such cases assumes no responsibility for their fees. It is just a case of the Department spreading the $50.00 amount over all municipalities paying the levy, and then asking each municipality individually to pay the balance chargeable to the students from its own municipality.

I am enclosing a copy of a letter from the Department, in which they disclaim responsibility for the fees for these students. In this letter, the last two names; namely, Mary Parker and Roy Patterson, are from outside the Province.
Now, in cases where there is no outside body to assume the fees, we charge the students direct, under section 134 (g) of the Public Schools Act, which allows only $5.00 per month. This explains the reason why the rate was placed at $5.00 a month in your account, although as a matter of fact I think the Department of Indian Affairs should pay $64.60, even although the Act is not very clear on the point.

When we charge the student direct, the amount is $5.00 a month, but when the municipality or department is responsible, the amount is $64.60. It seems to me that the Indian Department should come under the latter classification. However, this is merely in passing.

I think this should make it quite clear that the Department should assume responsibility for the fees for these students.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

FAW/MPR

Secretary-Treasurer

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6255, File 576-1, part 2)
Corner Stone of New Indian School Laid

Ceremony Attended by Representative Gathering; Historical Sketch of School

Thirty-four years after the original building was completed, the corner stone of the new Indian Industrial school was laid on Wednesday afternoon before a very representative gathering. The formal ceremonies were presided over by Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D., the present head of the school, while brief addresses were given by Dr. J. W. Atkins, president of the Manitoba conference, Dr. J. H. Edmiston, M.L.A., and Mayor Cater.

The actual laying of the corner stone was performed by the Rev. Thompson Ferrier, former principal and superintendent of Indian schools and hospitals for the United Church. Assisting in the program were the Rev. J. A. Cormie, M.D., president of missions for the Manitoba conference, Rev. R. G. Pritchard, W. H. Shillinglaw, and the Rev. D. H. Telfer, chairman of the Brandon conference. On the platform at the time were Mrs. T. Ferrier, members of the presidency and a number of ex-pupils.

During the ceremony, a splendid tribute was paid to the Rev. Thompson Ferrier for the great work accomplished by him during his long term of office, and confidence was expressed in the future of the training that will be conducted in the new building under the principalship of Dr. Doyle.

History of School

The historical sketch of the school placed in the corner stone by Rev. J. A. Doyle shows that it is part of the insistance in the policy of the Department of Indian Affairs in providing an educational and vocational training for Indian children in Canada. This educational program is carried out in cooperation with churches which years ago commenced missionary and educational work among the Indian people.

Thirty-seven years ago it was decided to establish a residential school under the care of the Methodist church, and the choice of the site here was made by the late Rev. James Woodsworth and the late Rev. Alex. Sutherland, D.D. It was three years later that the school, which has just been finished to make room for the new building, was erected, and a veteran missionary, Rev. J. Simmons, appointed principal. He was a master of the Cree language and had years of experience in Indian work. Four years later he retired and thirty years ago last June, Rev. Thompson Ferrier, then pastor of the Methodist church in Edmonton, and who laid the corner stone Wednesday, was appointed head of the institution.

Splendid progress in connection with the school and its 960 acre farm has been made, and high tribute to the business sagacity, tact and diplomacy was paid to the Rev. Thompson Ferrier for bringing the Brandon school to such a high standard. In February last, Rev. Ferrier tendered his resignation, and later the Rev. Dr. Doyle was appointed in his place.

More commodious quarters were needed and the present new structure will remedy deficiencies. During construction the pupils had to be taken care of, a number returned home where they could attend school for the present year, and 35 were taken on to the Edmonton school. It is expected that the new building will be ready for occupation in September, 1930. It will take about 150 pupils and when a number of other residential schools are filled to capacity and have waiting lists, it is expected that the new building will soon occupy in a very short time. The number of Indian pupils seeking higher education makes it necessary that high school work be undertaken as soon as school re-opens.

Thirty-four years after the original building was constructed, the cornerstone of the new Indian Industrial school was laid on Wednesday afternoon before a very representative gathering. The actual laying of the corner stone was performed by the Rev. Thompson Ferrier, former principal and superintendent of Indian schools and missions for the United Church. As part of the program were the Rev. Mr. Macdonald, D.D., president of the Manitoba conference, Rev. Mr. Critchard, W. H. Shillinglaw, Rev. D. H. Telfor, chairman of the Cranbrook presbytery. On behalf of the congregation Mrs. T. Pet. members of the presbytery and a number of ex-pupils.

During the ceremony, special tribute was paid to the Rev. Thompson Ferrier for the great work accomplished by him during his long term of office, and confidence was expressed in the future of the training that will be conducted in the new building under the principalship of Dr. Doyle.

History of School

The historical sketch of the school placed in the corner stone by Rev. Doyle showed that it is one of the institutions in the policy of the Department of Indian Affairs in providing an educational and vocational training for Indian children in Canada. This educational program is carried on in cooperation with churches which years ago commenced missionary and educational work among the Indian people.

Thirty-three years ago it was decided to establish a residential school under the care of the Methodist church, and the choice of the site here was made by the late Rev. James Woodsworth and the late Rev. Alex. Sutherland, D.D. It was three years later that the school, which had just been demolished to make room for the new building, was erected, and a veteran missionary, Rev. J. Simmons, appointed principal. He was a master of the Cree language and had years of experience in Indian work. Four years later he retired and thirty years ago last June, Rev. Thompson Ferrier, who was then pastor of the Methodist church in Edmonton, and who laid the corner stone Wednesday, was appointed head of the institution.

Splendid progress in connection with the school and its 960 acre farm has been made, and high tribute to the business sagacity, tact and diplomacy was paid to the Rev. Thompson Ferrier in bringing the Brandon school to such a high standard. In February last, Rev. Ferrier tendered his resignation, and later the Rev. Dr. Doyle was appointed in his place.

More commodious quarters were needed and the present new structure will remedy conditions. During construction the pupils had to be taken care of, a number returned home where they could attend school for the present time. While 53 were taken on the Edmonton school. It is expected that the new building will be ready for occupation in September, 1930. It will take care of 250 pupils and when the other residential schools are filled to capacity and have waiting lists, it is expected that the new building will be occupied in a very short time. Dear Sir:

I am inclosing draft of suggested letter to Agents, Missionaries, etc. I will appreciate very much your direction as to its contents.

I had some doubt in my mind in regard to advertising that pupils could attend Business College, and intended writing you soon in regard to this matter. Eliza Sutherland who wrote on grade ten last year, and who has been employed with Mrs. Hughes of this city since the school closed, is very anxious to take a Business Course, and has spoken to me a number of times about it. I had her doing some Office work before she left the school, and I believe she is quite capable of taking the course, and being very efficient in some lines especially. She wants to return to the school when it opens, and attend Business College from there. After watching her carefully since last mid-summer, I am quite decided that it would be wise to give her this chance. She is saving some money, and I think her father might be persuaded to pay at least part of the fee required at the Business College.

There is another girl about whom I believe you have had correspondence with Mr. Roy Hunter of the Juvenile Court, Dorothy Frances by name, who says she wants to take a Business course also. I have been taking an interest in this girl since her case was brought to my attention by Mr. Hunter, and the present indications are that she is by no means a bad girl, and has a good chance of making good. She is now in Mr. L. C. Ferrier's home, and is doing well. She wrote on her grade eight last summer, and wants to take grade nine and ten before taking a Business course. I would be glad to have your advice in this matter also.

I am,

yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

INDIAN SCHOOL TO BE FORMALLY OPENED JULY 18

Special Train From East to Bring 200 Guests to Ceremonies

The new Indian Industrial school will be formally opened July 18th according to plans which were disclosed today by Rev. J. A. Doyle, superintendent. Construction work has been carried forward all winter with the result that only some minor details remain to be done. It is not likely that any of the school pupils will arrive here until July 15th, but it is anticipated that the authorities will let them finish out their school year at their present place. The new school, now in charge of about 160 pupils, the building being raised as the best in the west.

The formal opening of the building will be witnessed by more than 200 guests in the city on that day. The New Orleans Southern Railroad, has arranged a special excursion train to travel through the district and it is being provided in the itinerary that a stop will be made at Brandon for the occasion. This special train will arrive at ten o'clock in the morning of July 18th, and the visitors will be taken on an inspection tour of the city and district until noon when they will arrive at the Indian school. There they will be met by members of the board of trade and members of the church organization assisting in the exercises. It is expected that several prominent speakers will be along with the special train, and will have a place on the opening ceremonies that day.
Indian Residential School

R. A. Doyle, D.D.

MEMO RE THE LAND USED BY
THE BRANDON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

As early as 1888, Dr. A. Sutherland, of the General Board of Missions of the Methodist Church, pressed for the establishment of an industrial school for the benefit of children of Lake Winnipeg Indians. The Department's policy at that time was to establish institutions in white centres and to emphasize vocational training of pupils.

In 1889, the Department approved of the scheme and the question of a suitable site was given consideration. Various localities were suggested - Fisher River, Berens River and Selkirk. Dr. Sutherland, the Rev. John McDougall and Dr. J. Woodsworth were in favour of a site in the southern part of the province. They were not satisfied, however, with the property near Carman, which was set aside by Order in Council for the school.

People of both Brandon and Carberry became interested and John Kerr, Clerk of the City of Brandon, wrote Rev. Mr. Woodsworth, of the Methodist Church, that the City Council would give a site next to the Experimental Farm and accept in exchange government lands elsewhere. Dr. Sutherland visited the West in 1891, examined the sites and recommended that the one at Brandon be secured. The City of Brandon purchased from J. W. Stewart the half section on which the school is situate. The price was $5,700. Mr. A. Kelly, Mayor of Brandon, wrote to the Department in 1891, accepting the section near Carman in trade for the site at Brandon. The site was occupied and the building operations commenced in 1892. In 1900, the deal was finally completed and regularized by Order in Council.

In 1911, the section on the hill was purchased for the use of the school for the sum of $16,000. In 1920, the City of Brandon completed a 99 year lease of the most southerly part of the school property for $6,000. 52 acres was required for municipal park purposes.

NEW INDIAN RESIDENTIAL
SCHOOL AT BRANDON CITY
OPENED FRIDAY AFTERNOON

(Special Dispatch to the Free Press)
Brandon, Man., July 18.—Brandon's new Indian residential school was opened here this afternoon in an impressive ceremony attended by some of the high officials of the United Church of Canada, and representatives of the department of Indian Affairs. The new structure is one of the finest of its kind in Canada, and those present at the opening of the building today were members of the church who had been called over in Brandon for the occasion.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D., principal of the school, spoke briefly about the aims of the institution and to the work it is doing. Hon. T. A. Cressy, minister of Indian Affairs, made a brief but made mention of the partly of the country. Russell T. Ferrier, education for Canada, spoke of the place education plays in the work of the department, and that experience indicated that residential schools are needed. Rev. J. H. Smith, of Regina, was present and, after re- diction of the students, he officially handed over the key of the building to the Rev. D. B. S. general secretary of the board of mission affairs of the United Church of Canada.

Rev. J. A. Doyle mentioned the valued services of Mr. Ferrier and congratulated him on his superintendence administration of the school. The dedication service was in the hands of G. W. Macdonald, minister of the United Church, Dr. Cochran, president of the church, and D.D., president of the Manitoba con- gregation, spoke. Addresses were also given from Rev. Thompson, Ferrier, Rev. W. H. Whitehead, Rev. G. R. Cox and others.

GOD SAVE THE KING.
NEW RESIDENTIAL INDIAN SCHOOL FORMALLY OPENED

Building Was Officially Handed Over to United Church in Canada

In the presence of an audience that filled the small auditorium to overflowing, Brandon's new Indian residential school was officially opened on Friday by officials of the Indian department and representatives of the United Church in Canada. In addition there were 150 special guests who were touring the west on the New Outlook excursion. Quite a large number of Brandon citizens availed themselves of the opportunity not only of attending the official opening but of inspecting this new building as well. The school is probably the finest of its kind in Canada and was favorably commented on by hundreds who went through it on Friday.

The program began early in the auditorium of the building with the Salvation Army band in attendance to furnish the music throughout the program. Rev. J. A. Doyle D.D., principal of the school, presided, while groups of about 200 performers were leading officials of the United Church and of the Indian department. In his introductory charge, Rev. Doyle emphasized the work that the school is doing, of its objective to send students back to their homes with Christian influence in the community, and of all the efforts being made by the school to make its program successfully.

Need of Schools

Hon. T. A. Crevar was present and in a brief address he said it gave him great satisfaction that the long-recognized need was finally coming to the Indians. Russell T. Perrier, M.A., superintendent of education, said that protection and education are two of the primary duties of the department he represented, and he told of the efforts made in times of education. Experience had taught them that residential schools are very necessary in planning the future life of the Indians, and he told of the steps that had been taken up to the erection of the new school.

Referring to the fact that it is quite necessary to turn the Indians to agriculture, Commissioner Graham of Regina gave figures to show that the number of Indians who now own thousands of acres of land under cultivation each year. As a sign of the times, he then handed the key of the building over to Rev. R. B. Codrane D.D., representing the United Church in Canada. The latter in his remarks paid special tribute to the sterling work of the Rev. Thomas Miller, who informed him that he was interested actively in Indian affairs, to the general work of the Board of Education in the question of schools, and congratulated Dr. Doyle on his administration.

The address of welcome was ably handled by G. W. Mason K.C., of Toronto, representing the moderator of the United Church in Canada, and the Rev. J. George Miller F.R.G.S., D.D., president of the Manitoba conference, greeted the audience from the platform from Rev. S. Wikens B.A., D.D., representing the Bishop of Brandon, who had been elected moderator of the synod of Manitoba of the Presbyterian church, but received from Rev. Thomas Miller, who was also representative of the Catholic church.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6255, File 576-1, part 2)
Great advancement has been made in Canada, particularly of late years, in providing our Indian population with a high standard of educational and vocational training. Through the aid of increased appropriations and personnel during that time, the Department of Indian Affairs has been enabled to enlarge existing buildings and construct new model rural and progressive schools, whilst higher salaries and grants have attracted better qualified teachers and instructors.

There are now 78 residential schools and 272 day schools, making a total of 350 centres of Indian education and activity. The total number of pupils is now 15,743, the average attendance being 11,579, constituting an increase during the past ten years of 25 per cent in enrolment and 6 per cent in attendance, ample evidence of the success of the work in preparing Indian children to become self-supporting citizens of the Dominion.

The residential schools are conducted by the Anglican Church, the Catholic, Presbyterian, and United churches, and high tribute must be paid to the zeal and self-sacrifice of those engaged in the work. The present administration, the close co-operation of religious denominations in the education of the Indians, and this well-meaning policy has demonstrated beyond all question the effectiveness of the system.

The formal opening of the modern residential school at Brandon, Manitoba, on July 18, 1930, adds another unit to the fine system of Indian educational institutions throughout the Dominion. It will be administered by the United Church of Canada and will have as its principal the Reverend A. A. Doyt. Dr. Duncan C. Scott, the modern educationist, the Reverend Thompson Ferrier.

This school, which replaces the residential school built on the same site in 1894, is one of the finest of its kind in Canada. Built of tapestry brick with trim of Manitoba limestone and a razzoo floor, it is fireproof throughout. Some idea of the accommodation afforded may be gleaned from the fact that it has five large dormitories, four dormitories, four class-rooms, a large study room, recreation rooms for both girls and boys, separate bath-room, hospital equipped with nurses' quarters, also a laundry equipped with the most modern hygienic appliances.

Adjacent to the school are a number of first-class farm buildings, one of which, the cow-barn, is one of the finest in Manitoba. There are, also, four residences for the use of the principal and married members of the staff.

The institution has a landscaped setting, and places it on a par with some of the finest schools and colleges of the older provinces. Brandon is situated on the north slope of the Assiniboine valley. The Indian school is on the north side of the valley, three miles northwest of the city and is between the Golf Club and the Dominion Experimental Farm. To the east, on the same ridge, is a large provincial hospital.

This school draws its pupils from widely ranging, owing to the scarcity of local resources. Residential schools are required because many of the Indians are engaged in occupations which prevent them from attending day schools, such as hunting, trapping, which take them away from their homes; and even the farms of those engaged in agriculture are not solidly built near white settlements, but are strung out along rivers and lakes, thus making it impossible to provide day-school accommodation for the greater portion of the pupils.

The curriculum provides academic instruction equivalent to the second year of secondary school. In addition, the girls are given a thorough training in domestic science, and the boys, a course of study together with a preliminary training in carpentry, blacksmithing, and the operation of internal combustion engines, sufficient to enable them to acquire a practical mastery in modern farm life.

While every possible effort is made to secure a sound moral and mental education, special attention is given to the health of the pupils. During the years spent in the residential schools, medical treatment is provided, which, with a balanced diet, and supervised recreation, assists in the building up of a robust constitution.

Under the care and tutelage of the Department of Indian Affairs the prairie Indian has now become a successful agriculturist. The official records for 1928 show that 65,104 acres in the Prairie Provinces alone, were sown to grain from seed of the approved seed-breeders. In addition, 971 acres were planted to root crops from which 61,448 bushels were harvested; and 97,706 tons of hay and other fodder were produced.

IMPROVE FACILITIES FOR INDIAN EDUCATION

Department of Indian Affairs Opens New Residential School at Brandon, Manitoba

Great advances have been made in Canada, particularly in late years, in providing our Indian population with a high standard of education and vocational training. Through the bill of increased appropriations by Parliament during that time, the Department of Indian Affairs has been enabled to make large existing buildings, and construct more modern and fireproof schools, while the grants and grants have attracted better qualified teachers and instructors.

There are now 78 residential schools and 372 day schools, making a total of 350 centres of Indian educational activity. The total number of pupils is now 15,757, the average attendance being 11,579, constituting an increase during the past ten years of 28 per cent in enrolment. In addition to these figures, ample evidence of the success of the work in preparing Indian children for citizenship and self-supporting citizens of the Dominion.

The residential schools are conducted by the Anglican, Roman Catholic, Presbyterian, and United churches, and high tribute must be paid to the zeal and self-sacrifice of those engaged in the work. The Department has had the close cooperation of religious denominations in the education of the Indians, and its welfare work has demonstrated beyond all question the effectiveness of the system.

The new school opened recently, the modern residential school at Brandon, Manitoba, on July 18, 1930, adds another unit to the fine system of Indian educational institutions throughout the Dominion. It will be administered by the United Church of Canada and will have its principal in charge Mr. J. W. Doyle, D.D., who succeeds the veteran educator the Reverend Thompson Foster.

This school, which replaces the residential school built on the same site in 1896, is one of the finest of its kind in Canada. Built of tapestry brick with trim of Manitoba limestone, and terrazzo floors, it is equipped throughout. Some idea of the accommodations afforded may be gleaned from the fact that it has a fine large assembly hall, four dormitories, two dining rooms, large study room, recreation rooms for both girls and boys, sewing room, sun-room, gymnasium, and numerous other facilities, also a laundry equipped with the most modern hygienic appliances.

Adjacent to the school are a number of first-class farm buildings, one of which, the cow-tarn, is one of the finest in its class north or south. These are residences for the use of the principal and married members of the staff.

The situation is a picturesque setting, which places it on a par with some of the finest schools and colleges of older provenance. Brandon itself is situated on the south side of the Assiniboine valley. The Indian school is on the north side of the valley, three miles north-west of Brandon and "be-

between the Golf Club and the Dominion Experimental Farm. To the east, on the same ridge, is a large provincial park.

This school draws its pupils from a wide radius, owing to the scattered location of the reserves. Residential schools are located because many of the Indians are engaged in occupations such as lumbering, fishing, freighting, and trapping, and take their wives away from their homes; and even the farms of those engaged in agriculture are not within walking distance of the reserves but are string out along rivers and lakes, thus making it impossible to provide suitable accommodation for the major portion of them.

The curriculum provides academic instruction equivalent to the second year in high schools, in addition the girls are given a thorough training in domestic science, and the boys, a course in various trades, including elementary training in carpentry, blacksmithing, and the operation of internal combustion engines sufficient to enable them to apply it in a practical manner in modern farm life.

In addition to the effort made to impart a sound academic and industrial education, special attention is given to the health of the pupils. During the past year, in addition to school medical treatment, is provided, which, with a balanced diet, and supervised exercise, has assisted in building up a robust constitution.

Under the care and tutelage of the Department of Indian Affairs the prairie Indian has now become a successful agriculturist. Official statistics show that 65,104 acres in the Prairie Provinces alone, were sown to grain, from which were harvested 1,671,971 acres were planted to root crops from which 61,448 bushels were harvested; and 67,766 tons of hay and other fodder were produced.

BRANDON, MANITOBA

REV. J. A. DOYLE, D.D.
PRINCIPAL
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.,
March 16, 1931

To Indian Agents, Missionaries, Teachers,
Chiefs and Parents or Guardians
of Indian Children

Greetings:

We wrote you a year ago when our new School was in process of building. We are writing now to give you further information in regard to our building, our pupils, our Staff and our prospects for the future.

Our New School Building

We are glad to present in this letter a picture of the new building. A splendid article on "Improved Facilities for Indian Education," which appeared in the October issue of "Natural Resources, Canada" contains the following description of our School:

"The formal opening of the modern residential school at Brandon, Manitoba, on July 18, 1930, adds another unit to the fine system of Indian educational institutions throughout the Dominion. It is administered by the United Church of Canada and has as its Principal the Reverend J. A. Doyle, D.D., who succeeds the veteran educationist the Reverend Thompson Ferrier.

"This School, which replaces the residential school built on the same site in 1894, is one of the finest of its kind in Canada. Built of tapestry brick with trim of Manitoba limestone, and terazzo floors, it is fireproof throughout. Some idea of the accommodation afforded may be gleaned from the fact that it has a fine assembly hall, four dormitories, four class rooms, two large study rooms, recreation rooms for both girls and boys, sewing room, sun rooms, hospital ward with nurses' quarters, also a laundry equipped with the most modern hygienic appliances.

"Adjacent to the school are a number of first-class farm buildings, one of which, the cow barn, is one of the finest in Manitoba. There are, also, four residences for the use of the Principal and married members of the Staff.

"The institution has a landscape setting, which places it on a par with some of the finest schools and colleges of the older provinces. Brandon city is situated on the south slope of the Assiniboine Valley. The Indian school is on the north side of the valley, three miles northwest of the city and is between the Golf Club and the Dominion Experimental Farm. To the east, on the same ridge, is a large provincial hospital."
Our Staff

We wish you could meet each member of our very excellent Staff. Next best we give you herewith their picture, with their names and the positions they occupy.

The following is the motto adopted by the Staff for the School: "The purpose of this School is to achieve the best possible development of the Physical, Mental, Moral and Spiritual life of each pupil under its care." We believe that every member of the Staff is whole-heartedly doing their best to carry out this purpose.

Our Pupils

You can see by the picture on the cover of this letter what a fine looking group of pupils we have in the School. In age they range from four years to over twenty years, and in school classes from little tots in a Kindergarten class to young men and women taking High School grades nine, ten and eleven. The Inspector of Schools has given us a splendid report. One student is going to Brandon Collegiate, taking Grade Twelve. Another attends the Business College in Brandon and still another the Normal School. We are anxious to give every pupil the best possible education and at the same time train them in every way to become happy, successful and useful citizens when they go out to take their place in life.

Every girl in the School is getting a good training in Household Science, and every boy is trained in Farming, Gardening, Stockraising, the use and care of Tools and Machinery. Each year a number of our older boys attend the Tractor School put on by the International Harvester Company. When our boys graduate they are in good demand for farm help.

Future Prospects

This School accommodates 160 pupils. We now have 150 on the roll and every month new names are being added. Our capacity will be reached by mid-summer. Eight or ten, we expect, will graduate this summer and will make room for that many new pupils. We, therefore, wish to urge that those planning to send pupils have the Application for Admission filled out by the Agent as early as possible and sent to Ottawa for approval.

As we have two University Graduates on our Teaching Staff, both of whom are splendid teachers, we are in a position to take as many High School students as can come. We would suggest to prospective High School pupils especially, that your Application be sent in with as little delay as possible.

Please write us for any information you may desire, and we will be glad to have any word from you which you think would help us.

Thanking you for your co-operation and help.

I am,
Yours sincerely,
J. A. DOYLE.

PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., May 12th, 1931

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I learned that it has been the custom in this School in the past to allow a good number of the older girls to attend C.G.I.T. Camp for ten days, which is held on a little lake about ten miles south of Belmont and I find that the Department has been making a grant of $100.00 for this purpose and I do not think that any money has been spent that has given a better return in the life and conduct of the pupils than has this money.

This year we have a number of older girls whom on the advice of the Agent or Missionary we are not allowing home for holidays as well as a number of others would be greatly helped by a Camp of this kind. There are 18 in all and two leaders from our Staff will be required to accompany them. The cost for the camp for the ten days is $7.50, in addition to cost of transportation and some extra expenses. We can use our truck to take them to the camp and bring them back and we will be glad if the Department can see fit to give us $160 which is the actual cost of the Camp.

I might point out that when $100 was granted 12 girls were sent. Awaiting your reply,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.
