VERY POOR COPY
Indian Reservation School, Brandon

The New Outlook is glad to know that the work which was started on with such splendid success by the Rev. T. Perrier for thirty years is making fine progress under the new management. Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D., and his efficient staff find the new building, which opened at year ago and opened July, 1930, an ideal place for the task. This school, which replaces the residential school built on the same site in 1894, is one of the finest of its kind in Canada. Built of superior brick with trim of Manitoba limestone, and terrazzo floors, it is fireproof throughout. Some idea of the accommodation afforded may be gleaned from the fact that it has a fine assembly hall, four dormitories, four class rooms, two large study rooms, recreation rooms for girls and boys, sewing room, sun room, hospital ward, teachers' quarters, also a laundry equipped with the most modern hygienic appliances.

This plant, with a good farm and suitable residences for the married members of staff situated on a fine landscape setting north of the city of Brandon, is the property of the Dominion Governments but operated by The United Church of Canada.

There is accommodation for one hundred and sixty children. During the first year of the new management there are one hundred and fifty-five in attendance. The prospects for next academic year are a school filled to capacity with a waiting list.

It is a real home for the children, as the spirit and atmosphere of family life are demanded to a high degree. The academic work is excellent, two of the teachers are graduates in Arts, and high school work, including Grade XI, is given. On the other hand the smaller children are well cared for by an expert in kindergarten work.

Recently under the guidance of Miss Dorothy Doyle, able assisted by other members of the staff and Miss G. W. Wood, a special dramatic evening was given in the assembly hall, one evening for the pupils and the staff, the following evening for visitors. The effort was to represent the coming of spring and the crowning of the May Queen. It was one of those occasions which cannot be described in words, but the costumes of the little ones, especially by the pupils, and the graceful action of those who took part was fascinating in the extreme.

There is a great future for this school as a builder of Canadian manhood and womanhood.

conditioning of the automobile. This work is carried on, on various makes of engines, automobiles and trucks. In the third year the entire day is spent in the shop.

Related Work

The other fifty per cent of the student's time is occupied in related work and includes the following subjects:

Theory—

Three hours a week covering the theory of the gasoline engine and the various units in the automobile. Also lectures on, wrong practices in the shop, and shop knowledge.

Drawing—

Three hours a week and consisting of free hand sketching for the most part of the different parts and units making up the complete automobile.

Mathematics—

Four and one-half hours a week. This includes what is known as shop mathematics and is the material which a mechanic must know and understand for the intelligent carrying on of the various operations of his trade.

Science—

Three hours a week. Including physics, and chemistry as related to a thorough understanding of the principles of the various parts of an automobile.

English—

One and one-half hours a week. This enables the student to spell and write correctly so that no difficulty will be encountered in making out written reports, time cards, etc. Business correspondence and accounts.

Written examinations are carried on from time to time covering these subjects and a grade of 65% must be attained for passing.

Before a diploma is issued to graduates of the three year course it will be necessary for the student to present a satisfactory certificate of employment covering at least six months in a garage.

For further particulars apply to

T. A. NEELIN, Superintendent of Schools,
Park School, Brandon, Man.

H. C. AUSTIN, Principal Technical School
Brandon, Manitoba.

BRANDON TECHNICAL SCHOOL
Brandon, Manitoba.
Established 1929

Under the direction of the Department of Education and the Brandon School Board

The school was organized in 1929 and at the present instruction is confined to auto mechanics and oxy-acetylene welding. The school is located on the corner of 11th Street and McTavish Avenue, Brandon, Manitoba, just south of the Winter Fair Building.

Calendar—1931-1932
Wednesday, Sept. 30—Registration day.
Thursday, Oct. 1—Class starts for First Year Students.
Monday, Nov. 2—Second Year Course starts in Automotive Electricity.
Monday, Nov. 30—Third Year Course starts in Automotive Welding and for specializing in Automotive Electricity.
Friday, Dec. 18—School closes for Christmas Vacation.
Monday, Jan. 4—School opens for all classes.
Friday, Feb. 26—Third Year course closes.
Friday, Mar. 25—Second Year course closes.
Friday, April 29—First Year course closes.

Conditions of Admission to the School

Applications will be received from any person 16 years of age or over, who wishes to take the course in Automobile Mechanics. In case the number of applications exceeds the accommodation facilities of the school the right is reserved to select those applicants who appear to have qualifications that are essential for success in such a course. Entering students should have academic schooling to Grade VII. or VIII. at least, for best results.

Applications for admission should be made as early as possible before the opening of the course. Forms for this purpose may be secured either at the School or at the School Board Office located in the Park School.

The School will issue certificates to all students who have completed satisfactorily the year's work. Diplomas will be issued to all students who have completed the regular three years' course satisfactorily. (Passing marks, 65 per cent).

No student will be eligible to receive a certificate or diploma who has not been in attendance 90 per cent of the time specified for the course, except in such cases where allowance may be made for past experience or training.

Students will be required to provide themselves with a set of tools, books, etc., estimated to cost about $15.00.

The discipline of the school throws responsibility for regularity and punctuality in attendance at classes on the student. Defacement of equipment or buildings is considered a grievous offence and is punishable by having the offender make good the damage done.

Brandon, Man.
To Indian Agents, Missionaries, Teachers, Chiefs and Parents or Guardians of Indian Children

GREETINGS:

We wish in the first place to thank most sincerely, especially the Agents and Missionaries, who have been so helpful to us during the past year in connection with the pupils which have come to us from your Reserves. We do appreciate your kindly co-operation and we are anxious to have you visit our School and get a first-hand knowledge of the work we are trying to do. In the meantime we are glad to give you as much information as we can concerning your boys and girls under our care.

The picture of the pupils which we present on the back page of this letter is divided into three groups according to their class room work.

The Intermediate Class Room Pupils

The top section of the picture includes the pupils in Grades III-VII. Miss W. E. Steinhauer, the teacher, is a graduate from this School. She attended Brandon Collegiate Institute and Brandon College until she secured her Grade XII, and the year following secured her Normal Diploma in the Brandon Normal School.

The Senior Grades

The middle group in the picture includes the members of the staff and all the pupils from Grade VII up. Miss D. E. Werthenbach, B.A., who is an Honour Graduate of Alberta University, is the teacher of this room. Twenty-two pupils are taking Grade IX, two in Grade X, one goes to Brandon Collegiate taking Grade XI, and her work is pronounced "very satisfactory" by the Principal of the Collegiate. One attends the Brandon Normal School and will graduate in June as a fully-qualified teacher. Three boys are attending the Brandon Technical School which gives a three-years course in Automobile Mechanics and which should qualify the student in every way to take any position in an up-to-date garage. One girl has just finished a Business Course in the Wheat City Business College in Brandon.

Primary Grades

The bottom group includes a kindergarten class and Grades I and II. Miss D. L. Doyle, who is a Scholarship Graduate of Chicago Teachers' College, is the teacher, and Miss Doris Ireton, B.A., a graduate of Brandon College, has been supplying for the last few months.

The class room work is inspected regularly by Inspector J. Boyd Morrison of the Department of Education for Manitoba, and his reports state very definitely that satisfactory progress is being made in every department of the class room work.

The Health of the Pupils

We are watching this phase of our school life very carefully. Our Matron, Mrs. Gertrude Mason, is equipped with that experience and those qualities of mind and heart which enable her to be a real mother to the pupils, and she is quick to observe anything physically wrong with any of them. The Boys' Matron, Miss M. Cranna, has had a partial hospital training, and renders the best of service in caring for any who are sick. A Doctor is called whenever necessary. In addition we now have the services of the Ninette Clinic. These doctors come from time to time and examine most thoroughly all new pupils and any others who may be suspected of developing serious trouble. The X-ray plates show that four out of five of all our pupils have had something trouble before coming to the School. This shows the urgent need of this watchful service.

A wholesome and balanced diet is being followed. The pupils are weighed regularly, and satisfactory gains in weight are recorded. A number of boys gained from twenty to thirty pounds each during the first three months of the school year, and taken altogether the Ninette Clinic found the pupils averaged five per cent overweight for girls and boys of their age and height.

The other departments of the School's life and training are being carried on satisfactorily. Miss R. Harland, the Girls' Matron, in a very kindly and tactful manner is carefully looking after the welfare of the girls. She is also stenographer and office assistant.
The Sewing Room

This department is under the efficient management of Miss M. McDonald, and under her charge many of the girls are showing marked ability in mending, dressmaking and fancy work.

Kitchen and Dining Room

An experienced and capable dietician in the person of Miss H. Reeder has charge of the kitchen and dining room, and the healthy appearance of the pupils proves her efficiency.

The Laundry

Our girls are being well-trained in all phases of laundry work by Miss L. Barager, who has charge of this department. She is painstaking and thorough-going in her work.

Farming

No matter what other education our boys receive it is our purpose that every one of them shall be given a good training in farming. The farm consists of 960 acres, and the Farm Manager and Instructor, Mr. W. E. Wood, is well qualified for his position.

Stock-Raising

Mr. C. H. Waldon is our careful and efficient Stockman, and is giving our boys a careful training in this connection. Our milch herd of dual-purpose pedigreed Shorthorns is pronounced by Hon. Robert Weir, B.A., Minister of Agriculture for the Dominion, one of the very best dual-purpose Shorthorn herds in the Prairie Provinces. Every animal is under Govt. inspection, and only healthy, good-producing cows are being kept in the herd.

Mechanical Work

Training in the care of machinery and implements and in mechanical work generally is by no means neglected, and this department is under the care of a capable mechanic in the person of Mr. H. Bicknell.

Sports

Football, softball, skating, hockey, etc., are thoroughly enjoyed by our pupils. Mr. Ernest McEwen, an outstanding athlete and a leader in boys' work, is coming on our staff next year and will direct the sports and athletic life of our School.

Singing and Music

A choral class of boys and girls is being voluntarily trained by Miss Jean Doyle to compete in the Musical Festival to be held in Brandon in May. Pupils chosen for this work are showing real promise.

Moral and Religious Life

We have no hesitation in stating that the moral and religious and general atmosphere of the School has greatly improved during the past year. More and more the pupils are taking an active part in our religious services and are showing a deeper interest in the worthwhile things of life.

Prospects for the Future

We now have 161 pupils in the School and a small waiting list. We expect, however, that ten or twelve pupils, at least, will graduate this year. We, therefore, wish to repeat our urgent appeal that those planning to send pupils will have the Application for Admission filled out by the Agent as early as possible and sent to Ottawa for approval. We can take a few new pupils in April and a number more after July 1st.

We would especially urge that prospective High School pupils have their Applications sent in with as little delay as possible.

Please write to us for any information you may desire, and thanking you again for your cooperation and help.

I am, Yours sincerely,

Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man., March 21, 1952.

J. A. DOYLE.
Indian Residential School

PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Sept. 13th, '32

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

As prices for all farm produce continue to be very low, and as the cost of supplies required in our school have not been proportionately reduced in price, we are finding it difficult to meet our requirements on the reduced Per Capita Grant. I am therefore, writing you to see if you will not permit us to increase the number of pupils for which we receive grant to 165 instead of 160. This would meet our requirements fairly satisfactorily and enable us to maintain the good standard which I feel we have reached in the maintenance of our school both in regard to food, clothing and education.

In another letter of this date I am giving a somewhat detailed report of our recent examinations.

Trusting that the above request may meet with favorable consideration,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle,
Ottawa, September 19, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, requesting an increase in pupilage at the Brandon Indian Residential School from the present number for which the grant is allowed, viz., 160, to 165 pupils.

In reply I regret that, as our funds this year are extremely limited, it will not be possible to provide the funds required in increasing the pupilage at this school. Consideration will be given to an increase in the pupilage to the number asked for when our Estimates are being prepared for the next fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.
We are looking forward to a good year this year. We have two pupils finishing Grade XI and taking part of Grade XII, one of these is Elsie McGaren, daughter of Mrs. McKay Flett, of Elphinstone. She attended the Birtle School and Mr Currie will write you in regard to her transfer to this school. Her father brought her over yesterday. We have two other pupils taking Grade XI, eight are studying in Grade X, eleven are registered in Grade IX, and seven in the Technical School. Two of the Grade IX boys have just applied to be transferred to the Technical School, but it is still doubtful whether they can be accepted or not on account of a city regulation to have two-thirds of their students from the city of Brandon.

I have come to value this Technical School training as very desirable for our boys. They take to it splendidly, manifesting great interest and efficiency.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle,
Indian Residential School

Dear Sir:

I felt I should write you giving information as to the success of our pupils at the recent Examinations.

21 pupils wrote Grade IX.
2 wrote Grade X
1 wrote Grade XI
5 first year in Technical school,
1 Teachers' Normal School and
2 wrote Grade VIII.

Four passed with Honours, two others had within an average of half a mark of Honours, 19 passed clear on all subjects, two had one supplemental and two had two supplementals. Therefore 63 1/3% of those that wrote had a clean sheet, 13 1/3 passed conditionally.

Brandon, Man.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

Referring again to my letter of February 22nd requesting your consideration of an increase of five in our pupilage and to your reply of February 26, #133-0-1, in which you request me to write again about the middle of April. I wish to cite the following points in this connection.

This increased number can be accommodated in our dormitories, dining room and class rooms, without any inconvenience. We would, however, require a few more beds.

Desirable and promising pupils are available and, in fact, are being urged upon us.

Financing is becoming increasingly difficult. Resulting from our reduced per capita grant, profit from farm produce has become in some things almost and in others altogether negligible. Commodity taxes, by both dominion and provincial, are adding much to the cost of many things we have to buy.

The Board of Home Missions, that might otherwise relieve us, is now taxed to the limit of its resources in providing the ordinances of the Church and in many cases material relief to Canadian people in the increasing number of impoverished districts and settlements.

If this increase in our pupilage can be granted it will help us materially and will be very much appreciated.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

To Indian Agents, Missionaries, Teachers, Chiefs and Parents or Guardians of Indian Children

Greetings:

We wish in the first place to thank most sincerely, especially the Agents and Missionaries, who have been so helpful to us during the past year in connection with the pupils which have come to us from your Reserves. We do appreciate your kindly cooperation, and we are anxious to have you visit our School and get a first-hand knowledge of the work we are trying to do. In the meantime we are glad to give you as much information as we can concerning your boys and girls under our care.

The picture of the pupils which we present on the back page of this letter is divided into three groups according to their class room work.

The Intermediate Class Room Pupils

The top section of the picture includes the pupils in Grades III-VII. Miss W. E. Steinhauer, the teacher, is a graduate from this School. She attended Brandon Collegiate Institute and Brandon College until she secured her Grade XII, and the year following secured her Normal Diploma in the Brandon Normal School.

The Senior Grades

The middle group in the picture includes the members of the staff and all the pupils from Grade VII up. Miss D. E. Werthenbach, B.A., who is an Honour Graduate of Alberta University, is the teacher of this room. Twenty-two pupils are taking Grade IX, two are in Grade X, one goes to Brandon Collegiate taking Grade XI, and her work is pronounced "very satisfactory" by the Principal of the Collegiate. One attends the Brandon Normal School and will graduate in June as a fully-qualified teacher. Three boys are attending the Brandon Technical School which gives a three-years course in Automobile Mechanics and which should qualify the student in every way to take any position in an up-to-date garage. One girl has just finished a Business Course in the Wheat City Business College in Brandon.

Primary Grades

The bottom group includes a kindergarten class and Grades I and II. Miss D. L. Doyle, who is a Scholarship Graduate of Chicago Teachers' College, is the teacher, and Miss Doris Ireton, B.A., a graduate of Brandon College, has been supplying for the last few months.

The class room work is inspected regularly by Inspector J. Boyd Morrison of the Department of Education for Manitoba, and his reports state very definitely that satisfactory progress is being made in every department of the class room work.

The Health of the Pupils

We are watching this phase of our school life very carefully. Our Matron, Mrs. Gertrude Mason, is equipped with that experience and those qualities of mind and heart which enable her to be a real mother to the pupils, and she is quick to observe anything physically wrong with any of them. The Boys' Matron, Miss M. Cranra, has had a partial hospital training, and renders the best of service in caring for any who are sick. A Doctor is called whenever necessary. In addition we now have the services of the Ninette Clinic. These doctors come from time to time and examine most thoroughly all new pupils and any others who may be suspected of developing serious trouble. The X-ray plates show that four out of five of all possible head symptoms are being trouble before coming to the School. This shows the urgent need of this watchful service.

A wholesome and balanced diet is being followed. The pupils are weighed regularly, and satisfactory gains in weight are recorded. A number of boys gained from twenty to thirty pounds each during the first three months of the school year, and taken altogether the Ninette Clinic found the pupils averaged five per cent overweight for girls and boys of their age and height.

The other departments of the School's life and training are being carried on satisfactorily. Miss R. Harland, the Girls' Matron, in a very kindly and tactful manner is carefully looking after the welfare of the girls. She is also stenographer and office assistant.
The Sewing Room

This department is under the efficient management of Miss M. McDonald, and under her training many of the girls are showing marked ability in mending, dressmaking and fancy needlework.

Kitchen and Dining Room

An experienced and capable dietitian in the person of Miss H. Reeder has charge of the kitchen and dining room, and the healthy appearance of the pupils proves her efficiency.

The Laundry

Our girls are being well-trained in all phases of laundry work by Miss L. Barager, who has charge of this department. She is painstaking and thorough-going in her work.

Farming

No matter what other education our boys receive it is our purpose that every one of them shall be given a good training in farming. The farm consists of 960 acres, and the Farm Manager and Instructor, Mr. W. E. Wood, is well qualified for his position.

Stock-Raising

Mr. C. H. Waldon is our careful and efficient Stockman, and is giving our boys a careful training in this connection. Our milch herd of dual-purpose pedigreed Shorthorns is pronounced by Hon. Robert Weir, B.A., Minister of Agriculture for the Dominion, one of the very best dual-purpose Shorthorn herds in the Prairie Provinces. Every animal is under Govt. inspection, and only healthy, good-producing cows are being kept in the herd.

Mechanical Work

Training in the care of machinery and implements and in mechanical work generally is by no means neglected, and this department is under the care of a capable mechanic in the person of Mr. H. Bicknell.

Sports

Football, softball, skating, hockey, etc., are thoroughly enjoyed by our pupils. Mr. Ernest McEwen, an outstanding athlete and a leader in boys' work, is coming on our staff next year and will direct the sports and athletic life of our School.

Singing and Music

A choral class of boys and girls is being voluntarily trained by Miss Jean Doyle to compete in the Musical Festival to be held in Brandon in May. Pupils chosen for this work are showing real promise.

Moral and Religious Life

We have no hesitation in stating that the moral and religious and general atmosphere of the School has greatly improved during the past year. More and more the pupils are taking an active part in our religious services and are showing a deeper interest in the worthwhile things of life.

Prospects for the Future

We now have 161 pupils in the School and a small waiting list. We expect, however, that ten or twelve pupils, at least, will graduate this year. We, therefore, wish to repeat our urgent appeal that those planning to send pupils will have the Application for Admission filled out by the Agent as early as possible and sent to Ottawa for approval. We can take a few new pupils in April and a number more after July 1st.

We would especially urge that prospective High School pupils have their Applications sent in with as little delay as possible.

Please write to us for any information you may desire, and thanking you again for your cooperation and help.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

BRANDON, MANITOBA
To Indian Agents, Missionaries, Teachers and Parents or Guardians of Indian Children:

Greetings:

As the third year in our new school building is closing we wish to say a hearty "Thank you" to all who have helped us in making this year the best we have had. We wish also, by a number of pictures and a short letter, to tell you something of our progress.

First let us record our deep sorrow at the passing since our last Annual Letter of Mr. Russell T. Ferrier, M.A., of the Department at Ottawa, and Inspector John R. Bunn, of Winnipeg, both of whom have been warm friends of our school. While we regret the retirement of Dr. Duncan Campbell as Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, we gladly acknowledge our loyalty to Inspector Dr. Harold W. McGill and have pleasure in presenting his picture in this folder. We also welcome, most happily, our friend of many years, Inspector A. G. Hamilton, who succeeds the late Mr. Bunn, as our Inspector in Manitoba.

The Pictures tell you as words cannot how your children look, and reveal something of their activities. We want you especially to become acquainted with each member of our staff and the position they occupy, for it is they who are influencing the lives and characters of your children while they are with us.

The Health and Happiness of our pupils is our first concern, for they cannot make progress as they should unless they are healthy. The general health of our school has been excellent this year. The Ninette Clinic helps us greatly. They did not find one case of active Tuberculosis on their last visit. This is very gratifying. Many things are contributing to secure these results. Common colds are being carefully watched. Each pupil is weighed regularly. Cod Liver Oil is given daily and medical and hospital treatment is given when necessary. Deep breathing, physical training and outdoor sports have also helped. That our pupils are happy is registered in their faces and also indicated in the general tone of the letters you receive from them.

Grades and Graduates. The success of our classroom work is well attested by the Inspector's reports and by the splendid results in last year's examinations. Our Normal student of last year is now our fully qualified teacher in the Normal Teacher's School. The three normal boys of last year are now teachers. This year seven boys attended the Technical School for Automotive Mechanics and we are glad to report that all have passed with good standing. Of the thirty students who wrote the Departmental Examinations last year four passed with Honours. Ewart Monias reaching 87.5%. Nineteen passed clear. Two had one subject only, and only two had more than one subject. These results are above the average in High School grades, and we expect equally as good standing this year. We have eleven pupils in what we call our Graduating Class, and all will leave behind them a good record.

Training Homemakers and Homemakers. It is our definite aim and purpose to train every boy that can go home and become a good farmer or go out into the world and make a good living and provide for a house, and to so train every girl that whether she becomes a teacher or a nurse or may be a business girl, she can be successful and happy in life. This year our girls are preparing some very fine pieces of needlework to be exhibited at the World's Fair in Regina. The boys also will show some artistic designs in fretwork.

Sports, Dramatics and Music. Under the guidance, training and coaching of our director of athletics the sport life of the school has been greatly developed. Our football team carried off the shield in the Second Division competition. The girls' basketball team, Bobcaygeon boys' basketball and skating, Hockey is also a favorite sport. On Victoria Day Percy Barrens easily won the three-mile race over all contestants. One June 3rd, the Brandon section of the Sunday School National Athletic Competition was held. Our boys entered the contest. One Texas group and one Trail Ranger group scored higher than any Turis or Trail Ranger group in Manitoba. Our National standards are not as available elsewhere as yet. In dramatics a number of our pupils have discovered powers that surprised themselves and others. Six plays were prepared and put on in the school during the year. One play by a group of boys was put on twice in the school, once in Brandon, and at two outside points. Fifty of our girls were formed into a Choral Class, and after careful and patient training sang at the Musical Festival in Brandon. Their work was highly commended by the adjudicator, Dr. Slater of England, who presented them with the shield.

Religious Activities. The spiritual side in the four-fold character is being well cared for in the very successful C.G.S. and Troopwork. Trail Rangers are held in the Sunday School. Members of the staff have given splendid leadership, and the pupils themselves have taken an active part in the services. Nineteen of the older boys and girls were prepared and taken into Church membership last Easter.

Next Year. With our excellent staff, fine equipment, and improved health and general spirit, we are looking forward with good prospect to the coming school year.

Those desiring to send us pupils should forward the Application for Admission at once as we will only have room for a limited number when the holidays are over. We especially desire that prospective High School students should get word to us at the earliest possible date.

Again thanking all who have helped us, and bespeaking your continued kindly co-operation,

I am, Yours sincerely,

Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man., June 7, 1933.

J. A. DOYLE.
Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6255, File 576-1, part 2)

VERY POOR COPY
Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I wish to thank you for your permission to use the picture about which I wrote you. It has come out very well. And I have returned the photograph to your brother's home.

I am enclosing herewith a copy of this year's circular letter. I find a letter like this to be the most effective method of maintaining an interest in the school among the Indian people whom we serve. The pictures no doubt make more impression than the letter itself. And they insure that the letter is preserved and shown to all their friends.

Again thanking you,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.
Indian School Shows Progress

J. A. Doyle Announces Growth of Scholarship and Industry in Industrial Institution at Brandon

Ending the third year in its course, Dr. J. A. Doyle, principal of the Indian residential school, Brandon, has issued the annual report showing progress made in all directions. The latest report enables students to form large groups of boys, Trail Rangers and Camp Girls in Training. These groups under the direction of leaders in the school.

Students who wrote the grade examinations during the past year achieved results above the average. In addition to regular scholastic instruction, both the boys and girls are trained to be self-supporting and homesteaders. The definite aim of the school is to train every boy so that he can become a good citizen on his father's land or go out into the world and earn a living. Every girl receives training which will fit her to take up a profession or become a successful homemaker.

The health of the pupils is a primary consideration. Each day is weighed regularly and foods are carefully selected. With the Ninette clinic last visited the school, not one case of active tuberculosis was found. The organized outdoor games and physical training are regarded as largely responsible for this.

The pupils are encouraged to take an active part in the organization of groups and in the church. Nineteen of the older boys and girls were prepared and assisted by church leaders last Easter. A large choir from the school competed in the musical festival at Brandon and carried off the shield.

Dr. Doyle was formerly mission secretary of the United Church in Canada. He has a well-equipped staff of teachers and workers, one of whom is a graduate of the school and the Brandon normal school.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6255, File 576-1, part 2)
Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., March 13, 1934.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Attention: Mr. J. D. Sutherland,

Knowing your very deep interest in the moral and religious life of the Indian pupils under your care, I am taking the liberty of dropping you this extra word.

I have been extremely disappointed in the past in our failure to secure a definite religious response which seemed to carry with it real conviction and a sense of a vital relationship and responsibility to God. Some members of the Oxford Group were in Brandon and in attending their meetings their methods and appeal seemed so sane and free from objectionable emotionalism that I felt a visit from them would be a good thing for our school. As it has turned out it would seem the time was ripe for just the type of appeal these people were able to make and the response on the part of the older pupils has altogether exceeded my expectations. As you may know, the Group leaders advocate a quiet time to be observed every morning. We have laid this before the pupils who have indicated their desire to live the better quality of life and are giving them the opportunity to come to the chapel before six o'clock in the morning at which time a chapter of the Bible or a portion of it is read by one of themselves and the rest of the time for at least fifteen minutes is spent silently. The number attending at this quiet has gradually increased and now between sixty and seventy are regularly in attendance. If this is maintained the results will be far-reaching. Already the spirit and atmosphere of the school has wonderfully improved.

I was also greatly encouraged that in the confessions made, and many of them at least were very thorough, very little seriously objectionable conduct was revealed. In all, while I think we are not over-optimistic, we are greatly encouraged.

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.
June 6th., 1934.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA. CANADA.

re: H. E. EBURNE.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
Ottawa, June 9, 1934.

Gentlemen:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to Mr. H. E. Eburne, formerly a member of the staff at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

From September first, 1925, to the end of June, 1929, Mr. Eburne taught in an Indian day school in Quebec but gave up duties on the latter date, and we have had no communication from him since that time.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Messrs. Clement & Clement,
Barristers,
Brandon, Man.
Dear Doctor Ferrier:

It was with deep regret that the members of the Schools Branch learned this morning of the death of your respected father.

Those who had the opportunity of being associated with him recognized his great devotion to duty, and it must be a considerable consolation to all the members of his family to know that the late Mr. Ferrier spent such a useful life, administering both to the spiritual and temporal welfare of the Indians in Canada. Please extend to your mother and accept on your own behalf our sincere sympathy.

Yours very truly,

Dr. Herman Ferrier,
1425 McGregor Avenue,
Fort William,
Ontario.

Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., August 10, 1934.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

After giving the matter serious consideration I am writing to see if it would be possible to have our pupilage in this school increased by five, i.e., one hundred and seventy instead of one hundred and sixty-five as at present. There are three main reasons for making this request:

First. We find that we can handle the extra five in dormitory, dining-room and classrooms without the slightest difficulty or inconvenience.

Second. We are having requests from agents and parents sufficient to indicate that this number of pupils and more will be available.

Third. This would help our financial condition very materially. The reduction of 15¢ in the per capita grant we felt seriously. The extra expenses we are at for minor repairs have added many hundreds of dollars to our expenditure but the most serious situation is from another partial crop failure. The high winds and drought in the spring with no rain during July has made it so that more than half our crop cannot be cut and bound with the binder. That which can be handled with the binder is much less than half an average crop. We will, therefore, have to buy a large quantity of feed in order to maintain our livestock.

The granting of this request would help us greatly in maintaining a living wage for our staff and a good standard of food and clothing for our pupils. Trusting that this may meet with your approval,

Yours respectfully,

JAD/W

October 19th 1934.

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir:

One James Morrison, formerly an employee of the Public Service of Saskatchewan, was superannuated some time ago and a notice has been received from a firm of lawyers in Scotland, where he was residing, of his death. The firm of lawyers who are handling his estate have requested the assistance of the Board in locating Mr. Morrison's relatives. The only clue in possession of the Board refers to a Miss M.G. Ross who, it is understood, was at one time a school teacher under the Department of Indian Affairs in or near Brandon, Man. The Board will deem it a favour if you will search your records and advise me whether this person is still in the employ of the Department of Indian Affairs. If so, will you kindly let me know where I could communicate with her?

Yours truly,

William R. Turner
Secretary.
Ottawa, October 25, 1934.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, requesting information as to the present address of Miss R.G. Ross, who, you understand, was at one time a teacher in an Indian school in or near Brandon, Man.

In reply I have to say that we have made a search of our records and can find no trace of this lady. She may have been engaged by the church authorities under whose auspices the Indian Residential School at Brandon is conducted or the Residential School at Birtle, Man. The teachers at these schools are engaged by the church authorities. I would suggest that you communicate with Rev. J.A. Doyle, D.D., Principal, Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.; and Rev. E.H. Leckhart, Principal, Indian Residential School, Birtle, Man. I regret being unable to supply the information you require regarding Miss Ross.

Your obedient servant,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

William P. Turner, Esq.,
Public Service Superannuation Board,
Legislative Buildings,
Regina, Sask.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Nov. 19, 1934.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have recently received requests from parents enquiring as to an approximate date on which we could take additional pupils in the school here. In this connection I note that in your letter of August 16th, No. 133-0-1, you state that the matter of increasing our pupilage by five will receive consideration when the estimates for the academic year, 1935-36, are made. I do not know just when these matters are considered but I would appreciate it very much if I could have the information when it is conveniently available and can, therefore, make my arrangements accordingly.

We certainly would appreciate it very much if this increase in pupilage is made possible.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

JAD/w
Ottawa, November 23, 1934.

Reverend Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant, with reference to the proposed increase in the pupilage of the Branden Indian Residential School.

Your previous request for an increase of five (5) pupils has been considered when preparing our estimates for the fiscal year 1935-36; but we will not know until after the close of Parliament whether or not funds have been provided for the purpose. If the funds are provided, the per capita grant for the increased number would be available from April 1st, 1936. However, you should not accept an increased number for whom you expect grant without again applying to the Department and receiving definite word that the increase has been allowed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

Following the suggestion in the last paragraph of your letter of Nov. 23, 1934, No. 132-0-1, I am writing again re the possibility of an increase of five in the pupilage in this school. As I have stated in previous correspondence, we can handle this extra number without the least inconvenience in any part of our equipment and the increased revenue would assist us very materially in the financial situation, which, at times, has been exceedingly difficult.

Ottawa, March 29, 1935.

Rev. Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 25th instant, I beg to say that in our Appropriation for the fiscal year 1935-36 provision has been made for a pupilage of 170 at the Brandon Indian Residential School. Per capita grant, therefore, will be paid for this number from April 1st, 1935.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.
To Indian Agents, Missionaries, Teachers and Parents or Guardians of Indian Children

GREETINGS:

Another busy and successful year in our school life is drawing to a close. Once again with a few paragraphs and pictures we wish to tell you about your children, who are under our care. We feel that our work is more sincere than to those who have given us much less help and co-operation.

We were honored recently with a visit from Dr. Harold W. McGill, of Ottawa, Deputy Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs, Inspector A. G. Hamilton, of Winnipeg, a warm friend of our school and pupils, has visited us a number of times and it was most stimulating.

We wish to record our regrets that Rev. Dr. Barner is withdrawing from the Superintendency of Indian work and will miss his visits. His stimulating visits. We will welcome Rev. Dr. Corning, the Missionary-Superintendent of the United Church for the Manitoba Conference, and Dr. Barner's successor, Rev. K. N. Ross, who is visiting the Indian Residential Schools in Toronto, and who has special oversight of all our Indian work, is always a welcome and helpful visitor in our school.

We are glad to report that these visits have been very helpful.

Some New Features. A Home Nursing Class, under the St. John's Ambulance, has been conducted this year. Thirteen of our older girls have been trained under the direction of Miss M. Matchett, R.N. Drs. Rawson and Sharp, of Brandon, conducted the examinations. All of the girls passed successfully except one. The average for the whole class was 76%.

We expect to continue this work so that each girl before graduation will have this training.

A Short Course in Agriculture has been conducted at the Provincial Farm, which is just across the road from our school. Two of our boys took the course this year and we expect to have a number next year.

Class Room Work. We believe that the average of our class room work has been the best we have yet had. One pupil will, we expect, enter Grade XI next fall. We have three pupils writing Grade X this fall and two others are writing Grade XI this month. Three boys have graduated from the Technical School in Brandon with good standing and one of them received a scholarship to the University of Manitoba. One of the Technical School graduates has taken Grade X work in addition to this course, and we expect he will pass. Prospects look very promising for the coming year.

Health. With the aid of the Ninette Clinic, the careful attention of our school doctors, the services of a trained nurse on the staff and the constant watching the weights and diet of the pupils, we have achieved a high standard of general health in the school.

Athletic. We give attention to athletics that we may develop sound bodies, good health and the spirit of good sportsmanship.

Last year our boys played football in the Brandon League and was successful in winning the Charity Cup. In the North Brandon League our girls played softball, and when the season was over they were placed second. Our teams finished third in the Brandon League. Our teams, Junior Eagles, Senior Eagles and Buffaloes, made the three highest scores in the province, and one of our boys won the Junior Eagles' award for the best player.

The Spirit of the School is continually on the upgrade. The Boys' and Girls' Councils have greatly helped by promoting good feeling and better understanding. The older pupils have been taking charge of the Sunday evening service very efficiently and are taking more responsibility.

During the past year we have not had room for all the pupils for whom application has been made. This year the Department has increased its capacity five, and we expect that twenty-five of our senior pupils will graduate. We, therefore, will have room for the largest number of new pupils of any year since the opening of the school.

It is important that all pupils commence with the opening of classes after the holidays. We will, therefore, appreciate very much the cooperation of Agents, Missionaries and parents in arranging for new pupils to come with the others when they return from holidays.

I am,

Yours sincerely,

I. A. DOYLE.

Brandon, Man., June 4, 1955.

Dear Dr. McGill:

The enclosed circular letter speaks for itself. We took the liberty of placing your picture on it again this year.

I find that this letter serves an exceedingly good purpose in helping us keep in better touch with the reserves from which we have pupils. It also serves in enabling us to say a kindly word of thanks to those who are constantly giving us help.

Dear Sir:

Since I have had charge of this school our gasoline has been supplied to us by the Imperial Oil Company and we have been exempt from the Provincial tax. They now request that a certificate number be supplied or some statement indicating that this school is carried on as an institution of the Dominion Government. We will be glad if you will supply us with the necessary number or statement.

Thanking you,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle,

Principal.
Ottawa, November 18, 1935.

Reverend Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, in connection with the Provincial Gasoline Tax.

Remission of gasoline tax is allowed on Government owned cars but this provision does not apply on cars used for Government business but not owned by the Government. The Department has never purchased cars for Indian residential schools and, consequently, we have never considered such cars our property. Under these circumstances, the Department has not felt prepared to sign the declaration that cars operated by Principals of residential schools are Government owned and are, therefore, entitled to remission of the gasoline tax.

I understand, however, that you are entitled to remission of the tax on gasoline used for tractors, engines, etc. Provision for remission of the tax in this regard can be made by yourself with the provincial authorities.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Brandon School for the Quarter ended September 1941.

Principal P.T. Chapin

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, shall payments be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively; and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paling it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLICQUES CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Brandon School for the Quarter ended March 1943.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter”.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

VERY POOR COPY
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pegging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Brandon Indian Residential School for the Quarter ended December 31, 1945.

Principal

Dated January 5th, 1945

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.
