NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Brandon Indian Residential School for the Quarter ended March 31, 1945.

Principal: Rev. O.B. Strapp

Dated: April 18, 1945

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

[Signature]

Dated at Brandon, Manitoba, this April 18, 1945.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

**AMOUNT of per capita grant due for Quarter:** $899
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pagging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

VERY POOR COPY
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Indian Residential School for the Quarter ended March 31, 1947.

Principal

Dated April 8th, 1947

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Dated at Brandon this eighth of April, 1947.

NOTE

Principals will please be guided by the instructions printed on the last page.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

VERY POOR COPY
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Brandon Residential School for the Quarter ended September 30th 1947.

Principal: R.O. Straff

Dated: October 3rd 1947

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent: R.O. Straff

Dated at: Brandon

this October 3rd 1947.

NOTE

Principals will please be guided by the instructions printed on the last page.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payments be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Principal

Dated April 12th 1948

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Principal

Dated at Brandon Man.

this April 12th 1948.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter”.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLICQUES CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Brandon Residential School for the Quarter ended September 30, 1949.

Principal: Rev. O.B. Stumpf

Dated: October 14, 1949

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Dated at: Brandon, Man.

NOTE

Principals will please be guided by the instructions printed on the last page.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Brandon Residential School for the Quarter ended December 31, 1949.

Principal Rev. O.B. Strapp

Dated January 9, 1950

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Dated at Brandon Man this January 9, 1950.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

VERY POOR COPY
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I hereby certify that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Brandon Residential School for the Quarter ended June 30, 1950.

Principal Rev. O.B. Straff

Dated June 30, 1950

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Rev. O.B. Straff

Indian Agent

Dated at Brandon this June 30, 1950

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Brandon Residential School for the Quarter ended September 30, 1950.

Principal Rev. O.B. Stepp

Date October 8th, 1950

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Dated at Brandon, Man. this October 6th, 1950.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Brandon Residential School for the Quarter ended June 30, 1952.

Principal: [Signature]

Dated: July 6, 1952.

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

[Signature]

Indian Agent

Dated at: [Stamp]

Principals will please be guided by the instructions printed on the last page.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals; placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Indian Residential School Quarterly Return

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Brandon Residential School for the Quarter ended December 31, 1952.

Principal

Dated January 8, 1953.

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent

Dated at

Principals will please be guided by the instructions printed on the last page.

January 12, 1940.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Gentlemen:

The inclosed statement of account covers an order for supplies for which we rendered invoices in quadruplicate to the:

Brandon Indian Residential School,

and we are advised by Dr. Doyle that these were certified and passed along to the Department for payment.

If it is in order, we would appreciate very much receiving payment by the end of this month if it could be arranged, as January 31st is the end of our financial year.

Your usual kind attention will be greatly appreciated, and for which we thank you kindly in advance.

Yours truly,

CHRISTIE SCHOOL SUPPLY, LTD.

Managing Director.
Ottawa,
January 19, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Re: Requisitions 21249 & 21275

To each of the above requisitions was attached an account in favour of the Christie School Supply Company. I should appreciate your advising if these accounts have been paid.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

The King's Printer,
Ottawa, Ont.
Mr. P. Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Replying to yours of January 19, File No. 133-0-4 re accounts of the Christie School Supply Company, I wish to advise you that same are in line for payment and cheque will be forwarded shortly.

Yours truly,

J. W. Driscoll
SUPERINTENDENT OF STATIONERY
Indian Residential School

J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., March 5, 1940

The Secretary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I beg to make requisition for the following athletic supplies for our school here:

- 6 senior footballs, with bladders
- 3 extra bladders
- 2 volley balls, with bladders
- 2 basketballs, with bladders
- 1 doz. playground balls (softballs)
- 6 playground ball bats (softball)
- 2 senior rugby balls, with bladders

Thanking you, I am

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle
PRINCIPAL.
Ottawa, March 13th, 1940.

Dear Sirs:

Please deliver to Room 503, Booth Building, for the Brandon Indian Residential School, the following:

- 6 footballs, complete,
- 3 extra bladders,
- 2 volley balls, complete.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

The Plaunt Hardware Co.,
187 Sparks St.,
Ottawa, Ont.

|--------------|----------|-------|
| football complete | 6        | $27.00 |
| extra bladders | 3        | $1.50 |
| volley balls complete | 2        | $10.00 |

Total: $38.50

Brandon, Man., November 13, 1940.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Canada.

Sir:

We would like very much to have a good picture of our King and the Queen also if possible; or one of the King and his family.

We have two very good pictures of the late King George and Queen Mary, but none of our present King.

If the Dept. sees fit to send us a picture either framed or without a frame, we would appreciate it very much.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

THE BRITISH EDUCATIONAL SOCIETY

1105 Federal Building
Toronto, 2

May 23, 1941.

Commissioner of Indian Affairs,
Dominion Government,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

One of our representatives interviewed Dr. J. A. Doyle of the Brandon Industrial School, Brandon, Manitoba, in connection with the WAVERLEY PICTORIAL DICTIONARY published by The Waverley Book Company of London, England. We understand that Dr. Doyle has made a request for a set of this dictionary work for the school library. Dr. Doyle referred our representative to Inspector A. J. Hamilton of Winnipeg. The latter looked over the work with Mr. Chapin, and both approved very highly of it.

The WAVERLEY PICTORIAL DICTIONARY is a publication in eight volumes, and has been placed in a very, very large number of schools and libraries throughout Canada. The price of this work is $49.50.

May we have your instructions to send a set of this work to the Industrial School at Brandon, Manitoba.

Thanking you, we remain

Yours very truly,

THE BRITISH EDUCATIONAL SOCIETY,

A.W.Meredith: S

Manager.

Universal History of the World - Lands and Peoples - The Pictorial Dictionary
Ottawa,
June 4, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to supplying the Waverley Pictorial Dictionary to the Brandon Indian Residential School. Due to conditions at present confronting us our appropriation has been reduced. Consequently it is not our intention, either at the present time or at any time in the immediate future, to purchase a dictionary of the type mentioned in your letter.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hosy,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. A.W. Meredith,
Manager,
The British Educational Society,
1105 Federal Building,
Toronto 2, Ont.

Brandon, Man., November 13, 1941.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing Requisition for School supplies.
The first two of these were on our Spring
Requisition of May 14th, but to date have not
come to hand and we are very badly in need of
the same. Twelve copies of the History were
requisitioned for, but only three were sent,
hence I am asking for the other nine herewith.
Am also asking for two more tins of Hectograph
Composition as we find the four received is
not going to be sufficient for the year.
We hope these items can be forwarded as soon
as possible.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

PUBLIC ARCHIVES CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
Ottawa, November 18th, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Re Requisition No. 22492.

We are in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School in which he states that only three of the 12 copies of Pages from Canada's Story ordered on the above requisition were received by him. If the remaining nine copies have not already been forwarded, I should be glad if you would ship them at the earliest possible date.

Please let me know what action you take in this matter.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. J. W. Driscoll,
Supt. of Stationery,
Dept. Public Printing & Stationery,
Ottawa, Ont.
OTTAWA, November 26, 1941.

Ref: "Stationery"

Mr. P. Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of November 18, File 135-0-4 re 9 copies of Pages from Canada's Story, requisition No. 22492, I wish to advise you that same are at present out of stock.

As soon as a new shipment is received, same will be forwarded to your official.

Yours truly,

J. W. Driscoll
SUPERINTENDENT OF STATIONERY
Ottawa, November 29th, 1943.

Rev. Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant, I would advise you that "Pages from Canada's Story" is at present out of stock. As soon as a new shipment is received, the nine copies which are outstanding on your order will be forwarded.

The other articles on your requisition have been ordered and should reach you in the near future.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. R. T. Chapin,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

VERY POOR COPY
Ottawa,
March 12, 1942.

Reverend Sir:

On your requisition of January 15 it is noted that you request a very large number of high school books. As you are aware, the Department would much prefer vocational courses at our residential schools to higher academic courses. Please let me know the names and register numbers of the pupils who you consider will be ready for high school work during the academic year 1942-43. As you are aware, funds at our disposal at the present time will not permit our giving favourable consideration to making grants for advanced educational work.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. R.T. Chapin,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

VERY POOR COPY
Ottawa, June 4th, 1942.

Rev. Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the first instant, with reference to the non-receipt of 18 Bibles for presentation purposes to graduates of the Brandon Indian Residential School.

On receipt of your letter I got in touch with the Government Stationery Office and was informed that 18 Bibles were forwarded on the 2nd instant.

Owing to the necessity for strict economy, we are not supplying the special edition of the Bible for presentation purposes. We are, however, supplying the same type of Bible as we usually furnish for classroom use at the residential schools. It is hoped that these will be satisfactory.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. R. T. Chapin, B.A.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

Ottawa, June 23rd, 1942.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, in which you state that three typewriter ribbons and one stamp pad were not included with a shipment of classroom supplies which you recently received.

Upon receipt of your letter, I got in touch with the Government Stationery Office and I am today in receipt of their reply which reads, in part, as follows:

"I have taken this matter up with my packers and they are sure that the ribbons and stamp pad were included in the shipment sent to your official on June 5th in two cases and 4 cartons.

I would ask you to kindly recheck and let me know if they have been located."

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Mr. Phelan;

Just recently, in connection with the Manitoba Physical Fitness Campaign, we have organized two groups with the pupils of this school. The Brandon Y.M.C.A. Athletic Staff is supplying the leaders for the groups and they are coming out to the school twice weekly.

Our present problem is equipment. Would it be possible for you to supply the following; 4 Basket Balls; 2 Indoor Play Balls; 4 Indoor Base Balls and Bats. 2 Gymnasium Mats.

I had hoped that it might have been possible to locate some of this equipment locally from some of the training centres that have closed up but to date have not been able to locate any that is not in use.

There is a quantity of 2" mesh heavy screen here which could be used to make screens to protect the windows in the assembly hall if we could receive authority to make an expenditure not exceeding $25.00 for ½" round iron with which to make the frames.

I have been in contact with Mr. Hart Deveney, Provincial Director for Manitoba and it is possible that he may call to see you on one of his trips to Ottawa.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa, 5th December, 1945.

Dear Mr. Strapp:

With reference to your letter of the 22nd ultimo, the Department approves an expenditure of $25.00 in order to place screens over all the windows in the room which is to be used for athletic activities.

Inflated balls are extremely hard to obtain, however, we will place an order and if we are able to purchase them they will be forwarded to you.

Is it not possible to purchase the Gymnasium Mats locally? Please make further enquiries as to their cost.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend O.B. Strapp,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Manitoba.

DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES
INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH

THE UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA
REV. O. B. STRAPP, PRINCIPAL

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

March 12, 1946.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

With reference to our requisition for school supplies, we would be glad if we could have a supply of "Dominion of Canada, Maple Leaf, C, Note Books come forward as soon as possible. We have not any on hand and it is not possible to use the softer faced scribblers for pen and ink work in the higher grades. We have had considerable trouble with the pen nibs supplied corroding at the points and causing spattering. We would be glad if a different nib could be supplied for these higher grades, and would suggest Falcon #048.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

- Prose of Our Day. 3 "
- Macbeth. 5 "
- The Admirable Crichton. 4 "
- Selections of English Poetry. 3 "
- L'Amour Francais. 5 "

- New Practical Physics. 1 "
- High School Chemistry. 3 "

Yours truly,

Principal.

Ottawa, September 12th, 1947.

Rev. Sir:

With reference to your requisition dated June 25th, please let me know the number of the 60 ink wells and the type of desk for which they are required. This information is required before we can place an order for them.

Please also forward sample copies of the note book refills and the squared paper required.

Philip Phelan

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. O. B. Strapp,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.
Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Deptmt. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

September 15, 1947.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

Herewith please find samples of the refills and squared paper required.

The ink wells are like small bottles with a cap and are 1.7/8 inches outside diameter. They can be procured from Christie School Supply here in Brandon at $1.30 per dozen.

In connection with the courses prescribed this year for grades VII and VIII we will require 18 copies "The Builders of the Old World" by Hartman and Ball. Also 18 copies of "The Story of the English Speaking Nations" which I am informed may not be released from the publishers until late in October.

For the grade IX class we require 12 copies "The Story of the Nations."

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Principal.

I have just received a letter from Mr. J. A. McNeill, Senior Teacher at the Brandon Indian Residential School. He writes in part as follows:

"I would be pleased if you would contact the right parties, in order that we might obtain, as soon as possible, the school supplies which we ordered last spring, particularly - History Grade IX and VII, Ink Scribblers, Note book covers and Refills.

Our class room work is just about at a stand-still, as a result of not receiving these in time for school opening. I have spoken to Mr. Strapp several times about them but get no results. Last week he bought a new Monarch car and left for a month's visit to Ontario so that I do not know what we are to do."

Will the Department please arrange to have the supplies forwarded at once.

Yours truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.
Mr. P. Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Department of Mines and Resources,
O T T A W A.

Ottawa, October 29th, 1947.

Dear Mr. Strapp:

We have been advised by the Stationery Office that the following books which you have requisitioned are not available until some time in December:

18 copies Builders of the Old World,
12 " Story of the Nations.

We are cancelling 15 copies "The Story of the English Speaking Nations".

We are also cancelling 24 copies of "The Story of Canada" as this book is out of print and will not be re-issued.

In connection with the delay in receiving some of the newly authorized text books, I would refer you to the message entitled "Delayed Text Books" on the front page of the Order Form of the Manitoba Text Book Bureau.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard D. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

February 7, 1948.

Rev. Sir:

Your requisition for school material dated December 31, 1947, has been received and is being checked in this office before it is forwarded to the Department of Public Printing and Stationery, where it is filled.

It is noted that you have requested:

- Builders of the Old World (Grade 7) - 15 copies,
- Story of the English Speaking Nations (Grade 5) - 12 copies,
- Story of Nations (Man. Ed. - Grade 9) - 6 copies.

In connection with your requisition of last year, the under-mentioned items were ordered:

- Builders of the Old World - 15 copies,
- The Story of Nations - 12 copies.

These books were not available at the time of ordering, but the Government Stationery Office promised to supply them at the earliest opportunity. Please let me know if you have received them so as to avoid duplication of your order.

The official list of Manitoba texts for 1947-48 does not include The Story of the English Speaking Nations. It shows Builders of the Old World authorized for Grades 7-8, and the Story of Canada authorized, in addition, for Grade 5. Please advise further your minimum requirements for these two texts.

Yours truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. O. B. Strapp,
Brandon Indian Res. School,
Brandon, Man.
Mr. B.F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

February 12, 1948.

Dear Sir;

We have received 12 copies of Story of the Nations.

Gr.VII. Builders of the Old World.
Gr.VIII. Story of the English Speaking Nations.

These books are listed in; "Junior High Grades"
Introduction to Social Studies Guidance. Province of Manitoba, 1947, page 40.

Inquiries have lead us to believe that these books will not be available until September 1948. We repeated the requisition as we were not aware that the previous list would be carried over to this year.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, August 18, 1948.

Dear Sir:

I have your requisition of June 25th, which just came to my attention a few days ago.

Please be advised that we do not supply Workbooks for Grades 5 and 6 Readers. In reference to the "Workbooks for Arithmetic" by Reid; "World Geography" and "Everyday Problems in Science", it is not clear to me as to what you actually require as none of these are listed on our standard school supplies list nor are they listed on the authorized list of Manitoba School texts.

Trusting to hear from you in this respect in order that the books required can be ordered.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing a list of supplies which are urgently needed.

Some of these books were ordered in Dec. '47, and again in June '48. Also in a special order after the beginning of the fall term. Up to date we have not received them.

We have 59 pupils at the present time in Grs I & II, so would appreciate it very much if this order could be filled, that we might begin the New Year to better advantage.

Thanking You Kindly

Respectfully Yours

(Mrs) M. E. McNeill
Indian Affairs.

Cal. B.F. Neary
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Colonel Neary,

I have discovered that I could use to very good advantage here, the duplicator which I was awarded for writing an article last year for the Bulletin when I was at Birtle and for which I have not hitherto found a justifiable use.

Respectfully yours,

(Mrs.) Barbara L. Cleas.

DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES
INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH

Mr. B.F. Neary,
Supt. Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir;

We require a number of textbooks for our Collegiate pupils. It is not possible to requisition for these books earlier as quantities and in some cases titles are not known until the pupils register.

May we have permission to make local purchase from Willson Stationery Ltd.?

Marita Sinclair and Miriam Stevenson have returned to school and if permitted to continue will have to repeat the academic subjects of grade X.

Francis Williams, Cora Walker and Patsy McKay have been accepted for registration by the Collegiate with their Provisional Grade IX for grade X.

In the last paragraph of my letter of July 2nd I asked for instructions re these 'Provisional' pupils etc. As I have not received a reply to date I have accepted them on trial.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Send the following message, subject to the terms on back hereof, which are hereby agreed to

Ottawa, September 13, 1949.

Rev. O.B. Strapp,
Principal,
Brandon, Man.

Provided sending fourteen grade nine pupils to Brandon High School eliminates grade nine class from your school. Permission to do so is granted—stop—for conditional or provisional students who have returned to school before this telegram is received we will accept whatever recommendation Brandon High School makes for their academic activities until Christmas when advisability of continuing will be reviewed—stop—purchase text books locally to best advantage.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6256, File 576-4, part 1)
September 13, 1949.

Rev. O.B. Strapp,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Manitoba.

High School Pupils

Dear Mr. Strapp:

A copy of our telegram of September 13 is enclosed. As you are aware, it has been our practice to provide textbooks and the usual school necessaries for High School pupils who have not in the past been very numerous at any one point. Now, however, the number of these pupils is sharply increased, and as your school has one of the largest concentrations of such pupils I shall welcome your cooperation in effecting any reasonable economies possible.

Firstly, I suggest, it must be impressed upon the pupils that the books, etc., are not their personal property but are merely on loan to them and are not to be damaged or defaced in the manner common to too many pupils. Indeed the books can well be regarded as acquisitions to your school library, be numbered and marked appropriately, and be charged out to the individual for as long as he needs them. The related library procedures could be appropriately performed by one of the senior students under direction.

The concessions to your conditional or provisional students represent a relaxation of the Department's previous ruling in regard to students whose year's work has not been completely successful. This relaxation, however, extends only to those pupils whose enthusiasm for school work is great enough to have prompted them to return to residence before the receipt of our telegram today.

.....2
expect that you will consult with the High School Principal and determine now on the basis of their past performance whether they should repeat their grade and course or whether they should attempt the next grade carrying conditions. In either case if at Christmas the results achieved by them are not satisfactory, any assistance to them will terminate and they will have to go home.

Your mention of the High School's readiness to accept fourteen grade nine pupils caused me to wonder whether there are more than this number and whether a few would be left over to continue their instruction in your school. You are aware of our wish to eliminate the instruction of pupils above grade eight entirely. We are advised that the transition to Provincial schools is more likely to be successful when carried out in a grade lower than grade ten. The casualties among your grade ten pupils give some support to this view. Hereafter exploration and appraisal of the abilities and interests of these older children will take place in grade nine or below and their retention in school will be based on something more than hope.

You are aware, of course, that in all this we are attempting to carry out recommendations of the Parliamentary Committee and while it will probably add to the load on you we are confident that you will give the experiment a fair trial.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant submitting plans of the proposed Methodist Sunday School at Brandon; and in reply I beg to state that the plans have been examined and it is thought they will do very well. The building will accommodate 100 children; but as the plans are stated to have been based upon...
upon those prepared by the Dept of Public Works for the St Paul's Indl School and so account as of the heating, water supply & fire escape referred to by you, which will be under the supervision of an Officer of the Public Works Dept during construction, it has been thought advisable to submit the plans & the partial specifications given by you to that Dept for examination.

This has accordingly been done & that with the request that expedition be used in the examination & that this Dept be advised of the result as soon as possible.

Yours,

The New grant for Construction of the Brandon School is approved in the Estimates for 1891-2. The Estimates for 1892-3 contain an item of $2000 for Remuneration. This item was increased to $4000 to cover the increase in the total Estimates of $3000. I do not think any of these proposed reductions can stand. It would be better to provide for some other way with less injury to the Educational system than removing the per capita grant. We have thought $2800 to be spent between date and June 93. The other $1000 can easily be provided from some other source before it will be required.

MEMORANDUM FOR THE MINISTER.

BRANDON INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL.

An item has just been sent to the Finance Department for insertion in the Supplementary Estimates for 1892-93 to re-vote the amount provided in the Estimates of 1891-92 to build the Indian Industrial School at Brandon, Manitoba, $20,000.00.

The Public Works Department has informed this Department that $20,000.00 will be required for the building. The lowest tender received on the Plans and Specifications was $20,000.00, and to this amount the Public Works Department adds $3000.00 for extras and contingencies, making the total amount to be provided $23,000.00. There is an evident difficulty in this matter; either the Plans and Specifications must be revised to conform to the Estimates, or else the expenditure of a larger sum than that originally provided must be authorized. If the former course were adopted the proposed award of the contract would have to be deferred, new plans and specifications drawn, and the tenders again advertised; if the latter, the amount required would be $20,000.00, which would have to be provided during the year 1892-3. These plans and specifications were drawn upon the same scale as those of the St. Paul's Industrial School. The contract for this School was awarded at $18,955.00, with extras and
and additional works, $2,593.50, the total amount paid to the contractors was $21,948.50. When the original Estimate was made for the Methodist Industrial School, which has been located at Brandon, it was understood that the building would be erected upon the St. Peter's Reserve. The location was afterwards changed to Southern Manitoba, and from that to Brandon, where it was finally fixed. There is no doubt that the building could have been erected upon the St. Peter's Reserve, as originally intended, for the same amount, or very nearly so, as the Institution at St. Paul's, and in inserting an amount in the Estimates for the new building the expenditure at St. Paul's was taken as a guide. The present location of the school at Brandon has undoubtedly materially increased the cost of the building, and, as I have shown above, the only way now out of the difficulty is either to reduce the plans or to consent to the provision of a sufficient sum of money to carry them out on the present scale.

June 8th, 1892.

Dear Mr. Secretary,

There seems to be some unaccountable delay on the part of the Public Works Department in proceeding with the building of the Brandon Industrial School. I venture to suggest for your consideration whether or not under the circumstances you would authorize me to prepare a memorandum to Council asking for authority to have the building erected under the supervision of the
Department of Indian Affairs.

The plan and specifications are ready, the money for the building has been voted, but I fear that if we go on in this way the current fiscal year will end before any action has been taken in the matter. The Public Works has been written to several times about the matter, and on the 9th September ultimo they were written to and urged to give the Department information as to when the building would be commenced. Sir,

With further reference to your letter of 19th ult., referring to the necessity for preparation of reduced plans, specifications and estimates which will come within the sum of $20,000.00, voted by Parliament for the erection of an Industrial School at Brandon, I have the honor to return herewith the tracing of the plan, submitted by the Rev. Dr. Sutherland for an Indian Mission School at Chilliwack, B. C.

The adoption of this plan for the Brandon School, I am unable to recommend, for the following among other reasons.--

The building is intended to be constructed of wood, and would be too cold to resist the severity of the winter weather in this country, and even could that objection be overcome by the employment of different material, where are others such as the location in the basement of lavatories and bath-rooms, the inability to place in the basement the necessary closets, the cramped character of the rooms, the comparatively limited amount of accommodation generally, and the want of a proper system of ventilation, so peculiarly necessary to the health of Indian children, in climate such as this.

To the Deputy of the

Supt. Genl. of Indian Affairs,

OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6256, File 576-5, part 1)
am however returning by parcel post, the plans and specifications transmitted by the Department, and at the same time fresh plans shewing the alterations which are suggested with a view to reducing the cost within the required limit.

The alteration in the specifications necessary to meet the changes in the plans I am not of course in a position to make, but beg to give the following additional information respecting the proposed changes.

It is suggested that the building be constructed of wood with brick veneer instead of walls of brick.

I am advised that the walls of the building as originally proposed are unnecessarily heavy.

It is proposed to confine the application of the Smead & Dowd system of heating and ventilation to the main building where it is considered essential, for the proper ventilation of the dormitories, and to enable closets to be placed in the basement, which is considered indispensable.

The wing not having dormitories nor closets, can, it is thought, be sufficiently well heated by an ordinary furnace, and so permitting saving in that direction to be effected.

It is thought that by the adoption of the changes referred to, the whole cost of the building will not exceed eighteen thousand dollars, thus leaving a sum of two thousand dollars available for the heating.

Alterations made as will be observed, include the provision of tanks, which are essential in view of the possibility of fire occurring, and where placed,

I am
am assured by Clerk of Public Works and other competent authority, there exists no danger of their freezing.

It may be pointed out incidentally that the arrangement of the original plan of the basement has been changed to get fuller advantage of the accommodation, and afford room for the children to play in stormy weather. Upon fuller consideration of the arrangement of the attic floor as I have had it shown in the new plan, I think a further slight alteration might be made with advantage.

The bed-room next to the bath-room might be enlarged by pulling down the partition between it and the bath-room and including the space occupied by the latter.

In that case the door on a line with that of the adjacent bed-room and entering upon the corridor might be closed up, entrance being by the door now shown as for bath-room.

Space for the bath-room might then be taken on the other side of the corridor from between the nurse's room and the bed-room, and the window of the bed-room could be moved more into the corner, and thus making the rooms a trifle smaller.

In conclusion I beg to point out the strong probability that if plans were on view at Brandon as well as at Winnipeg, the result would be the receipt of reduced tenders for the building.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Commissioner.

OTTAWA, 12th January 1893

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th Inst. and in reply to inform you that you are not quite correct in your statement of the amount of the appropriation for the Brandon Industrial School in 1891. The amount voted was $20,000. Tenders for the erection of the School were invited; the lowest received was for $27,000 which submitted to the Treasury Board, $8 was returned, being in excess of the amount voted, with instructions to have new plans for a less expensive building prepared. The $20,000 above referred to will be available to the 30th June next; new plans on a smaller scale have been prepared and accepted; invitations to tender are now being printed, and will be distributed as soon as finished. And with respect to the title which vests the land upon which the School is to be erected in the Crown, the papers conveying the title have been sent to the Department of Justice, and have, it is believed been forwarded by that Department to its Agents in Winnipeg, in order

Rev A. Sutherland,
Genl. Secretary
Methodist Mission Rooms
Toronto, Ont.

MEMORANDUM FOR THE DEPUTY.

The Rev. Dr. Sutherland is not quite correct in his statement of the amount of the appropriation for the Brandon Indian Industrial School in 1891. The amount voted was $20,000. Tenders for the erection of the school were invited; the lowest received was for $27,000 when submitted to the Treasury Board it was returned, being in excess of the amount voted, with instructions to have new plans for a less expensive building prepared. The $20,000 above referred to will be available to the 30th of June next; new plans on a smaller scale have been prepared and accepted; invitations to tender are now being printed, and will be distributed as soon as finished; and with respect to the title which vests the land upon which the school is to be erected, in the Crown, the papers conveying the title have been sent to the Department of Justice, and have, it is believed, been forwarded by that Department to its Agents in Winnipeg, in order that some missing documents may be procured, and a certificate of title under the Torrens system obtained.

January 10th, 1893.
Sir,

After lengthened correspondence an agreement was reached with the Indian Department for the erection by the Government of an Indian Institute at Brandon to be under the control of officers nominated by the Methodist Church. A definite selection of a site was made in June 1891, a sum of money of some £26,000 or £27,000 was voted by Parliament towards the necessary buildings. I am given to understand that tenders were received in April 1892 but were rejected by the Department, it is said, because they were too high. There has been some correspondence since regarding this matter but I am not aware that any further steps have been taken to secure the necessary...
necessary building. Quite a number of years have elapsed since negotiations with reference to this Institute began - the very long delay has been a serious inconvenience to us as well as a great loss to the children of those bands from which the pupils were to be drawn. I am instructed by our Missionary Committee to ask for a definite statement of the intentions of the Government respecting this Institute. In view of the fact that so many other Institutes have been completed equipped & given to the management of churches we are unable to understand why there should be this long delay so far as we can see unnecessary delay in our case.

I have the honor to be, Sir

Your obedient servant,

A. E. Hetherington

To the Deputy Minister

With reference to the plans accompanying the letter from Public Works Dept., 13th inst., I beg to refer you to the letter from the Chief Architect of 11th inst., in which he states that the brick-works in connection with the heating of the rear wing is omitted, and that the estimated cost of the building according to the amended plans would be about £22,600 exclusive of the heating apparatus which would be about £2,000.

Apparently no provision is made for heating the rear wing either in the plans or in the specifications, probably the £2,000 mentioned is intended to cover the cost of heating this wing. Might it not be well to have this matter arranged at once in order that it may...
be included in the original contract.

It is thus seen that the estimated cost of the building as now proposed is in all £24600.

The lowest tender received on the plans first submitted was £27000 which it appears was rejected by the Treasury Board (Act 5, Mr. Sutherland 1/3rd) as only £20000 was voted for the purpose.

In the said letter to Mr. Sutherland he is informed that the new amended plans have been accepted and that tenders are about to be called for. I presume no further action can be taken until these tenders are received.

Sam Bagg

P.S. This file has been held until the previous correspondence — now in the Justice Dept.

Industrial School,

Dear Sir,

In reference to the inquiry of Mr. F.H. Paget as to the certificate of electrical soundness which I gave you for one of the mares purchased for the Industrial School, I beg to say that while the Department is correct in inferring that the mare is not perfectly sound, it is wrong in supposing that she is not of good value for the money and will adapted for the work of the school.

The reason that she is not perfectly sound is that she has partial ossification of the lateral cartilages. This is a condition frequently present in the heavy breeds of horses, and in slight cases like the present one, it does not interfere in any way with the action or usefulness of the horse.

The law of soundness as recently applied in cases before the Courts in England...
looks upon soundness as nearing perfection, and that therefore the veterinarian is bound to consider any defect however trifling which prevents an animal from attaining that standard. For this reason and from the fact that comparatively few animals reach the standard of perfection, many veterinarians, myself among the number have adopted the practice of giving qualified certificates for animals sufficiently sound for the purpose intended.

I understand from you at the time the mans were examined and I had explained to you the nature of the defect of this one. That a qualified certificate would be sufficient, and I regret that there should have been any difficulty about the matter.

Trusting that this explanation will prove satisfactory I am

Yours sincerely,

Fred Torrance D.V.S.

Secretary.
Sir:

With reference to your letter of this date relative to the tenders received for the construction of the Indian Industrial School building at Brandon, the lowest of which you state is $21,564.00, the heating apparatus you add will cost $1850, while the sum of $2350 must be added for contingencies, making a total amount of $26,564. I beg to inform you that $20,000 being the amount included for the construction of this building the Estimates for the current year will be transferred immediately to the credit of your Department. It will be, of course, impossible for the whole of this money to be expended upon the building between this date and the 30th instant when the appropriation will lapse, but as much work of construction should be accomplished by that date as possible and on the 1st July the amount voted by Parliament in the Estimates for 1893-94 namely, $10,000 towards the same object can be transferred to your Department, and provision made for any additional expenditure not covered by what may be used of the $20,000 now transferred and the $10,000 that will be transferred on the 1st July by an item to be inserted in the Supplementary Estimates for the proximate year to be submitted to Parliament at its next session.

A. Gobeil, Esq.,
Deputy Minister of Public Works,
Deputy Deputy General of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of 9th inst., re cost of cottage &c., has been received, and contents noted.

With reference to explanation, they leave to say that the foundation cost more than was at first supposed, owing to a greater amount of stone-work being necessary. The cost of building also was more, as the weather getting cold, the workmen were unable to work to advantage. Had the weather been mild, a considerable saving in wages could have been made.

I was not advised as to the quality of material; and purchased what I thought would prove satisfactory; probably this cost more than was intended.

The parties who furnished the material, and also those who worked on the job, were all perfect strangers to

Dear Sir,

In compliance with your request, I herewith send a statement of material required for fencing the farm.

To build a fence with 3 wires and top rail, it will take:

- 2,640 posts,
- 14,080 ft. 2 x 4,
- 4,600 lbs. wire,
- 195 lbs. staples,
- 495 lbs. nails.

The posts should be 8 ft. long, of uniform size, 6 inches at top, and straight. As they will have to come from Rat Portage, they should be ordered early, so that they, along with the rest of material, could be hauled out to the farm, during the winter.

Yours,

(Sgd.) H. W. Todd.

P.S. This fence is similar to that on the Capt. Farn adjoining; they used 4 wires, but I think 3 sufficient.

(Sgd.) H. W. T.
