Dear Sir:

In reply to your inquiry of the 30th ultimo,
I beg leave to say that it will require 4 miles of fence
for the farm, viz: three miles around farm, and one half
mile avenue through farm with fence on each side.

The material necessary for a three strand fence
is as follows:

- 3,456 lbs. wire at 5¢ $172.80
- 2,840 posts * 25¢ $60.00
- 14,080 2 x 4 scantling $25.00 M. $352.00
- 195 "staples at 5¢ $9.75
- 495 " nails * 3 3/4¢ $18.56
- 2 gates * 10.00 $20.00

Erection of fence about $580.00

This should be the only expense in connection with it.

It could be erected cheaper by contract than by hiring labourers by the day.

Yours etc.,

(Sgd) H. W. Todd.
Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of 9th Instant, re cost of erection of fence, I beg leave to say that I have given the figures $580.00 as being as near the probable cost as I can ascertain; this would be a fraction over 45¢ per rod.

It will take from 15¢ to 20¢ each to dig the holes, according to the soil, which means from 30¢ to 40¢ per rod, besides which there is in connection with fence the clearing of right of way through the trees and scrub over one mile, stripping back off posts, setting posts, sawing off top of posts, sawing notch for scantling, nailing on scantling and wire.

It is impossible to give the exact figures for each of these items.

Mr. Bedford, Superintendent of Experimental Farm, informs me that the man, who had the contract for three miles of fencing on "Exp. Farm," lost money at 45¢ per rod, but that he, (Mr. Bedford) by hiring a full gang of good men and tools was able to build at that price.

I obtained the figures $580.00 from Mr. Bedford.

Yours etc.,

(Sgd.) H. W. Todd.

Feb. 19th 1874.

Rev. Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 14th inst., informing what progress has been made in the erection of the Industrial school building at Brandon, I have the honour to inform you that I am advised by the Dept. of Public Works that the building will not be completed until November next, and that the sum of about $8,000 has been expended up to date. The contract for the
The whole being over $21,000.

I regret that I am unable to give you any more definite information as to the particulars. The work then can be carried from the amount already expressed above figures. This will help the Dept. of Public Works supplied with the necessary funds and no delay in the carrying on the work will occur through want of further action on our part.

Yours,

[Signature]
Referring to your number 64411 of the 15th instant I beg to inform you that the date for the completion of the Industrial school at Brandon is fixed for the 30th October next and that it is not expected that the building will be completed before that date.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Dep'y Minister

Reed, Esq.
Deputy Superintendent
of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 25th inst., in reference, I beg leave to say that I herewith enclose a diagram, showing proposed plan of fence.

As you will see by the plan, there is to be an avenue across the farm from east to west, and there is considerable grain grown on each of this avenue; thus, with the proposed amount for expenditure viz., $500, it will be impossible to fence all the grain fields.

What I would propose, is that a fence similar to the one submitted to you some time ago, be built on north side of avenue, from east to west, also on east side, along road from avenue, to northeast corner of farm. This will leave the north and west side north of avenue still to be fenced. To accomplish this, I propose

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6256, File 576-5, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
propose moving the barbed wire and rough spruce posts, at present in a dilapidated fence along part of west side, and enclosing a portion of the hills around the school, and building a temporary fence of two barbed wires and posts, about 20 ft. apart, along north and west sides.

This would enclose all north of the avenue, in one block, and prevent stock getting on to damage trees etc.

The south side of avenue would have to remain unfenced, as at present.

For pasture there is a portion of farm on south side which could be fenced by running wire from the slough to the river, as seen on diagram, the river forming boundary on south, and exp. farm on east.

By our assistance, with removal of fence - this can be accomplished without exceeding the amount mentioned in your letter.

Kindly let me know at your earliest convenience, if I may order the material.

Yours,

H. W. Todd.

P.S. Had the whole farm been fencing, it was my intention to have used the wire on place in building a substantial fence, all the way across the south part of farm, to form a pasture.

(Sgd.) H. W. T.

Sir,

Your obedient servant

Brandon, Manitoba, Mar 9th 1894

Hon J H Doley
Altawa

Dear Sir,

I understand there are some outbuildings in connection with the industrial school to be erected this summer. I would like if possible to get contract for same as we have all our plant on the ground and could carry it on to better advantage if they were going on at the same time. There is a friend of mine who would like to get the job of caretaker if they regard him. He understands the working of the Mead Dowd system.

You will do what you can for me in matter.

I remain Yours truly,
J M Harrington
Sir,

Mr. Daly has handed me your letter of the 9th instant for reply, and I have to express regret that we are not likely to be able to avail ourselves of your offer to contract for out-buildings in connection with the Industrial Schools, since such building as the Department of Public Works has not already let contract for it is our intention to put up for ourselves.

With regard to application on behalf of a friend for the position of Superintendent, I may say that it is too early to enter into arrangements for such matters yet, but in my case the Methodist Church, under the auspices of which the school is to be conducted, has the first claim to have its recommendation of employees accepted.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Acting Deputy of the Superintendent of Indian Affairs.

Thomas M. Hargrave, Esq.,
Contractor and Builder,
P. O. Box 410,
Brandon, Manitoba.

Dear Sir,

The Manager of the Industrial Farm located here, tells me that last fall he received instructions from Mr. Reid of the Indian Department to arrange for the planting of apple trees along the road through the farm, continuing that runny through the Experimental Farm, expecting to procure the trees from his nursery.

As the planting of such trees would greatly enhance the value of the farm, especially as the neighbors to the west intend to continue the planting of trees on this road through their several farms.
H. L. Patmore,

Grower of Hay, Fruit, Forest and Ornamental Trees, Shrubs,
Woods and Flowering Plants.

113398

Brandon, Man., 189—

I beg to ask that you will use your influence to prevent the postponement of this work, as is now proposed; as early planting is desirable in preference to a year's delay, & the necessary labour at the present time can be readily and cheaply obtained, thereby rendering the expense very small.

In considering this, you will oblige

Yours faithfully,

I am, Sir,

MEMORANDUM

To E.F.E.Roy, Esq. From The Office of the Chief Archt.
Secretary. Department of Public Work
Ottawa, IIth June 1894

Re Industrial School, Brandon, Man.

Last September the Dept. of Indian Affairs, placed to the credit of this Department, the sum of $16,000.00, to meet two payments on a/c for building this School. Of that amount, there has been expended to date, the sum of $14,026.00, leaving a balance of $1,974. It is expected that by the end of the present fiscal year, the balance [$1974.00] in hand will be expended. It is estimated that after the present balance has been expended the sum of $9,080. will be required to pay for the completion of the Contract, &c.

Recommend that the sum of $10,000. be asked in the Sup. Estimates 1894-95.

[Sd.] D. Ewart
for Chief Architect.

Indusheal School,
Brandon, Man.
June 18th, 1894.

Dear Sir,

With reference to a letter received from the Deputy Minister, dated Nov. 10/93, authorizing the purchase of a scraper, with instructions to do what could be done towards filling in the excavation near the school; they have nothing to say, as the frost had set in before I received the letter, nothing could be done at the work last fall, and I did not purchase the scraper.

The contractor has to remove a lot of clay from the front of the school, to bring it to a proper grade, and he, while doing so, could, with a little extra trouble, fill it into the excavation. It could be done cheaper than, than in any other way. I think that probably $25 would do it in that way. Somehow this, as there was little prospect of spare time at the farm.

Yours, etc.,
[Signature]
H. W. Todd

Dear Sir,

Will you kindly give me information regarding a sub-contract I have completed on the Industrial School here at Brandon. That is I took a sub-contract for all the Cut Stone work from Messrs. Harrington & Chambers, the Contractors for said School, amounting to $1300.00. I have received only about $600.00 and as the School is drawing very near completion, I am anxious to know how I can secure the balance still due to me, as the Contractors refused giving me an order on the Government, if they are actually worth nothing outside of their contract.

My contract was completed & passed by the Inspector over two months ago.

I shall feel very grateful to you if you can in any way help me to secure the balance still due to me on this contract.

Your very respectfully,

James Thomson
Ottawa, 30th June, 1894.

Dear Mr. Thomson,

I have your letter of the 26th instant asking for information regarding your sub-contract on the Indian Industrial School at Brandon, and stating that the contractors for said school are owing you a balance of $650.00 for work done. I shall make immediate enquiry in regard to this matter and again communicate with you in the course of a few days.

Believe me,

Yours faithfully,

James Thomson, Esq.,
Brandon,
Man.

hereafter called "the Contractor," of the first part;

And HER MAJESTY QUEEN VICTORIA, represented herein by the Minister of Public Works of Canada, of the second part:

WITNESSETH, that in consideration of the covenants and agreements on the part of Her Majesty hereinafter contained, the Contractor covenant and agree with Her Majesty as follows:

1. In this Contract the word "work" or "works" shall, unless the context require a different meaning, mean the whole of the work and materials, matters and things required to be done, furnished and performed by the Contractor under this Contract. The word "Architect" shall mean the Chief Architect of the Department of Public Works of Canada, for the time being, and all persons acting over the said Chief Architect and include any of his assistants acting under his instructions, and all instructions or directions, or certificates given, or decisions made by any one acting for the Chief Architect, shall be subject to his approval, and may be cancelled, altered, modified and changed, as to him may seem fit.

2. All covenants and agreements herein contained shall be binding on and extend to the Executors and Administrators of the Contractor and shall extend to and be binding upon the successors of Her Majesty, and wherever in this contract Her Majesty is referred to, such reference shall include Her successors, and wherever the Contractor referred to such reference shall include Executors and Administrators.

3. That the Contractor will, at own expense, provide all and every kind of labour, machinery and other plans, models, articles and things whatever necessary for the due execution and completion of all and every the works set out or referred to in the specification hereunto annexed, marked , and set out or referred to in the plans and drawings prepared and to be prepared for the purposes of the work, and will execute and fully complete the respective portions of such works and deliver the same complete to Her Majesty, on or before the day of the month of in the year of Our Lord one thousand eight hundred and
The said works to be constructed of the best materials of their several kinds, and finished in the best and most workmanlike manner, in the manner required by and in strict conformity with the said specifications, and the drawings relating thereto, and the working or detail drawings which may from time to time be furnished (which said specifications and drawings are hereby declared to be part of this Contract); and to the complete satisfaction of the Chief Architect for the time being having control over the works.

4. That the several parts of this Contract shall be taken together, to explain each other, and to make the whole consistent; and if it be found that anything has been omitted or mis-stated, which is necessary for the proper performance and completion of any part of the work contemplated, in either the drawings hereinbefore referred to, or the specifications annexed, the explanation and interpretation given by the Chief Architect shall be received as such, be final binding and conclusive upon the Contractor, and the Contractor will, at his own expense, execute the same as though it had been properly described, and the correction of any such error or omission shall not be deemed to be an addition to or deviation from the works hereby contracted for.

5. The Architect shall be at liberty at any time, either before the commencement or during the construction of the works, or any portion thereof, to order any extra work to be done, and to make any changes which he may deem expedient in the works, in shape, size, nature, location, or position of the works, or any part or parts thereof, or in any other thing connected with the works, whether or not such changes increase or diminish the work to be done, or the cost of doing the same, and the Contractor shall immediately comply with all written instructions of the Architect in that behalf; and the Contractor shall not make any change, addition, omission, deviation from the works, and shall not be entitled to any payment for any change, addition, omission, deviation, or any extra work, unless such change, addition, omission, deviation, or any extra work, shall have been first directed in writing by the Architect, and notified to the Contractor in writing, and unless the price to be paid for any addition or extra work shall have been previously fixed by the Architect in writing, and approved of by the Minister of Public Works for the time being, and the decision of the Architect as to whether any such change or deviation increases or diminishes the cost of the work, and as to the amount to be paid or deducted, as the case may be, in respect thereof, shall be final, and the decision of his decision in writing as to such matters shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to be paid therefor. If any such change or alteration constitutes, in the opinion of the said Architect, a deduction from the works, his decision as to the amount to be deducted on account thereof shall be final and binding.

6. That all the clauses of this Contract shall apply to any changes, additions, deviations, or extra work, in like manner, and to the same extent as to the works contracted for, and no changes, additions, deviations or extra work shall annul or invalidate this Contract.

7. That if any change or deviation in or omission from the works be made by the Contractor, the cost of work to be done shall be decreased, no compensation shall be claimable by the Contractor for any loss of anticipated profits in respect thereof.

8. That the Architect shall be the sole judge of work and material in respect of both quantity and quality, and his decision on all questions in dispute with regard to work or material, or as to the meaning or intention of this Contract and the plans, specifications and drawings shall be final, and no works or extra or additional works or changes shall be deemed to have been executed, nor shall the Contractor be entitled to payment for the same unless they shall have been executed to the satisfaction of the Architect as evidenced by his certificate in writing, which certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to be paid therefor.
9. A competent foreman is to be kept on the ground by the Contractor during all the working hours, to receive the orders of the Architect, and should the person so appointed be deemed by the Architect incompetent, or conduct himself improperly, he may be discharged by the Architect, and another shall at once be appointed in his stead; such foreman shall be considered as the lawful representative of the Contractor, and shall have full power to carry out all requisitions and instructions of the said Architect.

10. In case any material, or other things, in the opinion of the Architect not in accordance with the said several parts of this Contract, or not sufficiently sound or otherwise unsuitable for the respective works, be used for or brought to the intended works, or any part thereof, or if any work be improperly executed, the Architect may require the Contractor to remove the same, and to provide proper material or other things, or properly execute the work, as the case may be, and thereupon the Contractor shall and will immediately comply with the said requisition, and if twenty-four hours shall elapse, and such requisition shall not have been complied with, the Architect may cause such material or other things in such work, to be removed, and in any such case the Contractor shall pay to Her Majesty all such damages and expense as shall be incurred in the removal of such material materials, or other things, or of such work, or Her Majesty may, in her discretion, retain and deduct such damages and expenses from any amounts payable to the Contractor.

11. All machinery and other plant, materials and things whatsoever, provided by the Contractor for the works hereby contracted for, and not rejected under the provisions of the last preceding clause, shall, from the time of their being so provided, become, and, until the final completion of the said works, shall be the property of Her Majesty for the purposes of the said works, and the same shall on no account be taken away, or used or disposed of, except for the purposes of the said works, without the consent of the Architect, and Her Majesty shall not be answerable for any loss or damage whatsoever which may happen to such machinery or other plant, material or things; provided always that upon the completion of the works and upon payment by the Contractor of all such moneys, if any, as shall be due from to Her Majesty such of the said machinery and other plant, material and things as shall not have been used and converted in the works and shall remain undisposed of, shall, upon demand, be delivered up to the Contractor.

12. If the Architect shall at any time consider the number of workmen employed or quantity of machinery or other plant, or the quantity of proper materials respectively employed or provided by the Contractor on or for the said works to be insufficient for the advancement thereof towards completion within the limited times, or that the works are, or some part thereof is not being carried on with due diligence, then in every such case the said Architect may, by written notice to the Contractor, require him to supply and provide such additional workmen, horses, machinery or other plant or materials, as the Architect may think necessary, and in case the Contractor shall not thereupon within six days, or such other longer period as may be fixed by any such notice, in all respects comply therewith, then the Architect may, either on behalf of Her Majesty or if he see fit, as the agent of and on account of the Contractor, but in either case at the expense of the Contractor, provide and employ such additional workmen, horses, machinery and other plant, or any thereof, or such additional materials respectively as he may think proper, and may pay such additional workmen such wages, and for such additional horses, machinery or other plant, and materials respectively such prices as he may think proper, and all such wages and prices respectively shall thereupon forthwith be repaid by the Contractor or the same may be retained and deducted out of any moneys at any time payable to the Contractor; and Her Majesty may
use, in execution or advancement of the said works, not only the horses, machinery, and other plant, and materials so in any case provided by any one on Her Majesty's behalf, but also all such as may have been or may be provided by or on behalf of the said Contractor.

13. In case the Contractor shall make default or delay in diligently continuing to execute or advance the works to the satisfaction of the Architect, and such default or delay shall continue for six days after notice in writing shall have been given by the Architect to the Contractor requiring him to put an end to such default or delay, or in case the Contractor shall become insolvent, or make any assignee for the benefit of creditors, or neglect either personally or by a skilful and competent agent to superintend the works, then in any of such cases Her Majesty may take the work out of the Contractor's hands and employ such means as She may see fit to complete the work, and in such cases the Contractor shall be liable for the cost thereof, and in respect of the works performed, but shall nevertheless remain liable for all losses and damages which may be suffered by Her Majesty by reason of the non-completion by the Contractor of the works; and all materials and things whatsoever, and all horses, machinery and other plant provided for the purposes of the works, shall belong and be considered as the property of Her Majesty for the purposes and according to the provisions and conditions contained in the eleventh clause hereof.

15. The Contractor shall not have or make any claim or demand, or bring any action or suit or petition against Her Majesty for any damages which he may sustain by reason of any delay in the progress of the work, arising from the acts or omissions of Her Majesty's agents, and it is hereby agreed that in the event of any such delay the Contractor shall have such further time for the completion of the works as may be fixed in that behalf by the Minister of Public Works for the time being.

Should the Contractor not complete the work herein contracted for at the period agreed upon as above mentioned shall be liable for, and shall cause to be paid to Her Majesty all salaries or wages which shall become due to person or persons superintending the work on behalf of Her said Majesty from the above named period for completion, until the same shall actually be completed and received.

22. If the Contractor fail at any time in paying the salaries or wages of any person employed by upon or in respect of said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary be twelve days in arrears, or if there be due to any such person twelve days wages or salary, the Architect must notify the Contractor to pay such wages or wages and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to the date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then Her Majesty may pay to such person salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenant with Her Majesty to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

23. The Contractor will protect, and will not remove or destroy, or permit to be removed or destroyed, the stakes, and other marks placed on or about the said works by the Architect of the works, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.
24. Any notice or other communication mentioned in this Contract to be notified or given to the Contractor shall be deemed to be well and sufficiently notified or given if the same be left at the Contractor's office or mailed in any Post Office, to the Contractor or foreman, addressed to the address mentioned in this Contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business.

25. And Her Majesty, in consideration of the premises, hereby covenants with the Contractor, that will be paid for and in respect of the works hereby contracted for, and in the manner set out in the next clause hereof, as follows, viz.:

For the whole of the works herein contemplated as set forth, referred to and described in the hereto annexed specifications, and on the plans prepared for the purpose of these works, which said works are required to be executed to ensure the construction and completion of

the sum in the whole of thousand

hundred and cents, of

lawful money of Canada.
26. Cash payments equal to about ninety per cent of the value of the work done, approximately made up from returns of progress measurements and computed at the prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this Contract, may be made to the Contractor monthly, if practicable, on the written certificate of the Architect that the work for, or on account of which the certificate was granted, has been done to his satisfaction and stating the value of such work computed as above mentioned—and upon approval of such certificate by the Minister of Public Works for the time being for the Dominion of Canada, and the said certificate and such approval thereof shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to be paid the said ninety per cent or any part thereof. The remaining ten per cent shall be retained, unless otherwise ordered by the Minister, till the final completion of the whole work to the satisfaction of the Chief Architect for the time being having control over the work, and within two months after such completion the remaining ten per cent will be paid. And it is hereby declared that the written certificate of the said Architect certifying that the work has been completed to his satisfaction shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to receive or be paid the said remaining ten per cent, or any part thereof.

27. It is intended that every allowance to which the Contractor fairly entitled will be embraced in the Architect's monthly certificates; but should the Contractor at any time have claims of any description which he consider are not included in the progress certificates it will be necessary for him to make and repeat such claims in writing to the Architect within fourteen days after the date of each and every certificate in which he allege such claims to have been omitted.

28. The Contractor in presenting claims of the kind referred to in the last clause must accompany them with satisfactory evidence of their accuracy, and the reason why he think they should be allowed. Unless such claims are thus made during the progress of the work, within fourteen days, as in the preceding clause, and repeated in writing every month, unless finally adjusted or rejected, it must be clearly understood that they shall be forever shut out, and the Contractor shall have no claims against Her Majesty.

29. The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work or release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof, but shall at the conclusion of the work deliver over the same in good order, according to the true intent and meaning of this contract.

3. Her Majesty shall have the right to suspend operations from time to time at any particular point or points, or upon the whole of the works, and in the event of such right being exercised so as to cause any delay to the Contractor, then an extension of time due to such delay by operation, to be fixed by the Minister of Public Works shall be provided for, shall be allowed to complete the Contract, but no such delay shall vitiate or avoid this contract or any part thereof, or the obligation hereby imposed, or any concurrent or other bond or security for the performance of this Contract, nor shall the Contractor be entitled to any claim for damages by reason of any such suspension of operations. And at any time after operations have been suspended either in whole or in part such operations may be again resumed and again suspended and resumed as Her Majesty may think proper. And upon the Contractor receiving written notice on behalf of Her Majesty that the suspended operations are to be resumed the Contractor shall at once resume the operations and diligently carry on the same.

31. Should the amount now voted by Parliament and applicable towards payment for the work hereby contracted for be at any time expended previous to the completion of the works the Minister of Public Works for the time being may give the Contractor written notice to that effect. And upon receiving such notice the Contractor may if think fit, stop the work—but in any case shall not be entitled
to any payment for work done beyond the amount voted and applicable as aforesaid—unless and until the necessary funds shall have been voted by Parliament in that behalf. And in no event shall the Contractor have or make any claim upon Her Majesty for any damages or compensation by reason of the said suspension of payment, or by reason of any delay or loss caused by the stoppage of work.

32. The Contractor shall not permit, allow, or encourage the sale of any spirituous liquors on or near the works.

33. No work whatever shall at any time or place be carried on during Sunday, and the Contractor shall take all necessary steps for preventing any foreman or agent or men from working or employing others on that day.

34. The Contractor shall not allow any public ceremony in connection with the work, without having previously obtained the permission of the Minister of Public Works.

35. It is hereby agreed, that all matters of difference arising between the parties hereto upon any matter connected with or arising out of this contract, the decision whereof is not hereby especially given to the Arbitrator, shall be referred to the award and arbitration of the Chief Architect for the time being, having control over the works, and the award of such Architect shall be final and conclusive; and it is hereby declared that such award shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to receive or be paid any sum or sums on account, or by reason of such matters in difference.

36. It is distinctly declared that no implied contract of any kind whatsoever, by or on behalf of Her Majesty, shall arise or be implied from anything in this contract contained, or from any position or situation of the parties at any time, it being clearly understood and agreed that the express contracts, covenants and agreements herein contained and made by Her Majesty, are and shall be the only contracts, covenants and agreements upon which any rights against Her are to be founded.

Ottawa, July 7th, 1894

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 3rd instant I have to inform you that the Department has made a rule not to entertain the claims of sub-contractors on any Government works, the past experience having shown that it involves the Department into unending trouble without in the end making the position of the sub-contractors any better.

In order to show how far the Department desires not to be held responsible in connection with sub-contracts, I enclose you herewith a form of contract which was signed by the contractors on this work, and you will see at page 5 that it is understood and agreed that no sub-contract for the execution of works contracted for shall be recognized in any manner or form by Her Majesty, who shall not be in any way held liable for the payment of any moneys due to said sub-contractors.

I may add that Messrs Harrington & Chambers have not yet completed...
completed their contract and that they have only received $11,820 on the total amount of the contract which is $21,475.

Believe me

Dear Sir,

Yours very truly

[Signature]

Deputy Minister

Hayter Reed, Esq.
Deputy Superintendent General
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
10th July

Dear Mr. Thompson,

Adverting to your letter of the 26th ultimo, I regret to have to inform you that the Department of Public Works, which is charged with the construction of the school at Brandon, can do nothing to secure to you the payment of the balance due on account of your sub-contract. That Department, I am advised, has made a rule not to entertain the claims of sub-contractors on any Government work, experience having shown that the recognition of such claims involved the Department in unending trouble without in the end making the position of the subcontractors any better. This rule cannot possibly be departed from as the agreement entered into with the contractors for the school contains the stipulation that no sub-contract for the execution of any of the work shall be recognized in any manner or form by Her Majesty, who shall not be in any way held liable for the payment of any moneys due the subcontractors.

I have learned that Messrs. Harrington & Chambers have up to the present only received $11,820.00 of the total amount of the contract, which is $21,475.00, and I trust that you will yet be able to secure from the contractors full payment of the balance due by them to you.

Brandon, Man., Sept. 11th, 1929.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of August 16th file No. 133-0-5, I wish to say that we tried out more thorly the 1020 tractor and found it unsatisfactory. It did not have power enough to handle the cultivator in our light land. We therfor brought out 2866 H. P. engine and have tried it out on the different phases of our work. It is now running the corn cutter. It handles everything with entire satisfaction. And at the same time we took in the old engine for repairs.

I saw the L. M. C. representative this morning, and he tells me that they have the engine apart, but have not completed the repairs. He finds that the cost will be $255.00. The arrangements with the Company was if we took the 2866 tractor, it would cost $750.00, and the old tractor. We therfor now have the option of taking this new tractor at $750.00, or waiting until the old engine is repaired and taking it back at a cost of $255.00. I am quite convinced that it would be in the interest of economy in the long run to purchase the new tractor on the terms defined.

Awaiting your final word in this matter,

I am yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.
Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man.,

#2.

We were anxious to find out if the drain pipes were clear, and after the water ran for the night, we found the drainage coming out in the pasture field about 20 rods below the tank. We had a man dig down to the pipe at this point, and found the tile about 7 feet in the ground and the tile continued beyond the point where we dug the hole. We found a brake in the tile where the water was coming out. It would seem from this indication that the tile beyond this point at least is plugged up.

I felt that we should not go any further with work in this connection without consulting your Department, and I assume that further consideration and negotiations in connection with it will be carried on with Mr. Shillinglaw, your representative in connection with the new building.

I am yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.
Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Sept. 6th, 1929.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

A short while ago a representative of the Water Power Department of the Dominion Government called on us and stated that their Department in Winnipeg had received a request from the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa to inspect the Water system and water supply on your property here, and we gave him what help we could in this connection.

He asked us to open the septic tank. We found it covered at the upper end with about 5 feet of earth. We engaged a man to dig down to the manhole, and opened up the three sections of this tank.

We found the first one filled to the top, about ½ of the substance in it was solids. After it was opened, it began to bulge out through the manhole, and we had as much as we could shoveled out, and then the liquid came up through the manhole and partly up in the hole we had dug. The second chamber was not quite full to the top, it contained liquid in the most part, about a foot or 18 inches heavy solids in the bottom. The third section was full to the top. We had the crust broken up, and set a man at dipping it until it was almost empty. Then the liquid burst through the obstruction and filled it to its normal level. This reduced the level in both the first and second chambers to normal. We then turned a flow of water from our water system into the sewerage drain and left it running over night, and found the tanks at normal level in the morning.
Ottawa, September 14th, 1929.

Reverend Sir,

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to a corner stone at the Brandon Indian Residential School. Your proposal to have a private function is approved as it is improbable that The Hon. Mr. Forke would be available. It would be satisfactory to the Department to place a metal box in the wall beside the stone already ordered for the corner. At a later date, if some lettering on the outside of the stone is desirable, you may correspond with the Department.

I trust that Rev. Mr. Ferrier's health will permit him to be present on the 24th instant.

I have, also, your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the Dominion Water Power Branch Engineer's finding in connection with the septic tank. Please do not incur any expenditure in this connection as it is possible that the engineer in question will recommend an entirely new septic tank. The Department's officers have already discussed this with Mr. Atwood, the District Chief Engineer at Winnipeg, who will continue his investigation and will be in charge of any improvements to the sewage disposal system at the school.

Your obedient servant,

PLASTER COAT WATERPROOFING SPECIFICATIONS

THE HAUSLING SYSTEM
For Waterproofing Concrete and Cement Mixtures

Waterproofing may be effected either in the concrete mass or by a cement coating on either the inside or outside of the masonry walls if "Anti-Hydro" is used in gauging water. The bond of "Anti-Hydro" cement coating to brick, stone, concrete or cement finished surfaces is perfect, adhering permanently against any head of water.

SPECIFICATIONS

WATERPROOFING—All interior surfaces of all exterior walls, upper surface of concrete floor slabs below grade, all pits, piers, etc., as shown on plans shall be waterproofed by the application of a plaster coat of 1 part Portland cement and 3 parts clean sand, gauged and tempered with a solution of 1 part "Anti-Hydro" to each 10 parts of water. Floor toppings shall be 1/2 inch thickness and shall serve the double purpose of waterproofing and a hard, dustless floor surface. Wall coatings shall be 3/8 inch thick, properly coved and bonded to the floor, and carried up to 1 foot above grade.

GROUTING—To insure perfect bond to underlying masonry, all surfaces, before application of "Anti-Hydro" mortar, shall be thoroughly roughed and cleaned and brushed with a slush or grout made by stirring Portland cement into a solution of 1 part "Anti-Hydro" and 3 parts water to the consistency of a heavy paint. The coating specified above shall then be applied, while the slush coat is still wet.

CONSTRUCTION JOINTS—Wherever possible the coatings should be made continuously until completed. Where construction joints are necessary they should be carefully cleaned and slushed with the grout described in previous paragraph before new coating or topping is applied. Care should be exercised to join the topping at a point away from the construction joint in the slab.

PUMPING—Where water is present in the excavation a pump of sufficient capacity to keep water below the floor shall be operated continuously while the floor and walls are being troweled and for 24 hours thereafter.

If, because of architectural treatment of interior surfaces of walls it is desirable to waterproof from the outside, the following paragraph should be substituted for the WATERPROOFING paragraph above.

SPECIFICATIONS

WATERPROOFING—Footings of all exterior walls shall be covered with a 1" topping of "Anti-Hydro" gauged mortar before walls are placed. The outside surfaces of the exterior walls shall be plastered with the same mortar from the footings to 1 foot above the grade, and the inside surface of these walls shall be plastered from the footing to the top of the floor level. The waterproof mortar shall consist of 1 part Portland cement and 2 parts clean sand, gauged and tempered with a solution of 1 part "Anti-Hydro" to each 10 parts of water. Wall coatings shall be 3/8 inch thick and coved and bonded to footing toppings. The upper surface of concrete floor slabs below grade shall be topped with the same waterproof mortar 1" thick, and properly bonded to the waterproof plaster on the inside of the walls.

SERVICES—Information and advice on all problems of waterproofing and concrete hardening may be had from any of our offices.

MASS CONCRETE WATERPROOFING SPECIFICATIONS

THE HAUSLING SYSTEM
For Waterproofing Concrete and Cement Mixtures

Waterproofing may be effected either in the concrete mass or by a cement coating if "Anti-Hydro" is used in gauging water. Specifications for cement plaster are shown on a separate sheet.

SPECIFICATIONS

WATERPROOFING OF MASS CONCRETE

All concrete in contact with earth on one side, and such other masonry as is indicated on the plans, shall be made of 1 part Portland Cement, 2 parts sharp, washed sand, 4 parts broken stone or gravel, and shall be waterproofed throughout the mass by the addition of "Anti-Hydro" liquid waterproofing to the water used in gauging the concrete mixture. Not less than 1 1/2 gallons of "Anti-Hydro" shall be used for each cubic yard of concrete. The correct proportion of "Anti-Hydro" and the proper consistency of the mixture will be obtained if for each barrel of cement 1 gallon of "Anti-Hydro" and 10 to 15 gallons of water be used. Concrete shall in all cases be mixed without excess water. Where forms are below water level, extremely stiff mix shall be used.

PUMPING

Where water is present in the excavation a pump of sufficient capacity to keep water below the forms shall be operated continuously during the pouring and for 24 hours thereafter. The earth must be so prepared that the water will easily drain under the concrete to the pump.

SPADING CONCRETE

All concrete shall be thoroughly and continuously spaded during the pouring.

CONSTRUCTION JOINTS

Wherever possible floor slabs and exterior walls and footings shall be poured continuously until completed. Where construction joints are necessary same shall be keyed with a 2" x 2" key. When pouring is about to be resumed the entire joint shall be treated with a slush composed of 1 part "Anti-Hydro," 3 parts water, and sufficient neat cement to form a thick creamy mixture. This slush should be applied with a brush and should still be wet when followed by the new concrete.

SERVICES—Information and advice on all problems of waterproofing and concrete hardening may be had from any of our offices.

ANTI-HYDRO WATERPROOFING CO.
Laboratories, 265-295 Badger Ave., Newark, N. J.

Form 157 July 1929
ANTI-HYDRO hardens and waterproofs Concrete

DIRECTIONS

See Table for All Mixing Proportions

In General
Successful waterproofing or hardening requires one gallon of "ANTI-HYDRO" for every barrel of cement used. To attain these results use a solution of "ANTI-HYDRO" in water or introduce directly into the mixer one quart of "ANTI-HYDRO" for each bag of cement while the water is being added.

To Secure A Certain Bond
When continuous work from start to finish is impossible, preparation joints is important. If work is to continue over a surface or from a joint that has reached its final set, become dry or dirty, the surface must be roughed as with a pick, washed with water and thoroughly brushed over or sprayed with "ANTI-HYDRO" grout. The new work must cover the grout before it dries.

Cautions
Insist on accurate measurement of all ingredients.

Use a fairly stiff mix and not a sloppy mixture. Concrete poured too wet will not be waterproof, will set slowly and will not be hard and will never attain normal strength.

Concrete must be well spaded in the forms. Don't depend on simply filling the forms.

Float and trowel well all plaster coats, floor topping, etc.

Use no lime in the same mix with "ANTI-HYDRO." When pouring floor surfaces, no drier should be used. The apparent need for a drier indicates that the mix was too wet.

ANTI-HYDRO WATERPROOFING CO.
NEWARK NEW JERSEY
The Integral Method

The function of "Anti-Hydro" may be expressed as waterproofing cement with cement, that is, mixing the unhydrated cement with a cement solution with which it is chemically active. The pores in ordinary concrete are thus completely filled with a material of the same character as the cement itself. This integrally forms an insoluble mass which is permanently waterproof and hard through and through. The unprecedented record of "Anti-Hydro" success since 1904 demonstrates beyond all doubt the permanency of this method.

How It Waterproofs

"Anti-Hydro" is a colorless liquid compound friendly to cement. When added in certain percentages to the water used in gauging Portland cement mixtures in the usual way, it accelerates the set, increases the strength, and renders the cement masonry impervious to water, moisture, frost, gas, oils, odors, etc. It chemically combines with Portland cement and excites and brings into service all the cohesive possibilities of Portland cements, which in themselves are the most efficient waterproofing mediums.

For Hard and Dustless Floors

By building hardness into concrete instead of painting it on the surface, "Anti-Hydro" produces dustless, adamant floors that are permanent. All of the earliest installations, now more than 25 years old, are in perfect condition today. "Anti-Hydro" increases the hardness of concrete at the age of three days, equal to that normally attained in one month's time.

Prevents Efflorescence In Brick Mortar

The addition of "Anti-Hydro" to Portland cement mortars used in masonry eliminates the necessity for any other waterproofing or damp-proofing. It also helps prevent efflorescent salts coming from the mortar and staining the masonry.

Prevents Disintegration

When used in concrete "Anti-Hydro" positively prevents disintegration. Corrosion of the reinforcing steel with its consequent bursting of the concrete is entirely prevented. It eliminates porosity, thus excluding moisture and renders walls non-conductive. Concrete walls or cement floors made with "Anti-Hydro" will resist the action of sea water, as well as the action of acids and alkalis. Similarly, concrete blocks, pipe or other cement products when made with "Anti-Hydro" will resist local acid or alkal conditions in the soil.

A Perfect Bond

The bond of "Anti-Hydro" coatings to brick, stone concrete, or cement-finished surfaces is so perfect that they will adhere permanently against any head of water.

Prevents Freezing

"Anti-Hydro" is almost indispensable in cold weather. One part "Anti-Hydro" and ten parts water used for mixing permits concreting at temperatures as low as 15 degrees F.

Road Work

"Anti-Hydro" produces a waterproof road with a harder and more durable surface which can be opened to traffic in days, where weeks are required without it. With certain brands of Portland cement, "Anti-Hydro" gauged concrete road patches may be opened for traffic in 24 hours. An exceptional bond is formed with adjacent concrete.

Other Uses

Wherever water resisting or water holding is required of cement, "Anti-Hydro" will prove invaluable. It has been most successfully used for waterproofing tunnels, subways, foundations, cellars, walls, pipe reservoirs, roofs, swimming pools, tanks, floors and for stucco work.

Saves Its Own Cost

"Anti-Hydro" enriches the mortars and saves the cost of trowelling, mixing and supervision. This saving in labor more than pays the cost of the "Anti-Hydro."

Sir,

Mr. Attwood's wire of September 11th states that the Department of Indian Affairs consider that a gravity system from their present reservoir will provide sufficient pressure for water services in the basement and first floor.

Our survey of the location shows that the elevation of the top of the reservoir is 112.4, elevation of outlet pipe from reservoir 109.4, the elevation of the basement floor will be 91.5 and the elevation of the first floor will be 102 with service outlets at an elevation of approximately 105 on the floor. Thus we will have a maximum pressure head of 112.4 - 105 or 7.4 feet on the service outlets of the first floor. This head will produce about 3.2 lbs. per square inch pressure at the service taps.

In ordinary private installations for houses the water supply usually operates under a pressure of from 20 to 40 lbs. per square inch and the lowest pressure considered serviceable is from 10 to 15 lbs. It is therefore evident that a pressure of 3.2 lbs. per square inch on the first floor at the Brandon School cannot be considered to give satisfactory results although water will flow.

The new building at Brendon is being equipped with fire hose on every floor, bath rooms are provided for on all floors and to supply these upper floors a pressure system is required.

The installation of fire protection equipment on every floor implies that fire protection is necessary and this can only be provided for by an adequate pressure system. Small pressure tanks cannot provide this protection, although they would serve to give a better service on the two upper floors. Without the installation of a good gravity tank system for water supply the situation would be that the basement would be supplied fairly adequately from gravity, the ground floor would have an unsatisfactory service and small pressure tanks would have to be installed to supply the upper two floors. No water supply for fire protection would be available.

Under these circumstances I would again strongly recommend that the water supply installation for this school be a pressure tank system to supply water to all services within the building. Nor can the prime requisites for any residential school be an adequate water supply and also a considerable measure of fire protection.

I am arranging to make a thorough examination of the present septic tank system in a few days and will let you know the results at once.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) D. B. Gow,
Assistant District Chief Engineer.

The Director,

Corner Stone of New Indian School Laid

Ceremony Attended by Representative Gathering; Historical Sketch of School

Thirty-four years after the original building was constructed, the corner stone of the new Indian Industrial school was laid on Wednesday afternoon before a very representative gathering. The formal ceremonies were presided over by Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D., the present head of the school, while brief addresses were given by Dr. J. W. Hilton, president of the Manitoba conference, Dr. J. H. Emerson, M.L.A., and Mayor Cater. The actual laying of the corner stone was performed by the Rev. Thompson Ferrier, former principal and superintendent of Indian schools and hospitals for the United Church. Assisting in the program were the Rev. J. A. Corbett, secretary-treasurer of mission for the Manitoba conference, Rev. R. G. Pritchard, W. H. Shillinglaw, and the Rev. D. H. Telfer, chairman of the board of directors. On the platform at the time were Mrs. Ferrier, members of the presidency and a number of ex-pupils.

During the ceremony, splendid tribute was paid to the Rev. Thompson Ferrier for the great work accomplished by him during his long term of office, and considerable expression was taken of the training that will be conducted in the new building under the principalship of Dr. Doyle.

History of School

The historical sketch of the school placed in the corner stone by Rev. Doyle showed that it is one of the institutions whose policy is the department of Indian affairs in providing an educational and vocational training for Indian children in Canada. The educational program is carried out in co-operation with churches which years ago commenced missionary and educational work among the Indian people.

Thirty-seven years ago it was decided to establish a substantial school under the care of the Methodist church, and the choice of the site here was made by the late Rev. James Woodworth and the late Rev. Alex. Sutherland. But only three years later that the school, which has just been demolished to make room for the new building, was reopened and a veteran missionary, Rev. J. Simmonds, appointed principal. He was a master of the Cree language and had years of experience in Indian work. Four years later came Mr. and thirty years ago last June, Rev. Thompson Ferrier who was then pastor of the Methodist church in Edmonton and who laid the corner stone Wednesday, was appointed head of the institution.

Splendid progress in connection with the school and its 960 acre farm has been made. Much credit due to the business acumen, tact and diplomacy was paid to the Rev. Thompson Ferrier in bringing the Brandon school to such a high standard. In February last Rev. Ferrier tendered his resignation and later the Rev. Dr. Doyle was appointed in his place.

More commodious quarters were needed and the present new structure will remedy conditions. During construction the pupils had to be taken care of as numbers returned home where they could attend school for the present year, while 83 were taken to the Edmonton school. It is expected that the new school will be ready for occupation in September, 1950. I will take care of 150 pupils and as a number of other residential schools are filled to capacity there have been many who is expected that the new building will be occupied in a very short time. The number of Indian pupils seeking higher education makes it necessary that high school work be undertaken as soon as school re-opens.
Indian Residential School

R. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Sept. 28th.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir:

The informal laying of the Corner Stone of the new Indian Residential School took place on Wednesday. I am sending you under separate cover, yesterday's copy of the Daily Sun which carries an account of the function.

The cost of the copper box in which the documents and articles were placed cost $2.75, if it is in order, I shall let this go with our tinsmith account and pay this item in our current expenses.

The face of the stone upon which lettering could be placed, is 32" long by 12" deep. The contractor has no one on the construction who could do this lettering. I called the marble works today, and they could do the work by bringing out an electric machine which they use. If "1929" alone was placed on the stone, it would cost approximately $5.00, and the cost would be in proportion to this, according to the lettering required, but $20.00 would be the limit of cost on a surface of this size.

We will await your direction as to what ought to be done.

I am yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

There is a 3 in. pipe, which served the old building, now running through the new Basement. This pipe enters at "Store room" and runs across Kitchen and on to the barns. Unfortunately it is only about 4 ft. underground now and will have a pretty good chance of freezing up for lack of cover. Could you take this up as the Contractor wishes to put it into shape before freezeup.

The Basement story is now practically complete.

Yours Very Truly,

VERY POOR COPY
Sir:

On October 5th I made an examination of the septic tank that has been in operation at the Brandon Industrial School for at least twenty years, during which time it has never been cleaned out or opened up. The contractors recently have uncovered the opening to the tank and have done some work in trying to flush it out and latterly have tried pumping out the liquid contents. It was found that the drain from the septic tank was plugged and that the tank itself was nearly half full of solid matter in all three compartments. After being pumped as dry as was possible, it was found that the tank again became nearly half filled up with water, showing the tank itself to be in bad condition and leaking. In speaking with Dr. Boyce, Principal of the Industrial School, he stated he had met a man who was engaged about twenty years ago on the construction of the septic tank. This man stated that they had encountered springs in the excavation for the tank and that great trouble was experienced in pouring the concrete for the chambers because of these springs and that a very poor job was made.

The septic tank in its present condition is practically useless and it is considered uneconomical to reconstruct it or to use the present site for another septic tank owing to the presence of the springs referred to above. It is therefore our intention to construct an entirely new septic tank, identical in size and character with that constructed for the Cecilia Jeffrey School at Kenora. Boring are to be taken so as to secure a location as close to the old site as possible, but yet be free from the presence of springs. If weather conditions permit, it is planned to complete the work this fall, the work to be done on a cost plus basis by the general contractor for the new school under direction of this office and under the personal supervision of the inspector at the school.

Will you please let me know at as early a date as possible whether this meets with the approval of yourself and the Department of Indian Affairs.

Your obedient servant,

C. H. Attwood,
District Chief Engineer.

Per.

The Director,
Dom. Water Power & Reclamation Service,
Dept. of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ont.
Sir,

Your file number: 13300-15.

Mr. Attwood reports that the present tank is practically useless and proposes building an entirely new septic tank identical in size and character with that constructed for the Cecilia Jeffrey school at Kenora.

I shall be glad to know if this proposal meets with the approval of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,

Sealed tenders addressed to the undersigned and endorsed on the envelope "Tender for Indian Residential School at Brandon," will be received up to noon of the 24th day of June, 1929, for the erection of the above mentioned building.

ENGL.
November 22nd, 1929.

Sir:

I am enclosing an analysis, made by the National Testing Laboratories of Winnipeg, of the water to be used at the new industrial school at Brandon. Mr. Blackie, who is President of the National Testing Laboratories and also City Chemist of Winnipeg, informs me that the water is quite hard and quite similar to the water supply in use in Winnipeg prior to the completion of the aqueduct from Shoal Lake. He states however that the water would lend itself readily to softening devices.

This analysis will enable you to determine the necessity or otherwise of installing a water softening device at the new school.

Your obedient servant,

C. H. Attwood.
District Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir.

Re Indian Residential School, Brandon.

I beg to submit the following report in regard to the progress on this work as to date:

The brickwork was completed on Nov.20.

The roofing was finished today and the building is now entirely enclosed.

The interior tile partitions are now being erected.

Lathing is now being done and it is the intention to commence plastering next week.

The heating plant is being gradually extended throughout the building and heat is now turned on in portions of it.

The Septic Tank has been constructed and connected to the drains.

The water supply pipes have been laid from the well to Pumproom.

Yours Very Truly,

W.H. Shillinglaw

RE: Indian Residential School.

Dear Sir:

I received a quotation from the Star Electric Co. Ltd. for wiring and connecting five motors at the Indian School for the sum of $477.70. This price plus 10% would be the price I would charge the Department, viz: $525.47. This does not include any motors.

I took the matter up with Mr. Gow of the Water Power Department, and they say that they have no authority from the Department of Indian Affairs regarding this matter. And that I would have to take it up with you. If you cannot sanction this you had better wire the Department, as the Star Electric man is on the job. Also this should be done while the walls are open, that is it should be done before the plastering is done.

Kindly advise me on this matter at the earliest possible date in order that I can have the work proceeded with.

Kindly return the Star Electric letter for my file.

Yours truly,

J. H. SIMMONS.

Brandon, Dec. 10, 1929.

Mr. R. Gurney Orr.
Architect.
Dept' of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Indian Residential School, Brandon.

Re Power for pumps, etc.
There does not appear to be any provision made for this power in connection with the contract for the building.

I have taken the liberty of securing a price for the necessary wiring from the Contractor and am enclosing Mr. Simmons letter. The service will run from main switch in Engineer's room across and through Laundry to Pump room and to be in conduit, with separate service for large pump. I took this up with the City Electrician and he has approved of the layout.

I am referring this to you for approval or otherwise and if satisfactory to you I think it would be well to wire me your approval so that the conduit can be installed as soon as possible to permit of lathing.

I will get you some photos as soon as we get some sunlight of which we are not having much these days, today is heading for a blizzard.

Yours Very Truly,

[Signature]

Brandon, Dec. 14, 1929

Mr. R. Gurney Orr,
Architect,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Indian Residential School, Brandon.

Mr. Simmons was here today and the question of the cement base in rooms floored with terrazzo came up.

He is proposing to put in the straight base without cove as there is nothing definite in the specification in regard to it. He has asked me to write you in regard to this as to your wish in the matter. He informs me that it will cost six cents per lineal foot extra to run a cove base.

I have suggested to him and the terrazzo contractor that it would save considerable time in laying terrazzo if they put in the cove base and would be to the advantage of the floor layer if he did this himself but the suggestion to the terrazzo man did not bear fruit.

I expect they will commence on this floor about Thursday next and if you will let me know by return mail it will be in time.

There are now seven plasterers on the job and the top floor is partly first coated and some of it second coated. The heating is now on all through the building.

Yours Very Truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Re Indian Residential School, Brandon.

I am enclosing you certificate for Mr. Simmons showing the amount due at this date.

Re Progress on the Building.
Plastering.— The whole of the Ground, First and Second floors are finished brown coating ready for final coat. Some brown coating has been done in the Basement.

Terrazzo Floors.— The base coat is completed on First and Second floors ready for terrazzo finish and this base coat is now being laid on Ground floor. The material for surface was expected to be in Brandon today.

Re Classroom Platforms.
Dr. Doyle wishes to have these platforms omitted from the Classrooms and I have instructed Mr. Simmons to omit them which I trust will meet with your approval.

Yours Very Truly,

Jan. 11, 1938.

Dear Mr. Shillinglaw,-

The maps you were kind enough to send give a good idea of the appearance of the new Brandon School. I notice, however, that the contractors have omitted the stone belt course on the front which lies over the windows on the first floor. Will you please advise me how this came to be omitted.

Yours very truly,

R. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

W. H. Shillinglaw, Esq.,
Brandon, Man.
Brandon, Jan. 15, 1930.

Mr. R. Gurney Orr,
Architect,
Dept' of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of 11th re stone belt course.

This stone course was omitted from the approved stone setting drawings as furnished to the Contractor. You might look up the sett you have and verify this. This is the reason it was not provided and I suppose we should have drawn your attention to it when you were here, the wall was at Second floor level then.

The sand has at last arrived for terrazzo floors and they are now at work laying the finish surface. The plastering is now all ready for the finish coat and some of the small rooms are now being finished.

Mr. J. H. Simmons informs me he will be in Ottawa shortly and will take up some matters with you when there.

Yours Very Truly,

[Signature]

REPORT ON SOFT WATER SUPPLY FOR BRANDON INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL.

An analysis made by the National Testing Laboratories, Winnipeg, of a sample of the water supply for the new Industrial School at Brandon shows a total hardness of 341 parts per million or 23.87 grains of hardness per Imperial gallon. This analysis shows that while the water is good for drinking purposes it must be classified as very hard water. Mr. A. Blackie, President of the National Testing Laboratories, and also City Chemist of the City of Winnipeg states that this water corresponds very closely in total hardness to the water in use in Winnipeg prior to the completion of the Greater Winnipeg Water Aqueduct from Shoal Lake. It is also stated that it is not as hard as the present water supply in the City of Brandon.

The Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, has requested a recommendation as to the advisability of installing a water softener or constructing a rain water tank to supply soft water to the building. In view of the degree of hardness, 23.87 grains per gallon, shown by the analysis made of a sample of the water supply it would be desirable and advantageous to those entrusted with the

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director, Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ontario.
operation of the school to have available an adequate supply of soft water. Officials of the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa will necessarily have to decide whether or not the extra expenditure required to obtain an ample soft water supply is warranted. To assist them in making their decision there is outlined below what is involved in securing an adequate supply of soft water at the school and the cost of same.

The present water supply system of the Brandon School was designed for a daily requirement of 5,000 gallons, this amount including the water supply to the barns and staff residences. However, the anticipated daily requirements within the school building itself will approximate 4,000 gallons. It is further estimated that 75 percent of this amount, or 3,000 gallons, will be required for service connections in the basement of the building, the remaining 1,000 gallons being required for the floors above. The basement connections include the kitchens, laundry, children's showers and toilets, the boilers and hot water heaters and also the water supply to the barns. This basement water supply is a gravity system operating under a head of approximately 16 feet, the source of supply being a 12,000 gallon reservoir located 540 feet from the building and fed by springs. The water supply for the floors above the basement is furnished by a pressure tank system. This system consists of a 2 h.p. motor direct connected on the same shaft to a 1,000 gallons per hour Typhoon pump which is connected to a 1,200 gallon cylindrical tank. This pressure in this tank can be varied but ordinarily will operate between
40 and 80 pounds, automatic regulation being obtained by means of an automatic pressure regulator.

Soft water is preferable for use in the laundry, kitchens, baths, washrooms and boilers and these services alone will require about 2,000 gallons daily. This supply cannot be obtained by the construction of a rain water tank and depending upon the water collected from the roof of the school building. The total area covered by the building approximates 10,000 square feet, the average yearly rainfall at Brandon is 13 inches, so that the quantity of rainfall that could be collected yearly would not exceed 68,000 gallons, or less than 200 gallons per day.

Water softeners are all based upon the principle of removing the grains of hardness by forcing the water through a thick mineral bed and periodically regenerating the mineral bed by the addition of salt. The size of the plant and the cost depends upon the quantity of soft water required, the quantity of hardness to be removed and the frequency of regeneration. Manufacturers of water softeners will not guarantee satisfactory results, nor will they recommend their products unless the water is fed to the softener at a pressure of at least 25 pounds.

At the new Brandon School the services for which softened water is desired are supplied from the gravity supply system. This system operates under an approximate head of 16 feet or a pressure of about 6.5 pounds per square inch. The installation of a water softener under these conditions will not give satisfactory results and cannot be recommended. To install a water softener and obtain a pressure of at least 25 pounds on the feed to
the water softener as required by the manufacturers, it will be necessary to do away with the existing gravity system and connect the whole water supply to the building with the pressure tank system. This would involve changing some pipe connections between the pump, the pressure tank and the water supply pipes to the building. This could quite easily be done and would not be an expensive switch. It would also be necessary to lay a new line of 1" piping between the intake pipe in the pump room through the building to the south west corner of the same in order to complete the gravity system to the barns, since it is not proposed to soften this water.

As installed the pumping costs for domestic water supply in the school would be approximately 12 cents per day as it is only necessary to pump 1,000 gallons per day. If the whole system is changed to the pressure tank system it will be necessary to pump 4,000 gallons daily at a cost of about 48 cents per day. These costs are based on a power cost of 8 cents per kilowatt hour, the existing rate at Brandon.

Manufacturers Agents in Winnipeg were requested to submit proposals recommending the type of softener required and the cost of the same F.O.B. Brandon. Only one proposal has as yet been received, this being from the Ward-Love Pump Corporation of Rockford, Illinois, through their agents in Winnipeg, Cranes, Limited. They recommend the installation of their D30 - 42S Crane Warlo Water Softening Plant, the cost being $1,800.00 F.O.B. Brandon. This softener would require regenerating about every three days, each regeneration taking about 45 minutes.
during which interval the water supply to the school would be shut off. This inconvenience could, however, be overcome by installing their double unit for which no quotation was given. It would be possible by means of interconnecting piping and installation of valves to retain the gravity water supply system for maintaining a continuous water supply during the periods of regeneration.

The floor space occupied by the softener is 4'6" by 7' and the headroom required is 7'6". Delivery could be made in from two to four weeks. The cost of installing, changing over from the gravity to pressure tank system, together with the cost of the softener would amount to approximately $2,150.00. Installation can be made in the pump room of the school building.

In conclusion it might be pointed out that if soft water is required the only satisfactory method of procuring the same is by means of the installation of a water softening plant. This plant will not give satisfactory results if connected up with the present gravity system because of the low pressure. The whole water supply for the school building can readily be changed to the pressure tank system with but little expense and if this is done a satisfactory and adequate water softening plant can be installed for $2,150.00. The elimination of the gravity water supply system will increase the cost of pumping about 36 cents per day, which increase will be more than repaid by savings effected in the laundry and kitchen. The water softening plant could be installed at any time, now or after completion of the building, but in the case of the latter the cost would be slightly increased as the installation and changes in piping would necessitate some
redecorating.

Assistant District Chief Engineer.

Winnipeg, Manitoba,
January 22, 1930.
January 27, 1930.

Sir:

In further reference to your letter of December 17th last regarding the water supply at the new Indian school at Brandon, Manitoba, I enclose herewith a report received from our District Chief Engineer at Winnipeg with reference to the advisability of installing a water softener or constructing a rain water tank to supply soft water to the building.

You will note that the report recommends the installation of a water softening plant at an estimated cost of $2,150., it being calculated that the rainfall which would be collected would not be sufficient to provide a supply for the necessary service at the school.

I shall be glad to have your instructions in regard to this matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

Encl.

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Acting Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6256, File 576-5, part 4)
Jan. 31, 1930.

Dear Mr. Atwood,

I have today received a copy of Mr. Gow's report on the advisability of installing a water softener at the new Brandon School, and I would be obliged if you would advise me what you would think if the question of installing a softener was left in abeyance until after the school was in operation for a time in order to see if they really require a softener.

I would like if possible to use the gravity system as already planned and if it was found necessary to put the softener in at a later date I do not think there would be very much difference in the cost than if installed at the present time.

Yours very truly,

R. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

C. H. Atwood, Esq.,
Dominion Water Power Branch,
WINNIPEG, Man.

February 5th, 1920.

Dear Mr. Orr,

I have your letter of the 31st regarding Mr. Gow's report on the advisability of installing the water softener at the new Brandon school, and requesting my views as to the installation of the water softener at the present time.

According to the chemical analysis made, the water at the Brandon school is hard water. However, it is the same source of supply that has been used in the old Brandon school for a number of years, and unless your Department has in the past had complaints regarding the hardness of the water, I do not see why it should not be continued in the past. One of the main features of the water supply to the new school was the matter of supplying water to the laundry, kitchen, showers and toilets in the basement, or probably eighty percent of the total water requirements of the school, by a gravity feed system, thus eliminating a great expense in the cost of pumping to provide a pressure system.

While the gravity system should provide ample water to meet the requirements of the school and the equipment supplied in the basement of the school, the pressure on this gravity system is not sufficient to operate a water softener. When inquiries were made of the firms supplying water softeners and it was found that these could not be operated on the low pressure of the gravity system, Mr. Gow and myself in discussing this matter both agreed that the installation of a water softener might well be left in abeyance for a time in order to determine whether or not a softener was an actual necessity.

My own views in this regard are to continue the installation of the water system as originally planned and to omit the installation of the water softening equipment for the present. The increased cost of installing a softener at a later date would in any event be a small item and need not be considered at the moment.

Yours very truly,

C. H. Atwood,
District Chief Engineer.

R. Gurney Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
J. H. SIMMONS,
GENERAL CONTRACTOR,
WINNIPEG, MAN.
January 31st, 1930

Dear Sir,

Re Indian Residential School, Brandon.

I beg to submit the following report to this date re progress on this building.

Terrazzo Floors. These floors are completed on Ground, First and Second floors except for cleaning up. The Basement floor is now being laid and about one third finished.

Plastering. Auditorium is completed. The whole of the First Floor will be completed by Tuesday. Several of the small rooms on the remaining floors are finished. There is some trouble with condensation from the roof which, I hope, will clear up as the moisture gets out. This has prevented finishing the Second floor.

Yours Truly,

Feb. 20, 1930.

Sir,

I beg to refer to my letter of the 31st ultimo with reference to the water supply system at the new Brandon Indian Residential School. It has been decided to omit the installation of a water softening equipment for the present, in order to give the water system as originally planned a trial and see if it is possible to operate without the softener.

You will note that the installation of a softener makes it necessary to abandon the gravity system as at present installed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting, Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa.

This decision has been communicated to our District Chief Engineer at Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. R. Gurney Orr,
Architect,
Dep't of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Re Indian Residential School, Brandon.

I am enclosing you a list of Lighting Fixtures selected by Dr. Doyle and myself when in Winnipeg last month. These were provided for under the $700.00 item in the Specification and the numbers are from Northern Electric Catalogue.

You will note that all fixtures, lamps, etc., amount to $637.36 and an additional item of 19 extra plugs, $76.00 making a total of $713.36. The Contractor is covering the entire list for $700.00.

Dr. Doyle wished to have these plugs in certain rooms and as there were no outlets for them we arranged to have these plugs combined with switches on the same plate.

I trust this will be satisfactory to you and will have your approval.

I am not going over every day this month.

Yours Very Truly,
