WINNIPEG, MAN. March 12th, 1930.

R. Gunney Orr, Esq.,  
Architect,  
Dept. of Indian affairs,  
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

RE: Brandon Indian Residential School.

On page 59, Paragraph 12. of the Specifications, calls for "Best quality burlap shall be provided in all corridors, passages and stairways. Burlap shall be provided three feet high." This specification covers walls composed of studding, lath and plaster, with wood base. The present walls are tile and plaster with a cement base.

Would it not make an incomplete job to place burlap on the present walls? Would it not be better to paint the plastered walls in place of applying burlap.

I took this matter up with Mr. Shillinglaw, but he thought I might better take the matter up with you direct.

Awaiting your early reply.

Yours truly,

J. H. SIMMONS.

Per

March 15, 1930.

Dear Mr. Shillinglaw,

I am enclosing herewith a letter which I have received from Mr. Simmons with reference to burlap. It is not my intention that burlap shall be installed on the walls where we have used tile partitions, and it will therefore be satisfactory if the walls, corridors, etc., to the height of three feet are painted as suggested by Mr. Simmons. Will you please advise.

Yours very truly,

#2.

The bathroom is constantly very cold, and yet in subzero weather the snow melts on the roof above the bathroom, showing that the heat is escaping through the roof.

If the house does through another winter I think it is all that could be expected of it.

I had Mr. Simmons go over the house carefully yesterday, and he would be able to give you any further information in regard to its condition.

I am,

yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.
Indian Residential School

A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

APR 1 1930
PHONE 2835

Brandon, Man., March 26, 1930.

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Some time ago you requested me to give my opinion as to how long the Principal's residence here could be used without serious repairs being necessary, and I beg to submit my judgment in this matter.

The foundation, which is on the surface, has sunken in some places and thereby has placed the house very much out of shape. It also makes it necessary to bank the house well in the cold weather in order to keep things in the cellar from freezing.

The studs supporting the cribbing have rotted at the foot and in a number of places the cribbing is giving way, and the earth coming into the coal bin end passage.

The mainposts supporting the house are also decayed, so that the house is settled in some places seriously. There is a 2 and a ½ inch drop in the living room, and in the kitchen the floor drops 5 inches in 8 feet.

The cellar is always wet. Commencing about February a spring broke out in front of the furnace and has been running constantly since.

The furnace fire pot is cracked, but may do through another winter.

Throughout the house the hardness has gone out of the plaster. One can shove a screwdriver into it anywhere, and in many places it is only held up by the wall paper, and in one room strips of cotton were used over the cracks in the plaster before the last wall paper was put on. The pulverized plaster is constantly coming done around the burlap in both the living room and hall.

[Handwritten note:]
VERY POOR COPY
Brandon, April 4, 1930.

Mr. R. Gurney Orr,
Architect,
Dept' of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Re Indian Residential School, Brandon.

I beg to submit the following report on this work—

The contractor is now finishing up the usual final details, such as painting, cleaning up, etc.

Carpenter, except for fitting screens and small odds and ends is practically complete.
Heating, some small details to attend to.
Plumbing, ditto.
Electrical Work, complete except a few fixtures not arrived.
Painting, some wainscot yet to finish and the usual touching up.
Cleaning up, the whole of the floors have been scrubbed and only some details to clean up.
Now cleaning up outside and will do balance of grading as soon as frost is out.

Mr. Simmons has mentioned the question of taking the building over on completion but I have informed him that I had no instructions to do so. I presume you will take a run up for a final examination before this is done.

Yours Very Truly,

[Signature]

Will try and get you a decent photo as soon as possible.

[Handwritten note]

Architect,

Dear Sir,

Re Indian Residential School, Brandon.

The cold water pipe line through the Basement is shewing a tendency to sweat with the usual results.

I have taken the liberty of asking Yates, Neale & Co. to give me a quotation for covering this piping and am enclosing same. Of course nothing will be done unless approved by you. I would expect it to do so as cold water will be running through it to the stables as well as through the building supply.

I have also obtained a price for covering the large hot water tank in case you should think it desirable.

I expect to have the power line run shortly when we will be able to test the pumps.

April 10th, 1930.
Box 91.

Mr. H. H. Ward,
Deputy Minister of Labour,
Ottawa, Ont.

Gentlemen:

The latter part of December 1929 and the early part of this year 1930 I was working on the Brandon Indian School, Brandon, for Mr. L. Boaz, 478 St. Jean Baptiste, St. Boniface, Manitoba, plastering contractor. I have only received ($3.80) three dollars and eighty cents from him my first pay for Dec. 20th. Then for the next two (2) weeks I have never been paid as you will see by the account. Mr. Boaz ignores all letters and I cannot get in touch with him in any way, nor can the general contractor who has paid me all monies excepting for the two weeks for which I am sending account. This account he refuses to pay. I feel he is responsible for this as general contractor. Would you kindly advise me as to whom I should go as this is a Dominion Government job. Mr. Simmons address is:- 506 Confederation Life Bldg., Main St., Winnipeg, Man.

Thanking you for your attention. I remain

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) Morris Kennedy.
Ottawa,
April 22, 1930.

Dear Mr. Orr,

Enclosed herewith is a copy of a letter which has been received in the Department of Labour from Mr. Morris Kennedy of Toulon, Man., in which he refers to his employment as a plasterer's helper on the Brandon Indian School and states that he has not received payment in full for his work while employed by a subcontractor, Mr. L. Boaz of 478 St. Jean Baptiste, St. Boniface, Manitoba. Would you be good enough to have this matter brought to the attention of the general contractor in order that any amounts which may be owing to this workman shall be paid.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Gerald H. Brown,
Assistant Deputy Minister of Labour.

Encl.

R. Gurney Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., April 28th, 1930.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

It has been the custom at the Brandon Residential School in the recent years, to turn in one or both of the cars, pay the difference and secure the new model.

Remembering this I asked the Canadian Motors Ltd., to appraise these cars, and give me their report. I include herewith their statement. Whatever you decide to do in this connection this year will be appreciated.

I am,

yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.
Ottawa, May 7, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, with enclosure, with reference to the cars in use at the Brandon Indian Residential School. In reply I have to state that it is the general practice for the management to make replacement of cars, agricultural machinery, etc., from the per capita grant or other school earnings. At the present time, the school is not receiving a regular grant and your inquiry was properly addressed to the Department this year. As our funds are extremely low, I regret that authority for the trade-in cannot be granted. After the school is on per capita grant and farm receipts are good, it is hoped that it may be possible for you to make replacement, without reference to the Department. The enclosure is returned.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.
R. Gurney Orr Esq.,
Architect,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Orr:

The Brandon Indian Residential School has been completed since April 21st. My foreman turned the keys over to Dr. Doyle, but officially the building has not been taken over. In order to protect myself I had to renew the insurance again today. When will the building be taken over?

I forwarded to Mr. Shillinglaw some time ago the bills for extras and additional work, which I hope he has forwarded to you long before this date.

I am anxious to have the building taken over in order to cut out the extra expense of insurance.

Yours truly,

J. H. SIMMONS.

Per. [signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6256, File 576-5, part 4)
May 15, 1930.

Dear Mr. Simmons,

Replying to your letter of the 10th instant, with reference to the Brandon School I note that the building was completed on April 21st. I expected to be in Brandon before this, but owing to pressure of work here have been unable to make the trip. I have today written to Mr. Shillinglaw instructing him to issue final certificate on your contract on the 21st of May, which will be 30 days after date of completion. He has also been instructed to take over the building from you for the Department.

A telegram was sent you today advising that it will be satisfactory to apply your security cheque held in connection with the Brandon School on your tender for the Blue Quills School.

Yours very truly,

R. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

J. H. Simmons, Esq.,
506 Confederation Life Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.
May 15, 1930.

Sir,

I have been advised by Mr. Simons that his contract for the Brandon School was completed on April 21st. It will therefore be in order for you to issue a final certificate on Mr. Simons' contract on May 21st. The amount of this certificate should be made up of the balance due, including any extra work and the 10% which has been held back. I would also ask you to please accept the building from Mr. Simons for the Department.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting, Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. H. Shillinglaw, Esq.,
BRANDON, Man.
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Gentlemen:

We are very sorry to have to notify you that under date of March 15th we found it necessary to put a Lien against the Industrial School here, in connection with Sub-Contract on the Plaster. May add that this is no reflection on Mr. Simmons, the Contractor, and we are extremely sorry to have to do so, but we could not get anywhere with Mr. Boux, The Plasterer, and to protect ourselves we found it necessary to put this lien on.

We are simply drawing this to your attention in case you might not be acquainted with the fact when making final settlement. We are,

Yours truly,

A. R. McDiarmid Ltd.

The Ottawa Drama League.

The League is an unincorporated association of nearly 1200. It was organized in 1914 by about 100 members, it obtained the use of the Victoria Museum for its productions. The lecture hall where the lectures have been given, the lecture hall was destroyed by fire, and its present location is the House of Commons, in consequence of which it has not been available for other purposes. The league presented four productions in 1915-16 at the Russell Theatre. There are no facilities for members to live beyond the pay of the league.

Handicaps on the League's activities.

The lecture hall in the Russell Theatre is not large enough to accommodate performances seating accommodation for more than 300 people.

May 13th, 1930.

Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs
Dept. Public Works,
Winnipeg, Man., Ottawa.

Dear Sirs:

In November, December of 1929 and January 1930, we supplied sand, gravel and teaming to Leon Boux, (478 St. Jean Baptiste, St. Boniface) Sub-contractor at Indian School, Brandon, on instructions from J.H. Simmons, contractor.

The understanding was that we were to keep the accounts separate and that Mr. Boux would settle his direct.

To-date we have never seen this gentleman and our drafts on him have been ignored and returned.

We have also drawn on Mr. Simmons for the amount of this account, as he is the contractor and it was on his orders that goods and work were supplied to Mr. Boux, but to date we have had no response and our drafts are returned.

We would thank you to withhold sufficient funds on this account until we have received settlement of our account per enclosed statement.

We are forwarding copy of this letter to Mr. J.H. Simmons.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Re Morris Kennedy wage claim.

W. H. Shillinglaw

PUBLIC ARCHIVES OF CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
Brandon, May 20, 1930.

Mr. R. Gurney Orr,
Architect,
Dept' of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Re Indian Residential School, Brandon.

In accordance with the instructions of May 13th from the Department of Indian Affairs, I am enclosing the Final Estimate on this contract together with all accounts for Extras and Additional work done by Mr. Simmons.

I understand from Mr. Simmons that he discussed with you certain items when in Ottawa and which are included in these statements, such as Pumping Water, Front Entrance Stairs and some other details.

Referring to Summary No.1:

Item No.1 - This work was required to be done on account of the soil conditions under portions of the outer wall footings, to loose material and soft soil under some of the columns and portions of the interior wall footings.

No.2 - On the removal of old concrete floors, old drains, etc., some portions required refilling to grade. It was considered advisable to use gravel for this refilling.

No.8 - I instructed the Contractor to have these hung to permit of putting up and removing transom storm sash. It will also allow of ventilation if they do not wish to open windows.

No.9 - Mr. Simmons claims that this was not provided for in the change from wood to concrete and steel construction. Cement floors in rooms in main portion of the building have been painted for which no charge is made.

No.10 - The plans shew 6 in. C.I. columns which were changed to 6 in. H columns on approved steel plans. These columns did not look good in the Diningroom and I had him encase them in plaster forming them round.

No.11 - On account the possible filling in behind the Boiler and Pumproom wall to form a road I had the waterproofing carried up 8 ft. above grade.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6256, File 576-5, part 4)
Referring to Summary No.2.

Item No.3 - This was done to ascertain if old tank was in a condition for future use but it was leaking and later abandoned for a new tank.

No.4 These swings had to be removed for disposal of earth from excavation and it was also desired to erect them in a new location.

No.7 - No mention of light or power is made in specification or plans for Projection Room and the Contractor claims he is entitled to an extra for this.

The above explanatory notes cover items which were not otherwise provided for.

I have checked these items as closely as possible and the work and materials have been done and provided. I have included the amounts in the Certificate but have not certified to the individual items. I have informed Mr. Simmons that the extras are subject to your criticism of any items you may consider are not correct and on which you may require further information. Should you require further explanation or information of any items please let me know and I will give it to you.

Yours Very Truly,

[Signature]

J. H. SIMMONS  
GENERAL CONTRACTOR  
506 Confederation Life Building  
WINNIPEG, MAN. May 27th, 1930

W. H. Shillinglaw, Esq.,  
Inspector, Indian School,  
108 Strand Block,  
Brandon, Man.

Dear Sir:-

RE: Accounts of A. R. McDiarmid Ltd. and Lane & Co. -vs- L. Boux.

I am in receipt of yours of the 26th inst. RE; the above mentioned parties. In reply may state as follows:-

L. Boux, plastering contractor, Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man. has no monies due him, but has been over paid the sum of $1,577.01 on his contract. This over payment is accounted for by me having to pay all plasterers and plasterers laborers wages direct to the men from December 21st, 1929 to the completion of the work.

It was necessary for me to take over the payment of the plasterers direct or they would have quit the work on account of not having received their wages from L. Boux. If I had advanced any money to Boux to pay wages, it is doubtful if the men would have received same.

As there is no money due L. Boux, who owes Messrs. A. R. McDiarmid Ltd. $962.60 and Messrs. Lane & Co. $260.80 I do not see how I can be held liable for these accounts.

However I am satisfied to have the Department, when making final settlement, deduct the amount of these two accounts and hold same under protest, until such time that a proper settlement has been arrived at with these parties.

RE: C. M. Kennedy, Laborer -vs- L. Boux.

Further to our conversation when in Brandon, I have paid C. M. Kennedy, Laborer the sum of $38.25 in settlement of his claim against L. Boux. Enclosed find his receipt.

Trusting that this will clear the way in order to have my Final estimate put through immediately,

Yours very truly,

S/L.

[Signature]

PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., June 18, 1930.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

The new school building here is very fine in every part, and will be a great delight to all who have to use it.

Some members of the staff have arrived and are busy getting things in shape. Some equipment also has come in.

The wash-basins in the boys and girls wash-rooms have been used to some extent by the working men, and it is the consensus of opinion on the part of the members of the staff and others that there should be a splash-board placed the full length of the rows of basins, and between the two rows so that the dirty water would run back into the basins rather than splash down on the piping etc. below the basins. There is also need of soap dishes to accommodate these basins. I have therefore asked McDowell & Co. of this city to quote a price on this equipment, and I inclose herewith their statement.

The soap dishes would be bolted at the peak of this splash board, the iron extending about an inch above the peak, and the one pair of bolts would accommodate the two soap-dishes for the pairs of bowles.

If the installing of these splash-boards meets with your approval, we will instruct this Firm to put them in at once.

Awaiting your reply,

I am, yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sirs:

Re Brandon Industrial School

As no doubt you are aware, we have filed a lien for the sum of $962.50 against the above mentioned property, covering materials supplied to L. Boux, who was a sub-contractor to Mr. J.H. Simmons for plastering, etc.

We would advise that this lien has not as yet been satisfied by either Mr. Boux or Mr. Simmons, both of whom are responsible. We would appreciate your advice as to how you are handling this matter, whether you are remitting us direct or whether you are making arrangements with Mr. Simmons to take care of this amount; as we are anxious to have this matter cleaned up at as early a date as possible and we shall be glad to have your advice as to what course you are taking. We shall be pleased to furnish you or Mr. Simmons with a discharge of the Mechanic's lien immediately on receipt of remittance.

Yours very truly,

A.R. McDIARMID LTD.

MANUFACTURERS OF MAPLE LEAF BRAND MILLWORK
Ottawa, June 20, 1930.

Dear Mr. Orr,

Under date of April 22nd Mr. Brown, Assistant Deputy Minister of Labour, wrote you enclosing a copy of a letter which had been received in this Department from Mr. Morris Kennedy of Toulon, Manitoba, in which he refers to his employment as a plasterer's helper on the Brandon Indian School and states that he has not received payment in full for his work while employed by the sub-contractor, Mr. L. Boax of 478 St. Jean Baptiste, St. Boniface, Manitoba. Mr. Brown's letter requested that this matter be brought to the attention of the general contractor in order that any amounts which might be owing to the workmen might be paid.

To-day the Department is in receipt of a further letter from Mr. Kennedy stating that his claim has not yet been adjusted nor has he had any word from the Department of Indian Affairs.

I would therefore be glad to know how the matter stands at this time.

Yours truly,

H. H. Ward,
Deputy Minister of Labour.

R. Gurney Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Reverend Sir:

Pursuant to Mr. Ferrier's arrangements, when at the Brandon Indian Residential School, for a flagpole, I have now to inform you that Mr. Orr believes it should remain in its present position. Please arrange with Mr. Cuff, of Christie's Limited, to have the pole lengthened 25 ft. Then, you will please properly install it in cement, seeing that no unnecessary expense is incurred. Christie's account, in duplicate, for the pole complete and for one flag, which was purchased, should be forwarded to Ottawa for payment.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.
Memorandum:

When I was at Brandon, there were three matters that were brought to my attention, which should be referred to you.

There was no flagpole or suitable place to fly a flag for the opening, so I got Christies Limited, of Brandon, to temporarily place a 40 ft. steel pole in front of the building. If the pole remains in its present position, it would have to be lengthened at least 20 or 25 ft. It might be better to install it on the building. What do you advise?

In order to protect the root house from slipping any farther and opening up any larger cracks, I understand filling should be placed at the back of the building, up to the top of the cement, which is waterproof. Would you please give instructions in this connection, indicating what type of fill would pack the best.

The large stock barn is in need of early attention. The interior surfaces of the cement wall, which is approximately 10 ft. high, are rapidly deteriorating, with the result that chunks are falling down or can be picked off with the fingers. Mr. Shillinglaw states that it is very difficult to get good gravel for cement work at Brandon and he blames the present condition on the hear frost, which adheres about an inch thick all winter long on this interior surface. It was suggested that an air space be left and a cheap brick be used for a new surface, but this would be very expensive. Something should be done without delay, for the cement has been eaten away to a depth of 3 inches in places.

[Signature]

Sir,

It has been reported that the rear of the new Brandon School requires filling in order to protect the root house. Will you kindly arrange to have whatever filling you think necessary done. As much of the work as possible should be performed by the school staff and equipment.

It has also been reported that the interior concrete walls of the stock barn are in need of repair. In order to remedy this condition the bad spots of the concrete should be thoroughly cleaned out and filled with cement. All of the interior walls should be given a coat of cement plaster and a coat of waterproofing. If it is found necessary at a later date arrangements can be made to cover the inside of the concrete walls in order to provide an air space.

Brandon, Man. June 18, 1930.

Mr. R. Gurney Off.
Architect.
Dep't of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I am mailing you today three prints unmounted of the exterior of the School. The photographer did not take enough plates with him to get interiors but I will get them again. The weather has not been good here for outside photography on account of wind, rain, etc., until this week which accounts for the delay in getting them.

We had about 5 in. of rain here last week and it left the ground around the School in a pretty soft condition and muddy and does the same after every rain with the result that a large amount of mud is carried into the building.

On account of this Dr. Doyle and I thought it better to lay some gravel where necessary and doing some necessary grading to better conditions around the building until final decision is made as to the grounds.

The old roothouse is showing some tendency to move downhill and to prevent any mishap we are doing some extra filling at the rear of the school to hold the bank in place. I trust the above will meet with your approval.

Yours Very Truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa
Mr. A.F. Mackenzie,
Acting Asst., Dep't and Secretary,
Dep't of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Re Indian Residential School, Brandon.

Replying to your letter of Aug. 2.

I have given the necessary instructions re filling to protect roothouse. Dr. Doyle appears to think his own staff will be able to do this work in spare time.

Re Stock Barn.

I have examined these walls and they are in a very poor condition. On two sides and west end there is very little of the surface which is not more or less scaled off, in a good many places to a depth of two to three inches and an occasional place to at least 4 inches. Where this scaling has taken place, and this will cover about 75 per cent of the wall surface, the surface is in poor condition to receive a coat of cement and I am doubtfull if it would stay on any length of time. It would be useless to attempt to fill up the deep places. I attempted to get a photo of this wall with poor success but the enclosed one will give you some idea of its appearance. The whole wall in this photo is scaled and at points marked X is 2 to 4 in. deep. I am going to have another examination of it and try to form some idea of the cost of the work and will advise you further before doing anything.

I trust this will be satisfactory to you.

Yours Very Truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6256, File 576-5, part 4)
Brandon, Man. Aug. 14, 1930.

Mr. A.F. Mackenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dept' of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Re Barn,-Indian Residential School, Brandon.

Referring to your letter of Aug. 2 and my reply of Aug. 7 regarding Barn.

I have gone over this wall again with the plasterer I would employ to do the work. He considers he can make a reasonably good job of this cement plastering but will not undertake to put on a greater thickness than one inch of cement mortar as it will not hold. I agree with this. This will leave the wall uneven.

The proposal is to clean off all loose concrete and thoroughly brush and wash the surface then apply a brush coat of neat cement to form a bond with old concrete. This to be followed with a coating of cement mortar composed of one part Portland cement to two parts sand and waterproofed with Pudlo Waterproofing Powder mixed with the mortar.

Practically the whole of the north and west walls and approximately onehalf of the south wall will require plastering, or approximately 210 sq.yds. I do not think that this can be done for less than $1.50 per sq.yd.and be at all satisfactory. I am not at all satisfied that the results will be what I would call permanent on account of the old concrete providing a poor base for bond. On good sound concrete I would not be afraid of good results.

This will probably answer your purpose until something more permanent is decided on.

I thought it better to let you have this information before going to any expense and if you will advise of your decision I can have the work done at once.

Yours Very Truly,

W.H. Shillinglaw

Phone 2755

Aug 30th Repairing Cement Walls in Cattle Barns.

Material 4-1/2 118.90
Labour 180.00

Certified correct and that price is fair and reasonable.

Brandon Sep 20 1930

Invoice attached
Mr. A.F. Mackenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dept' of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Re Indian Residential School, Brandon.

I am enclosing account of F.W. Hurst for repairing and cementing wall of Barn as per your letter of August 23, 1930.

This work was very carefully done and I hope it will stand up and give you good results considering the nature of the concrete we had to work on. I had the unplastered portions of the wall cleaned off and given a brush coat of neat cement and Pudlo hoping to keep the condensation from penetrating the surface of the walls.

We had a small amount of the Pudlo left over and this I turned over to Dr. Doyle to use in any other patching he may wish to do in the other barns.

I am also enclosing my account for the items of work shewn on it and which I trust you will find satisfactory.

As this will close my connection with this work I wish to express my appreciation to your Department for the many courtesies received during the carrying on of the building.

Yours Very Truly,

[Signature]

Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Nov. 29, 1930

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Some necessary repairs had to be made on the furnace a few days ago and while these were being done the mechanic discovered that the fire box was so badly cracked that it might fall to pieces at any time. Another man was out this morning with the man who came before and they both declare that it is unsafe to go on with the furnace as it is. A new fire pot will cost $5 in Winnipeg. I am now writing for authority to have this repair made. I had hoped it would do over winter but these men are very emphatic that the risk of continuing is very great.

Awaiting your reply,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle,
Ottawa, December 5, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, regarding the installing of a new fire pot in the furnace at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of the purchase and installation of a new fire pot. All expense in connection with this work should be kept as low as possible, and, when completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

The Department would like to have a report from you setting forth the reason for the fire box becoming damaged in such a relatively short period after the boiler was installed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal, Indian Res. School,
Brandon, Man.

Brandon, Man., Dec. 3, 1930

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

There are no stops on the doors in this new building to keep the door-knob from hitting the wall. In some cases the wall is becoming quite dented.

The stop required is one that screws into the door. The metal one with a rubber tip which would be suitable comes at $4.00 a Dozen. And we would need 7 Dozen to supply all the doors which require them. Shall we purchase these and put them on?

Awaiting your reply,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

Indian Residential School

R. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., April 29th, 1931

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Yesterday Mr. Ames, formerly of Ames & Baker of this City, called to enquire if we desired to disposed of the Windmill and Derrick and I told him I would write you immediately.

The windmill is not in use now and I cannot see that any emergency might arise which would make it practicable to use it. In very windy weather when the wind is from the north, especially, the mill continues to turn a good deal and the derrick is leaning out of plumb to the south. Mr. Ames says the most he could offer is $35.00.

It seems to me as it is deteriorating in value it would be best to dispose of it. If this meets with your approval I would be glad if you could see fit to add this amount to the $175.00 you have set apart to be spent this year on the fixing up of the grounds around the School.

I might say that we have our teams busy whenever possible doing some necessary grading at the west side of the School and at the back.

Awaiting your reply,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.
Ottawa, May 5, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, requesting authority to dispose of the windmill and derrick at the Brandon Indian Residential School. It is noted that this equipment is of no further use and that you have received an offer of $35 for same.

The Department will approve of you arranging for the sale of the windmill and derrick, and you may utilize the proceeds in fixing up the grounds around the school building. It will not be necessary, in accounting for the expenditure which you were authorized to incur in the fixing up of the grounds, to account for the proceeds received from the sale of the windmill and derrick.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal, Indian Res. School,
Birtle, Man.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6256, File 576-5, part 4)
Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., May 12th, 1931

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

After ten months of occupation of this splendid new School and doing our best to care for food stuffs we find that some sort of a cooling system or frigidaire equipment is necessary for the store room for food. This room as you know, while insulated with four inches of cork has no means of either ventilation or keeping the air cool. Placing a tub of ice in the room has practically no effect, as it can only be placed near the floor and the air does not circulate.

When Dr. Scott was here last autumn he asked me to get estimates on the cost of frigidaire equipment and submit the same to the Department. And that he would urge that this matter receive attention immediately after the opening of the new fiscal year. I have secured tenders from the Imperial Motors of this City and also of Mitchell's Hardware Limited and enclose them herewith.

Trusting that it will be possible to give us help in this connection,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

Enc.
Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., May 12th, 1931

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

When Dr. Scott made his visit to this institution last Fall he looked over the Principal's residence and while doubtful if anything could be done this year on account of the prospective scarcity of money he asked me to have a sketch made of the house I thought would be suitable and forward the same to the Department.

I talked this matter over with the architect Mr. Shillinglaw, and we looked over a great number of plans and he made a sketch which I enclose herewith. This house only has six rooms, apart from the sunroom, sleeping porch and a small sewing room and is nothing like the size of our present house but I think will meet the requirements splendidly.

When the Department decides to go ahead with this building we will have other suggestions to make in regard to this or a similar plan.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

Enc.
Ottawa, May 19, 1931.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, enclosing a sketch of a house that is desired as a principal's residence at the Brandon Indian Residential School. This will be placed on file and will be given consideration when funds are available for the building.

I have also your letter of the 12th instant, with reference to frigidaire equipment for the food stores at the Brandon School. The appropriation for improvements at Indian schools was so seriously cut, that the Department will have to postpone consideration until it is determined whether or not a supplementary estimate is to be secured.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., June 21, 1931

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

When the old school building was being wrecked about two years ago the bell was broken in getting it down and since opening the new school we have tried to get along without the use of a big bell but we find it very unsatisfactory. I am, therefore, herewith applying for a big bell to be placed somewhere on the building.

I have consulted Christie's as to the size of bell usually sold for purposes of this kind and find that bell #24 on page 58 of their Catalogue #40 is recommended by them. And that is approximately the size of our old bell. The price is $48.50. There would be some additional expense for material to build a suitable tower in which to house it. But I think the work on this would be done by our mechanic with the assistance of the boys.

The advisability of placing the bell in front of the school just within the oval, which we contemplate laying out will also be considered. The cost of placing it there would be a little greater as a cement platform should be made on which to erect the frame for it.

Awaiting your reply and direction,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.
Ottawa, June 30, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, requesting that a bell be supplied for the use of the Brandon Indian Residential School and giving an estimate of the cost.

In reply I have to regret that we have no funds this year to provide for the cost of this equipment and will, therefore, be unable to authorize the purchase of a bell.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., 19—

Pipes of the fire engine pump and the pipes connected with the air pressure tank pump and are now using most of the water for the School from the well. Even at that we are without water in the upstairs of the Principal's residence part of the time.

This condition is in keeping with the water supply reported all over the country and we are hoping that abundant rains will before long relieve this scarcity.

Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Aug. 6th, 1931

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

The reservoir at the spring which gives us our water supply for the houses, school and barns demands serious attention. Both the south and the west walls in the west chamber have cracked down the centre and are bulging in. The west wall has come in about five inches at the centre. I had the Brandon Heating & Plumbing Co. bring out a man yesterday to examine it and it is very evident that something should be done at once.

These men advise and I think their advice is sound, that the only thing that can be done is to dig the earth away from these two walls, and put in a re-enforced concrete wall on the outside. That would mean two walls approximately 10 X 10 X 9 and 10 inches thick. They place the approximate cost of this work at $125.00. We would use the gravel from our own pit, which I think is satisfactory for work of this kind.

We think this work should be done as soon as possible for if a heavy rainfall should come within the next few weeks and the water should fill up our tank and therefore the gravel field surrounding the tank, it would be impossible to do this work satisfactorily. If on the other hand rain does not come and the tank therefore stands nearly empty a good deal of the time, it will cave in all the sooner.

The water supply from this source is not yet adequate to supply the school and other buildings, as I stated in a previous letter we have made a connection between the
Ottawa, August 11, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, reporting on the condition of the reservoir which supplies water for the houses, school and barns at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that you may incur an expenditure not exceeding approximately $125 in having the work mentioned by you carried out in placing this reservoir in good condition. The school staff should give any assistance they can in carrying out the work.

After the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of any materials required and for the labour.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

Indian Residential School

Rev. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., August 18th, 1931

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

At the recommendation of the Drs. both locally and those who took the clinic here I am starting a record system in regard to the weight, height and general health of the pupils. We did not have scales on which to weigh them and as I was anxious to commence this record as they returned from holidays I secured suitable scales the other day through the Johnson's Hardware. This was a $24.00 scale which I purchased for $16.00, with a Government guarantee. I would have waited and consulted you in this matter but the condition of some of the pupils returning made me desirous of getting this work under way at once. Unless I am otherwise instructed by you I will have this item charged to the Capital account.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle,
Ottawa, August 24, 1931.

Reverend Sir:

It is noted, from your letter of the 18th instant, that, on the recommendation of the medical officers, you recently purchased a set of scales to assist you in recording the weight, height and general health of the pupils. It is also noted that you were able to secure these scales at a cost of $16, and payment for same will be made upon receipt of a properly certified account, in duplicate.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

BRIDGEBURG, ONT.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sirs:-

We enclose you herewith a statement covering your purchases from August 1929 to date with credits according to our records here. As you will see on the statement there appears to be a considerable balance due us. Will you kindly compare this with your records and let us know if there is any additional information you require. Hoping you can straighten this matter out for us, we are

Yours truly,

JW/EC.
Encls.

WADE & SONS LIMITED.
Ottawa, February 27th., 1932.

Sirs,-

Referring to your letter of the 12th instant, enclosing a statement covering the purchases made by the Brandon Indian Residential School from August 1929 to date with credits according to your records, I beg to state that all the accounts submitted to the Department by the Principal have been paid, and it is assumed that the balance due you is payable by the institution. Your statement has been sent to the Rev. J.A. Doyle, the Principal, with request to look into the matter with a view to arriving at a settlement.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. MacKenzie
Secretary.

Messrs. Wade & Sons Limited,
Brandon, Man.
Ottawa, February 27th., 1932.

Rev. Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith a statement received from Messrs. Wade & Sons Limited, of Brandon, covering your purchases from August 1929 to date with credits according to their records. You will see on the statement there appears to be a considerable balance due them, and as all the accounts submitted to the Department have been paid, it is assumed that the balance is properly chargeable to the School. Will you kindly get in touch with this firm with a view to arriving at a settlement of their claim.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. MacKenzie
Secretary.

Rev. J.A. Doyle,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

Ottawa, May 11, 1932.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, enclosing voucher No. 169 in favour of the Johnson Hardware Co. Ltd., Brandon, for $2.54. It is noted that this account covers various small items supplied from time to time for the use of the Brandon Indian Residential School.

It is considered that accounts of this nature should be paid from per capita allowance or other receipts of the school. Our funds are extremely limited, and it will only be possible to consider payment for supplies required for repairs or any extensive replacement of equipment, and in this connection I would request that, before incurring any expenditure, you write, giving details and the cost involved, and obtain the necessary authority. The account referred to is returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

July 16th, 1932

Brandon, Man.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I beg to make requisition for the permission to purchase the following in Hardware and Paint:

We have found it necessary to make considerable changes in the interior of our pig and sheep barn. We no longer have room for the sheep in the stable and are making provision for them in the barn above the stable. We are also reducing the number of pens for hogs and providing additional space for cattle. We do not require any new lumber for this but a quantity of nails and some paint. We are also fixing up what was to be a gymnasium above the shop for handicraft, fretwork and athletic games. It had been re-arranged when part of the old building was torn down for sleeping quarters. We also need some athletic equipment. The list is as follows:

50 Window lights for barn 10x12
20 " " " " " shop 10x8
100 " " " " " shop 10x12
2 kegs 4 inch spikes
1 keg 2½ inch nails
1 keg 2 inch nails
1 keg Cedar fence staples
4 pairs strap hinges, 4 inch
10 pairs strap hinges, 1½ inches
10 gal. red barn paint
1 gal. green paint
2 gal. grey paint for verandah floor Principal's residence

Athletic equipment:
1 eight lb. shot. Price $0.25
1 five lb. shot. $0.25
1 Official basket ball $7.50

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

Ottawa, July 20, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, requesting permission to purchase the hardware and paint mentioned in your letter in carrying out necessary repairs to the interior of the pig and sheep barn at the Brandon Indian Residential School, and also in fixing up a gymnasium for handicraft and athletic games.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you incurring an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $200 in the purchase of the hardware and paint, etc. You should forward an itemized account, in triplicate. This you should certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department for payment.

Regarding the athletic equipment, the Department does not provide or pay for 5 or 5 pound shot, and if you require this equipment you should pay for same from per capita allowances or other receipts of the school.

A basketball will be ordered here and sent to you.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., August 9, 1932.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have to write you in regard to the Recreation Room on the boys side of the Residential School here. The walls on the West and South sides and part of the East side were finished with metal lath and plaster. The wall on the North side and part of the East side was plastered right on the brick. Where the metal lath was used, the plaster has crumbled off to a great extent and to some extent the metal lath has given way and the room is therefore in a bad and unsightly condition.

I had Mr. E. C. Higgins looking at it the other day, and he suggests that the only satisfactory way of repairing it will be to plaster up the broken places and line the room where the metal lath is used with v-joint to the height of a little over four feet.

We also find that the plaster on this room also on the bathroom, lavatory, and lockerroom and the small entrance to the dining room are getting discolored and cannot be washed to get good satisfaction. We believe that when the walls are repaired these rooms should be painted so that they can be washed satisfactorily. Mr. Higgins estimates the cost of this work as follows: Repairing plaster $16.00; Lining with v-joint $45.00; Painting $225.00. Total $286.00.

His Excellency, the Lieutenant Governor is making an official visit to Brandon on October 7. A visit to our School is included in his programme and I would like to have this repair work done before his visit takes place. I am enclosing Mr. Higgins letter.

Awaiting your direction and authority, I am

Yours respectfully,

JAD/IHR.

It is noted that this account includes $39.00 for labour installing supplies costing $26.70. Please let me know the length of time the electrician was engaged and the rate per hour. Brandon, Man., Oct. 15th, 1932

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your letter of October 6, #133-0-5, re voucher #206, for $35.90 for repairs to the range in the school kitchen. Voucher in favor of Neale & Yates. And in reply I wish to say that the stove was so badly burned out in the fire box that it was impossible to go on without these repairs. There was no opportunity of making requisition of the Department as the work simply had to be done to keep the stove in use.

I might further add that when the stove was purchased following expert advice a one-fire-place stove was secured. With the amount of cooking that has to be done in a school of this size one fire has to be kept at almost full force a great deal of the time to accomplish what is required and this stove perhaps for this reason has not stood up satisfactorily. I asked Mr. Yates sometime ago to ascertain from the Foundry Company if some change could be made in the stove that another fire place could be inserted. But have not yet received his reply.

When information comes or we get any new light on the matter I will communicate with you in regard to it.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.
Indian Residential School

J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Oct. 12, 1932

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of September 28th #133-0-5, re voucher #200 for $55.70 in favor of the Boyd Electric Company for material supplied and work done.

I have taken this matter up with the Electric Company and have gone over the details in regard to material and work. They have charged $1.10 an hour for their electrician and 85 cents an hour for their helper. Twenty hours work was done.

Since the new building was erected I have tried to have my mechanic take care of this work as far as possible and it appears that some things had been neglected and other things improperly done. We therefore, had to have a checking up throughout all the buildings, putting in switches and other appliances which had gone out of order. I am quite convinced that all the work was necessary and some of it long overdue.

I wish also to assure you that we are anxious to cooperate with the Department in the keeping of expense for repairs as low as possible, consistent with what will be economy in the long run and efficiency and safety in connection especially with the electrical department.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Oct. 13th 1932

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of Oct. 6th, #133-0-5, re Windmill I beg to say that I cannot ascertain the length of time this mill has been in use but I would think seven or eight years or possibly more. It was used for pumping water to the tank in the old school. And I believe gave good satisfaction. It has been out of use since building operations commenced but as far as I can see is in good condition.

This windmill will not be needed in the future as an electrical pump has been installed and it is not now connected with our system.

The highest estimate of value that I has secured from a local dealer is $35.00. They claim it will cost around $25.00 to $50.00 to disassemble and reassemble it on other premises. Mr. McPherson came in this morning, looked it over and volunteered an offer of $50.00. My judgment would be that he's offering full value.

I might further add that the south side of the tower is settling into the ground, so that the top of the mill is between three and four feet of plumb, ultimately the mill would have to be removed for safety.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6256, File 576-5, part 4)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
Ottawa, November 7, 1932.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 27th ultimo, regarding trouble you are having with cockroaches in the pantry and kitchen at the Brandon Indian Residential School, I beg to say that Bulletin No. 112 of the Department of Agriculture suggests the following:

"Cockroaches may be readily controlled by means of sodium fluoride. This material should be lightly dusted in places frequented by the roaches such as about sinks, baseboards, cupboards, hot water pipes, etc. The sodium fluoride adheres to the legs and antennae of the roaches, and in cleansing themselves the insects are poisoned by it. Sodium fluoride retains its effectiveness and may be left undisturbed as long as convenient or until the cockroaches have completely disappeared. As this chemical is somewhat poisonous reasonable precautions should be taken to prevent children or domestic pets from gaining access to it.

"Two other materials which form the basis of many proprietary roach powders and which often are recommended, are pyrethrum and borax. Pyrethrum insect powder is less effective than sodium fluoride, it loses its effectiveness quickly on exposure to air, and has to be used in larger quantity. Borax, also, is less satisfactory than sodium fluoride. It is easily obtainable, however, and mixed with equal parts of powdered sweet chocolate, is a fairly effective remedy. Superheated steam and fumigation with hydrocyanic acid gas are also effective in destroying cockroaches. In the case of hydrocyanic acid gas fumigation, however, our experiments indicate that a concentration of gas produced by using 1½ lbs. of calcium cyanide per 1,000 cubic feet, although effective against nymphs and adults, does not destroy the eggs."

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Nov. 9th, 32

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In sizing up the difficulty we have had in the past with boys and girls snatching little opportunities to meet each other we find that if a gate were placed across the hall at the foot of the girl's stairs preventing them from going down the hall, which passes by both dining rooms, four store rooms, the kitchen, two pantries, the laundry and reaches to the furnace room, that it would solve a great deal of our difficulty. I have enquired in a number of places where a suitable gate of this kind could be secured at a reasonable price and found the most satisfactory results in every way, could be secured by having Mr. A.L. Campbell make one out of galvanized iron pipe, and the heavy woven wire, such as is used for gates in banks, burglar proof gates, etc.

To install this gate a plank has to be fastened into the solid brick wall to hang it onto and a suitable stop arranged on the frame of the first door going into the staff dining room. The cost of this is $18.50. We will supply the varnish for the plank and woodwork required at the other end of the gate, we will also put on the lock and clasp necessary.

I beg therefore to make requisition to have this gate installed at this price.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle
Ottawa, November 16, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, requesting authority to incur an expenditure in the installing of a gate across the hall at the foot of the girls' stairs in the Brandon Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that it is necessary to conserve our funds, which are extremely limited, and I regret, therefore, that we will be unable to provide the expenditure required. If you consider it urgent that a gate be installed, it is thought that the expenditure could be met from per capita allowances or other receipts of the school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

Vote 201
for one to read. When the house was constructed no beam filling was done. The cornice boards have evidently never fitted properly and have so shrunk or warped so that there is an opening from about half an inch to an inch and a half around the whole building. Then there is nothing but lath and plaster covering the upstairs rooms. This is ample explanation for the abnormal coldness of the upstairs, notwithstanding the fact that the house has an oversized furnace and consumes a great deal of coal.

I had Mr. Wade of Messrs. Wade & Sons, look at it the other day and he suggests that a coat of insulax be spread between the joists over the whole attic surface. This would cost without the labor a little over a Hundred Dollars. It seems too bad to put this much expense on the building if it was only to be used for a year or so. For a temporary job he further suggested that fine shavings mixed with sawdust and slack lime might be used to give temporary relief. The cost of this would not be more than Fifteen or Twenty Dollars and we could do that work ourselves. The objection to this method is that the filling used is so inflammable that it makes it undesirable but there is only one chimney going up through the roof and it is of good brick construction and very little danger would exist.

Awaiting your advice and direction in this matter,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle,
Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Nov. 18th, '32

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I wish to write you in regard to the Principal's residence here. Had times been normal it was definitely planned as reported to me both by Doctor Schütz and the late Mr. Ferrier that a new house should be built before this. We have, therefore, not asked for any repairs except paint for the verandah, which was in bad shape. This work has been done and improves the outside appearance very much. There are some other repairs which will have to be done in the near future, unless it should become possible to put up a new building.

When we had to open up the sewer pipe last spring we found the sills of the building rotten almost entirely away. The building has settled so much that there is five inches difference in the level of the floor in the width of the living room. In some parts it is settling in the centre of the building and others at the walls. The plaster in most of the house is quite dead, and is only being held up by the repeated coats of paper which it has had. The pulverized plaster keeps shifting down from behind the burlap on the stairway and some of the rooms are seriously in need of decorating.

Our worst difficulty, however, is that the house is dreadfully cold. In the wintertime the bathroom is seldom warm enough to take a bath without either turning off the other registers or having additional heat supplied. We have just discovered the main cause of this. Following a severe storm the house warmed up and the snow which had drifted into the attic began to melt. This led us to investigate and on going through the man-hole we found the attic space almost light enough on a bright day.
Ottawa, November 26, 1932.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, relative to the condition of the Principal's residence at the Brandon Indian Residential School. In this connection I have to say that the Department has no funds to undertake any extensive work on this building at the present time. It is noted that you had Messrs. Wade & Sons inspect the building and that a temporary job can be carried out by using fine shavings mixed with sawdust and slacked lime, which would give temporary relief. The Department will approve of you incurring an expenditure not exceeding $20 in having this work carried out. It is noted that there would be little danger from fire in using the above mentioned filling, as there is a good brick chimney. After the work has been completed, please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure.

It is not possible to state at the present time when funds can be provided for the erection of a new residence. Early next summer, you might forward a recommendation as to the repairs you consider absolutely necessary to make the building fairly comfortable, in the event of funds not being available for the erection of a new residence.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith voucher #222 in favor of Yates, Neale & Company for $35.28.

It is a great regret to us that this stove is giving so much trouble. I have taken the matter up repeatedly with Mr. Yates and this time they have increased the weight of these castings to about three times the thickness. And it is hoped that they will last many times as long as the lighter weight castings. They are cast in Brandon and do not cost any more than those Mr. Yates has been getting in from the factory.

As I said in a previous letter I had him take up with the factory the matter of the possibility of having another fire place put in this range but he finds this cannot be done without the whole thing being sent back to the factory. I can assure you we will exercise every precaution possible to save a recurrence of this expenditure.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I beg to submit herewith a report on the Brandon Indian Residential School, inspected between February 15th and 17th, 1933.

The classroom work is carried on in three rooms. The junior room is in charge of Miss Lulu Ironstar. Miss Ironstar is a qualified teacher and is a treaty Indian belonging to the Assiniboine Agency in Saskatchewan. Grades are arranged as follows:

Grade I - 32
" II - 19

Miss Ironstar thoroughly understands the Indian children. She has a pleasing manner and an interesting way of presenting the work. The pupils are bright, quick in responding to questions, and I believe are making good progress. All the children were well dressed and clean. The classroom was tidy and fairly well aired.

The blackboard supplied for this room does not meet the requirements. There is wall space for another thirty feet and this should be supplied in order that the little ones may become accustomed to the blackboard work. It would also result in a saving in connection with scribblers and notebooks.

The intermediate grades are supervised by Mr. E. McEwen, and are arranged as follows:

Grade III - 20
" IV - 18
" V - 18
" VI - 12

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
BRANDON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

Seating accommodation is provided for fifty pupils and as these grades are operated on the half day system, there is plenty of room for all. The children are well along in their grades and I consider Mr. McEwen is doing excellent work.

In this classroom there is only 15 ft. of blackboard, which is certainly insufficient for such a large number of pupils. There is plenty of wall space, both at the side and back, where additional blackboard could be installed. The room was tidy in appearance and well aired.

The senior room is in charge of Miss D. E. Werthenbach who is an honour graduate in Arts of the Alberta University. The grades are as follows:

| Grade | VII | IX | X | XI |
|-------|-----|----|---|----|
|       | 7   | 11 | 8 | 2  |

In addition to the above, there are three pupils, who were late in entering school and who will be discharged this coming spring, that are receiving special instruction. The pupils in this room attend class all day and are only requested to assist at other work before and after school and on Saturdays. The pupils all appeared well along in their grades and, according to the test examinations set by the teacher, they have obtained splendid marks, and I would judge they are on a par with white children in the City schools. These young people were all well dressed and one could not help but admire the care exercised by each in their personal appearance. As is the case in the other rooms.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6256, File 576-5, part 4)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
BRANDON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

other rooms, more blackboard space is badly required.

There are at present two girls taking Grade XII. These children are obliged to attend the Collegiate in Brandon in order to get this knowledge. There are also four boys attending the Technical School in Brandon. The work at this school covers automobile mechanics and gas welding, and is spread over a period of three years. The boys are obtaining splendid marks in their test examinations and are greatly pleased with the opportunity which is theirs of having this privilege.

The laundry is in charge of Miss L. Barager, who appears well qualified to carry on the work. The room is large and well equipped with all necessary machinery. This is a heavy department, but the sample of the work seen was well done, and the girls appeared to enjoy the work.

Miss H. Reeder is matron in charge of the kitchen. She is a splendid cook and the girls receive instruction in all lines of cooking, also in the baking of bread and the making of butter. The meals served on one of the days during my visit were as follows:

Breakfast: Porridge, Sugar, Bread, Dripping, Tea

In addition to the above, the senior boys received potatoes.

Dinner: Meat, Potatoes, Gravy, Usually one other vegetable, Bread, Water to drink.

The children receive all the vegetables and bread they desire. If no meat is supplied, they are given vegetables and a desert consisting of fruit, rice, or milk puddings.
BRANDON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

Supper: Soup, Potatoes, Bread or Buns, Tea, and dessert (dried apricots)

In future, the children will receive butter or lard with this meal.

The refrigerator room, I understand, was built to accommodate a frigidaire, but this have never been installed. Ice is used, but as there is no ventilation in the room, the air becomes musty and laden with all the various odors, so that it is necessary each day to leave the door open, and as a result, the room is little better than a pantry as it is impossible to keep it cool with ice. The installation of a frigidaire system would be a great help in the care and saving of food.

Miss M. Cranna is the boys' matron and is also in charge of the dispensary and infirmary. The boys' dormitories were all well aired, the beds neatly made, and the bedding clean. The boys are provided with nightgowns. The toilets were clean and in good working order.

In the boys' side of the infirmary I found three or four small boys in bed. These children have been running a slight temperature for some time and were receiving special food and care in order to better their health condition. There were no girls sick, and I found the infirmary tidy and the beds neatly made.

The girls' matron is Miss R. Harland, and I found the girls' dormitories well aired and clean. The toilets were in good working order. The girls are also provided with nightgowns.

The dormitories used for the small boys and girls are situated on the third floor, and accommodate fourteen beds each. The switches for the lights are placed on the inside of the dormitory walls. This should be
should be changed to the outside, and would entail very little work. I would also recommend that the top panel of the doors leading to these dormitories be taken out and replaced with glass. The children in both dormitories are the smallest in the school and when the doors are closed and locked, as they are at night, it is difficult to hear them if anyone is needed in case of sickness. I find that the staff member in charge on this floor sleeps across the hall from the dormitory, and at night their door is also kept closed, making it more difficult for the sound to carry.

Mrs. G. Mason is the matron in charge at this institution, and is a woman well qualified for the position. Good discipline is maintained throughout the building, and Mrs. Mason is very much respected by all the boys and girls.

Fire drill was observed during my inspection, and the children were able to get out in about 2½ minutes. There are no fire bells in the basement, and I found it impossible to hear the fire alarm either in the kitchen or laundry. This difficulty might be overcome by placing an extra large bell on the first floor, but I am of the opinion that one bell should be placed in the basement of the school. The fire equipment was all in good condition, and none of the doors leading on to the fire escapes were locked.

There is a shortage of water, and very little fire protection could be relied on from this source. At the present time the water supply is so low at certain periods that it is impossible for the Principal to obtain water in the bathroom at his own home. If this condition does not improve it may be necessary, in the near future, to build another reservoir and tap a larger spring located some little distance away.
BRANDON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

little distance from the old source.

There is a large root cellar at the back of the school building, which is well supplied with potatoes and all other vegetables. I understand that almost 2,000 bushels of potatoes were harvested last fall.

The barns and outbuildings are in fair repair, but badly in need of paint.

The Principal has obtained a very fine herd of Shorthorn cattle, and the school is supplied with a fair amount of milk. Sheep and hogs are also kept. Most of the meat required for the school is supplied from the surplus stock of cattle, sheep and hogs, and is killed on the farm.

There is considerable work yet to be done in fixing up the grounds surrounding the new building. On both sides of the building at the rear, a great improvement would be made if a floor of cement could be laid. In fact, I think something of this nature will be required as the water from the hill back of the school rushes down over this portion of ground, washing it away, and I have no doubt will eventually work into the foundation and cause serious trouble. The attached sketch will more clearly show the requirements in this connection.

This school is well managed; the discipline is good, and the children are receiving an excellent education and training which should fit them well for their work in later life. I find the Principal, Dr. J. A. Doyle, greatly interested in his work, and undoubtedly he has the situation well in hand.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Ottawa, February 28, 1933.

Rev. Sir:

Mr. Inspector Hamilton, in a report on his recent inspection of the Brandon Indian Residential School, has drawn attention to several requirements. He refers to the need of more blackboard facilities in each of the classrooms, and, in this connection, you are being written in a separate communication.

He also refers to the dormitories used by the small boys and girls, located on the third floor. He states that the switches for the lights are placed on the inside of the dormitory walls, and that these should be changed to the outside, entailing very little work and expenditure. He also recommends that the top panel of the doors leading to these dormitories be taken out and replaced with glass. The children in both these dormitories are the smallest in the school, and when the doors are closed and locked, as they are at night, it is difficult to hear them if anyone is needed in case of sickness. He states that the staff members in charge sleep across the hall from the dormitories and, at night, their doors are also kept closed, making it more difficult for any sound to carry. It is considered that the Inspector's recommendation regarding the placing of the switches on the outside of the dormitory walls and the replacing of the top panel in the doors with glass should be carried out. This work should not involve any large expenditure, and we would request that you arrange to have it carried out at an early date, keeping all costs as low as possible. When same has been completed, you should forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of any material and for the labour. No doubt, certain of the work could be performed by the school staff without cost to the Department.

The Inspector also draws attention to the fire alarm bells, and recommends that a bell be installed in the basement. You may arrange to have this done when the work mentioned above is being carried out. You should see that a bell of a suitable type is installed.

The Inspector also recommends that a floor of cement be laid on both sides of the boiler room and laundry in the rear of the school building, in order to drain off the water and protect the foundation of the building. I should be pleased if you would furnish an estimate of the cost of the material and labour in the laying of a cement floor as indicated on the sketch enclosed, which was submitted by the Inspector. Our funds for the next fiscal year will be extremely limited, and unless the expenditure for the purpose would not be large, we could not authorize same.

I may add that the Inspector's report is most favourable on the management, discipline and services of the staff and work generally at this school.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.
Ottawa, February 28, 1933.

Sir:

I have your 209-11 of the 21st instant, reporting on your inspection of the Brandon Indian Residential School.

The Department is pleased to note that the work being carried out by the teachers in the classrooms is satisfactory and that the pupils are making progress in their studies. The question of providing more blackboard facilities will receive attention, and the Principal will be written to forward the dimensions of the blackboard material required for each of the classrooms.

I regret that we will have no funds to provide for the installation of a Frigidaire system or for the installing of cement flooring on both sides at the rear of the school building.

The Principal is being written regarding the installing of a fire bell in the basement.

The Department is also pleased to note that this school is well managed; that the discipline is good and that the children are receiving an excellent education and training, and that the Principal and staff are greatly interested in the work.

I wish to thank you for your very full report on the work and general conditions at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Hamilton, Esq.,
Director of Indian Agencies,
Indian Office,
Winnipeg, Man.

Brandon, Man., March 6th, 1933

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of February 28th #133-0-5, for which I thank you.

I have written concerning Blackboards in a separate letter. I have also arranged for the change to be made in the light switches in the small dormitories on the third floor. There is not a bell procurable in Brandon suitable for a fire bell to be placed in the basement, but one will be secured as early as possible.

Within a few days I will send forward an estimated cost for material and labor which will be required in laying a cement floor as indicated in your letter and accompanying sketch. We will certainly appreciate it exceedingly if this improvement can be made.

May I convey to you my very sincere thanks for the last paragraph of your letter. I have a splendid staff, each one I feel is deeply interested in the work they are doing and a word of commendation such as you have given stimulates greatly the impulse to achieve the best results.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man.,

Mr. Higgins is very strongly of the opinion that it is urgent for the well-being of the foundation of this part of the school that at least some of this cement work be put in and especially that the wall referred to be constructed. For the welfare of the building the east side is the most urgent but for the inconvenience from mud the west side is more urgent. We will certainly appreciate it very much if this work can be done.
