Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

March 29th, 33
Brandon, Man.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of February 28, #133-045, in regard to cement floor being placed on either side of the boiler and laundry rooms at the rear of the building. The most favorable estimate I can secure is from Mr. Higgins, who finds the cost of material and labor to be as follows:

1000 sacks cement----------$900.00
150 yds. gravel-----------75.00
Labor in mixing & laying cement--------450.00
Total---------------------$1325.00

This includes a cement wall from the rear corner of the school on the east side to extend 75 feet east, curving a little to the south. This is absolutely necessary to keep the parapetis bank at the rear from washing and working down over the court at this side of the school. If this wall is not put in the earth will soon be washed and worked away from the foundation of the root house, which is very close to the northeast corner of the school. If this wall were put in separately it would cost approximately $150. Without this wall it is impossible to keep the water in the spring intact and also when we have heavy rainfall from washing in around the foundation.

In the above estimate we would do all the excavating and the teaming of the gravel, but would need to hire help for loading the gravel. Our older boys are practically all in high school work and are in school for the full day and have to give a good deal of attention to their studies out of school hours. And the farm work makes very urgent demands upon the time of all the boys we have available.
Ottawa, April 4, 1933.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, giving an estimate of the cost of installing a cement floor on either side of the boiler and laundry rooms at the rear of the Brandon Indian Residential School building.

In reply I regret that, as our Appropriation for the fiscal year beginning the first instant has been so considerably reduced, there will be no funds to provide the expenditure required in having the cement floor installed. Would it not overcome, to a large extent, the present conditions if crushed stone or cinders were laid on both sides of the boiler and laundry rooms? It is thought that either of these materials could be obtained at small expense and, if spread where required and rolled down, would prevent the earth from being washed and worked away from the foundation. If either of these materials would be satisfactory, the cost of same and placing where required would have to be met by the school authorities. I shall be pleased to hear from you regarding the matter.

I may add that, for the present fiscal year, a small Appropriation only has been provided for urgent repairs, etc., at our Indian residential schools.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.
walls were put in, however, the crushed stone or cinders would be a great help to the situation.

The crushed stone can be secured from the city at $4.00 per square yard. But I think the cinders, which can be secured from the C.P.R. at seventy-five cents per square yard would serve this situation equally as well. It would take about 170 sq.yds. to make a proper job.

The walls would cost about $150 each. It would also be necessary to put a cement curb at each of the two doors, as the door sills are at least nine inches below the level to which the cinders should be raised. This would cost another $25.00. Making a total cost for the walls and curbs of $325.00.

It would be impossible with our greatly reduced income to meet this expenditure out of our school funds. If, however, you can find it possible to arrange to put in the cement part of the work, we will endeavor to do the necessary excavating and secure and instal the cinders.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Ward,
Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., April 7th, 1933

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of April 4, #133-0-5, concerning cement floor for courts on either side of the boiler and laundry rooms has just come in. We are naturally quite disappointed that this work cannot be done in the near future. Now that the frost is coming out of the ground and the water soaking down from the hill at the rear these spaces are in a terrible mess with mud.

The trouble is not with the earth being washed and worked away from the foundation but the opposite. The school is set back into a curve in the hill and from the back of the building the hill rises with a steep slant to about seventeen feet above the normal level at the sides of the school. With this precipitous hill curving on either side toward the front of the building when a heavy rain falls or the snow is melting in the spring the water carries the earth down towards the building instead away from it, and the water soaks in about the foundation. This, of course, will become a serious menace to the building if allowed to continue.

The only relief for this condition is to have walls built from the rear corners of the school in both directions for about seventy-five feet. And thus, prevent the water and earth from washing down over these spaces and soaking in about the foundation. Mr. Higgins, the contractor, thought that a wall on the east side would be sufficient, if the cement floor was laid on the west side with a deep gutter constructed at the foot of the hill and with sufficient slope to this floor to shed the water readily away from the building.

You can thus see that without these walls there would be very little value in putting in crushed stone orinders. If the
May 9, 1935.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Ottawa, May 19, 1933.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, enclosing a voucher in favour of Yates, Neale & Company for $15.69 covering repairs to laundry boiler at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

In connection with the payment of future accounts for expenditure at this school, I have to refer you to the enclosed memorandum dated March 16, last, regarding the new financial procedure and encumbrance system. I would refer you to paragraphs two and three, from which you will observe that no expenditure must be incurred, for which this Department will be called upon to pay, until the necessary authority has been granted. You should, therefore, before undertaking any repairs, alterations, etc., report the matter to the Department, giving full details as to the cost of material and labour, and receive authority before incurring any expenditure. It is necessary, under our new financial system, that an encumbrance be obtained before any expenditure is authorized. I would request that you be guided regarding all expenditure in accordance with the enclosed memorandum.

For your information, I may add that there is only approximately the sum of $300 available in our Appropriation for the current fiscal year for repairs or work of any other nature at the Brandon Residential School. Our Appropriation has been so greatly reduced this year that it will be necessary for the school to pay the cost of replacements and repairs of a minor nature from per capita allowance or other receipts of the school. The account of Yates, Neale & Company referred to above, is returned herewith, as it is considered that the repairs made to the laundry boiler and stove, being in the nature of replacement, should be paid by the school.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

Brandon, Man., May 27th, 1933

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of May 19, #133-0-5, and I wish to thank you for your definite information as to the amount that is available for repairs for this school for the current fiscal year. This amount will not be at all adequate to meet the repairs that ought to be done but we will govern our requests so that we will not exceed this amount and will improvise for other repairs as necessity demands and a number of things of course will have to stand over until funds are available.

I am now making request for permission to send bills in favor of the Brandon Heating and Plumbing for the following items:

1. Leak occurred in the hot water pipes running through the ceiling just over the girls study room, we had to have the plumber at once to open up the plaster, breaking through the metal lath in order to locate the leak and repair the pipe, this will cost approximately $9.00.

2. During the scarcity of water in the wintertime we were without water supply in the hot water system in the Principal's residence for some days, when the water did come the pipes were stopped up with the accumulation of the formation that had been gathering for many years, a roaring noise warned us of danger of explosion, we had to call the plumber in this emergency and the cost of this is also $9.00.

3. The jacket heaters in the school have never been satisfactory. We have had to abandon their use and keep a fire in one of the furnaces to maintain our supply of hot water in the building. It is therefore, necessary to have a valve or valves installed to prevent the steam from going through the pipes of the whole building during the hot weather. The cost of this
Ottawa, May 30, 1933.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th instant, referring to departmental letter dated the 19th instant, in which you were informed as to the amount available in our Appropriation for the current fiscal year for repairs, etc., at the Brandon Indian Residential School, and requesting permission to forward account in favour of Brandon Heating and Plumbing for three items mentioned by you.

In reply I have to say it is noted that the three accounts referred to total approximately $25. Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, December 4th, 1933.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, enclosing account for $64.80, covering the cost of books secured for the four Indian boys attending Technical School.

No authority was given for this purchase and it is noted from the account that the Encyclopaedias cost $5.50 each. Would it not have been possible for the boys to get along with only one copy of each book? These could be used jointly. Our appropriation is so limited that every possible effort must be made to reduce expenditures.

I am doubtful if payment of the account can be made but further consideration will be given to the matter when your reply is received.

I might, also, point out that you should have forwarded a requisition in order that the books could have been ordered from the Government Stationery Office if the Department wished to supply them.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie.
Secretary.

Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., December 11, 1933

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of December 4th., No. 133-0-5, and I have noted carefully its contents and regret that I did not send in for permission to purchase the books for the technical boys but simply followed the precedent of both last year and 1931. I find in looking over the correspondence, that under date of September 30, 1931, I made requisition for books at that time required for first year students in the Technical School and under date of October 6th., 1931, file 133-0-1, I received your reply authorizing me to arrange for the purchase of these books and forward the account to the Department. Taking this as a precedent I did the same thing the next year and again this year.

Two years ago I approached the Principal, Mr. Austin, of the Technical School, in regard to having one copy of Dykes Encyclopedia for the three boys but he stated then, and repeated the same thing in conversation today, that it is a regulation of the School that each student must have one of these books. It is in constant use in their class room work and each boy is required to have one in front of him in connection with some of their classes. The one book of course will last for the three years and then should be well enough preserved to be of service when the boy goes into practical garage or machine shop work.

Trusting that the above explanation is satisfactory and that you can see fit to pay this account as financing with us is becoming increasingly difficult.

I am

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Serious trouble has developed with the high pressure boiler which heats the water for the laundry. We had an expert out two days ago and he finds that the tubes are all in a very serious condition and will have to be replaced. The cost, he estimates, will be ninety-two dollars. The tubes are leaking so badly that it is almost impossible to get the water heated for washing. I would appreciate it very much if you could send an immediate answer giving us authority to have this work done.

The expert tells us that in his judgment it is the hardness of the water that has caused these tubes to be in a condition requiring replacing so soon.

Awaiting your word,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Davis

Paint, etc.:

The barns especially and all the out-buildings require painting, for which about 65 gallons of red and white paint will be necessary.

The boys' and girls' study rooms and the girls' playroom, bath and toilet rooms are badly in need of paint. It is also very desirable that the assembly hall, which also has to be used for group games, should be painted with a brown or other suitable color about seven feet high on the three walls. This will require about 6 gallons of brown and 3 gallons of cream.

The bungalow just east of the school is badly in need of decorating and should have the following colors in Muresco following Benjamin Moore's color chart:-

| Color | Quantity |
|-------|----------|
| No. 5 | 5 lbs.   |
| 12    | 15 lbs.  |
| 8     | 5 lbs.   |
| 20    | 10 lbs.  |

This house and the one at the gate will require 2 gallons of inside gloss white paint and 3/4 gallon first coat paint. The bungalow veranda should be screened in as Mr. Wood has two small children which they desire to be kept outside as much as possible. This would require 1 reel, 40" wide, 14 x 14 mesh, screen wire cloth, black. The front room of the house at the gate is badly in need of wallpaper.

We have deferred making any request for re-decorating in the Principal's home as the building of a new house has been under consideration and if there is some prospect of this going forward within a year or two it will no doubt be advisable to undertake decorating. In some of the rooms the plaster itself is only held by the paper and just how long it will last is quite doubtful.

In two other letters I wish to refer to fencing and other matters.

Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., March 13, 1934.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Attention: Mr. J. D. Sutherland.

The enclosed letters outline some of our immediate needs. Other items you have in the list you made last fall and I will review them just briefly.

Garage: There has been no change in this building since last fall but the late spring is when we have noticed the widening of the cracks the most seriously. I do not think there is any immediate danger of the roof falling in.

Residence: It is most difficult to know what to suggest and I will be guided entirely by the prospects of having a new house within a reasonable time. When I came here five years ago, Mr. Russell Ferrier was very definite in his statement that a new house would be built inside of two years. Altered conditions, of course, have made this impossible.

Water Supply: For a few weeks in the winter practically no water reached the bathroom in our house but it returned with a strong flow or fairly so earlier this year than last and if we have more precipitation during the next few years this difficulty may be obviated.

Cold Room: I still think it most urgent that we should have some kind of refrigeration in connection with our kitchen and dining room.
Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., March 13, 1934.

Cement Courts: With the spring thaw the freshet is on now and the earth from the hills is washing down and covering up a good deal of the cinders around the outside of these courts that we put in last year. It certainly would relieve us greatly if the necessary walls could be built and the courts put in. When Inspector Hamilton visited us last we observed that the front part of the root house on the west side was continuing to move away from the rest of the building, i.e., the crack is decidedly increased and he thinks it will also be necessary to put a wall about ten feet nearer the root house than the one already proposed.

Assembly Hall: In another letter I have included paint to cover the space of a wide wainscoting for three sides of this building. We, of course, would very much like to have a pulpit, suitable curtains for the platform and drapes for the windows. These, not only for appearance, but we believe they would also improve the acoustics of this auditorium.

Water Softener: The water, as you know, is extremely hard and I find we are paying out a good deal of money for the necessary material to soften the water in order to have the washing done satisfactorily and I sincerely hope that we can soon have a water softener installed.

Hen House: On account of the serious infection of T.B. in the old hen houses we have not deemed it advisable to use them since we deserted them nearly three years ago. We have been improvising accommodation for a few hens around the other buildings but this is not satisfactory and we cannot keep a sufficient number

Ottawa, April 13, 1934.

Reverend Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, in further reference to your request for fencing material at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

Provision has been made in our Appropriation for the year 1934-35 for rebuilding the retaining wall at the rear of the Brandon School and also for some repairs to the Principal's residence. No provision has been made for the fencing material requested in your recent letters. At the present time, the Department is not in a position to authorize the expenditure that would be required for the fencing. You might, however, write again about the first of September, and the matter will then receive further consideration.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Residential School,

Ottawa, April 30, 1934.

Reverend Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letters of the 12th and 13th ultimo, with reference to certain repairs which you consider are required at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

As you have been previously informed, provision has been made in our Appropriation for the current year for rebuilding the retaining wall and also for repairs to the Principal's residence. Our total Appropriation has not been increased and, consequently, the Department has not sufficient funds to enable us to authorize all the expenditures mentioned in your letters.

It is expected that arrangements will be made at an early date for rebuilding the retaining wall and repairing the Principal's residence. In addition, the sum of $200 is available in our Appropriation for minor repairs at the Brandon Residential School. During the current fiscal year, you may forward accounts to an amount not exceeding $200. Any expenditure over and above this amount, for replacements or repairs of a minor nature at the Brandon School, will have to be paid from the per capita allowance or other receipts.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKensie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

Brandon, Man., April 21, 1934.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

May I refer to our letter of March 12th in which we made requisition for some hardware and other supplies necessary for the buildings at this school.

We appreciate very much the fact as referred to in your letter of April 13th, 133-0-9, that the retaining walls to the east and west of the furnace and laundry rooms will be built. Might I suggest that as Inspector Hamilton expects to be here soon, he be asked to consult builders here with whom he is very well acquainted in order to obtain the best possible price for the doing of this work in a satisfactory manner.

I would also suggest that this apply to the Principal's residence. It is exceedingly difficult on account of the precarious condition of the plaster to know just what decorating it is safe to undertake.

In regard to hardware and electrical supplies, we are in urgent need of some of these and as I have to go to Winnipeg on May 3rd in connection with other matters I would like at that time to secure the wholesale price on what we will be allowed to purchase.

Awaiting your reply,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

August 15, 1934

Memorandum

The Honourable The Superintendent General,

With reference to the Principal's residence at the Brandon Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man., I beg to say that $1,000.00 is provided in this year's estimates for repairs to the residence.

At our request on May 23rd you furnished the names of two contractors in Brandon from whom prices might be obtained for the repairs, and on May 27th the Reverend Mr. Boyle, Principal, was asked to consult these contractors and have them submit an offer for the work required. No reply has been received from the Reverend Principal, and no further action has been taken. Before authorizing any of the repairs it is necessary that we have this information in order to ascertain the nature of the work required, and the cost of same.

There are no funds available to erect a new residence either in the Vote for Indian Education or under the Public Works Construction Act.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., August 23, 1934.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of August 20, No. 133-0-5, re repairs to buildings has just come in and in reply, beg to say that after receiving your letter of May 29 I got in touch with the contractors mentioned as early as I could. Mr. Frank C. Lissaman came over in a few days and took particulars in regard to the work. Mr. Jones was out of town but returned in a couple of weeks. He also came over, took measurements and specifications. Both men promised to send estimates in the near future. I did not receive answer from either of them so early in July I went to see Mr. Lissaman and urged him to give me his tender. This he did just as I was leaving for a trip to the East. I could not find Mr. Jones and since returning learn that he has been out of the city most of the summer. He returned to Brandon last night and I telephoned him this morning and he has promised to have his tender ready in a few days. As soon as it is available I will send them both forward.

It is exceedingly difficult to suggest any repairs at the residence without having the whole house decorated, broken plaster patched, the woodwork painted and the floor, in places, jacked up and new posts put in. It is settling very badly in the centre and in some places the sills are almost entirely rotted away. If there is any prospect of a new house within a reasonable time it would be unwise to expend much money on the present building.

I will, however, secure estimates on what we regard as urgent and submit them at an early date.

Brandon, Man., August 31, 1934.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Referring again to your letter of August 20, No. 133-0-5, and mine of August 28, I beg to enclose herewith tender from Moore Bros. for interior decorating of the residence and rubber roofing for the veranda.

Our local Member of Parliament, Mr. Beaubier, suggested this firm as reliable and thorough in their work.

Other repairs are needed but we think it better to leave them over for the time being. The railing around the veranda on the top is so rotted that it cannot stand much longer. In the kitchen part of the house the sills have rotted so badly that the walls are settling but the large soft water tank which is under the kitchen floor has not settled. Therefore, the centre of the floor bulges up quite seriously. In the main part of the house the walls have not settled but the centre has so that there is five inches difference in the level of the floor from one corner of the den to the other. As I stated in a previous letter the lime has entirely gone out of the plaster and it continues to sift down from behind the burlap in the den and hall and stairway. This could only be remedied by re-plastering these rooms. The paper is all that holds the plaster in its place throughout the rest of the house. For these reasons we have decided to ask only for the re-decorating in the interior.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

JAD/W

Brandon, Man. Sept. 6, 1934.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

The water situation here is becoming quite serious. Since the last week in July it has been running short. We have been cutting down in the use of it in every possible way and shutting it off entirely during the night. For the past three weeks we have had none in the bathroom at our residence and none in the hot water tap in the kitchen. That means that the water never rises above three feet in the reservoir in the hill and repeatedly it ceases to flow altogether. The recent rain, which was less than an inch, has had no effect on it whatever. In previous years the reservoir filled up during the night at this time of year and the lowest flow did not come till after Christmas or in February. If the same decline in flow takes place this year we will be entirely without water before very long.

Awaiting your advice and direction in this matter,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle
WINNIPEG, MAN., September 15th, 1924.

I have just returned from the Brandon Indian Residential School and wish to report that some action must be taken at once in connection with the water supply. For the past month or six weeks, the school has been operating with insufficient water and the supply is becoming less and less. This is the first time in the history of the school that any shortage has occurred, although last winter, during the real severe weather, the supply barely met the demand. I think it would be a big mistake to attempt entering the winter without making some further provision to supply the school with water. There is another spring which at present has a good flow, but the expense in connecting up will entail several hundreds of dollars.

I would recommend that Mr. D. B. Gow, of the Dominion Water Power Branch, be instructed to visit the school and submit his recommendation and an estimate of the cost.

This is an urgent matter and I trust it will receive the Department's immediate attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Sept. 27, 1934.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to our water supply at this school, I beg to say that the situation has grown considerably worse since I wrote you last. The water stands in the reservoir at about fifteen inches. After being shut off it will come up to about two feet but when the largest amounts are being used it empties the reservoir.

In previous years the lowest water has been during late January and February, it standing about four feet lower than at this time of year. This, no doubt, is account of the depth of frost either at the source of the spring or some place where it comes through the ground to our supply. We, therefore, feel quite certain that unless we have an abnormal amount of moisture this fall together with an unusually mild winter we will be without water when winter sets in.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

PUBLIC ARCHIVES OF CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
Sir,

I have your letter of October 12th with reference to the difficulty with the water supply system at the Brandon Indian Residential School and instructing that an inspection be made and a report forwarded as to what is required to provide an adequate water supply system. In accordance with your instructions, the writer accompanied by Mr. J.T. Rose, visited this school yesterday and made an examination of the situation.

I wish to draw your attention to the following paragraph from the report submitted under date of September 29, 1929, by the writer, then Assistant District Chief Engineer, and relating to the proposed water supply installation for this school:

"For the present it is proposed to make use of the present source of supply, namely the reservoir constructed in 1928. However, there is a second spring located higher up on the plateau back of the school and about one-half mile distant. It is claimed that there is a larger flowage from this spring than from the utilized one and if the necessity arises this spring can be used to feed the main reservoir by pipeline."

The writer at that time had some doubts as to the adequacy of the existing source of water supply, but the fact that the water supply was then in existence, and furthermore that it has provided a fairly adequate water supply for five years fully justifies the recommendations made at that time.

The prevailing dry cycle of years has affected the water supply from springs throughout the entire Province and there is no certainty that conditions will not become more serious. In 1931 it was noted that the source of water supply at the Brandon School was showing decreased volume and during the winter of 1932-33 there were times when the pressure was insufficient to furnish a continuous supply of water to the residences. Conditions were becoming more serious during the winter of 1933-34 and during the past summer and the present autumn, the water supply has been inadequate for the school's needs. Some of the residences are without water supply at all. There is grave danger that during the coming winter the water supply to the school itself will completely fail.

The second spring referred to in the above paragraph in the 1929 report, has completely failed and provides no present source of additional water supply. There is, however, a

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau,
Ottawa, Ontario.
flowing spring that emerges from the gravel strata about 1800 feet from the school. This spring still shows a substantial flow probably in excess of the full requirements of the school. It has not shown any material reduction in volume during the present summer and autumn, but no one can definitely say for how long this source of supply will last if the dry cycle continues. It is, however, a source of supply to augment the present supply and it is the only possible source of additional supply. At this spring the water trickles out from the gravel strata into a morass overgrown with willows and trampled by cattle seeking drinking water. It emerges from this morass as a small stream flowing down a rather deep coulee and eventually entering into the Assiniboine River. It will be necessary to impound the greater portion of the flow of this spring at the place where it emerges and convey the water by underground pipe line to either the existing reservoir or to the school itself. Some inspection is necessary to determine just how this spring water originates in various places from the gravel strata and may be impounded before being conveyed to the present reservoir 1800 feet distant. At the present time it is rather an unsightly looking source of water supply and no doubt it is very badly contaminated.

It is difficult to give an estimate of the cost of procuring this additional water supply, owing to uncertainties relating to the difficulty of impounding the water supply at this source. The pipe line would entail an outlay of approximately $2,500.00. The clearing of the source of supply and the impounding of the water might approximate $1,500.00, making a total cost of $4,000.00 under ordinary working conditions. Winter excavation, however, would add to these costs considerably.

Before recommending the tapping of this additional source of water supply, the writer would urge that the existing source of water supply be explored to ascertain whether or not sufficient additional flow cannot be obtained to provide a water supply adequate to safeguard the needs of the school during the coming winter.

Those responsible for the construction of the existing reservoir in 1928 cannot now be reached so particulars relating to the same are entirely lacking. It is possible that only a portion of the capacity of this particular spring is being procured in the concrete reservoir. To determine whether or not such is the case it will be necessary to excavate a trench immediately downhill from the reservoir, tap the gravel bed and ascertain the conditions. If it is determined water is escaping and in sufficient volume to provide an adequate water supply, it will then be necessary to cut off the escaping water by plank sheeting thus forcing the water back into the reservoir so as to create sufficient head to deliver water to the residences which at present get water only occasionally. If additional water were procurable it would then become advisable also to lower the outline pipe from the reservoir.

It is possible that such an examination would entail an outlay of $100.00 but if it results in sufficient water being secured to get safely through the coming winter, this amount together with an additional $150.00 or $200.00 for sheeting and alterations, would alleviate the necessity of proceeding with the new pipe line with all its uncertainties of continuity of supply and construction during the period of year when excavation is both difficult and costly.
I would accordingly recommend that we be authorized to expend up to $100.00 in exploring the possibility of water supply at the existing reservoir and also to carry out some test work at the second spring which it may be necessary to tap. As the situation is urgent I would recommend authorization be wired to make such preliminary investigations.

I regret that it was impossible to make the inspection earlier than yesterday in response to your instructions, but owing to the absence of both Mr. Rose and the writer from the office for some time past, such an examination could not be made.

Your obedient servant,

(sgd.) D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.
October 27, 1934.

Sir,

In further reference to your letter of the 10th instant regarding the water supply at the Brandon Indian Residential School I enclose herewith copy of a letter dated the 24th instant received from Mr. Gow in which he reports on the existing situation.

He recommends as a first step to find out if additional water can be obtained from the spring now being used by examining conditions below the spring to find out if any water is escaping from the existing reservoir, and if so to cut off the escaping water by plank sheeting thus forcing the water back into the reservoir so as to create sufficient head to deliver water to the residences which at present get water only occasionally.

He estimates that the examination would cost about $100, and if it shows that more water is available in this way, the expenditure of about $200 more for sheeting and alterations would provide water during the coming winter.

Mr. Gow states the situation is urgent and asks that authority be wired to him to make such preliminary investigations.

You will recall that Mr. Gow has been authorized to go to Lebret, Saskatchewan, to prepare a report on the water supply and sewage disposal system for the new school there and consideration should be given as to which of these should receive precedence in the instructions to be given to Mr. Gow.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. Mackenzie, Esq.,
Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

J.T. Johnston,
Director.
October 27, 1934.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 27th with further reference to the water supply at the Brandon Indian Residential School, I beg to say that the Department approves of an expenditure up to $200.00, as recommended by Mr. Gow in his report, and you may therefore wire him to this effect.

With reference to the necessary survey and report on the water supply and sewage disposal for Lebret, I think it would be better to leave these arrangements entirely to Mr. Gow.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

The Director,
Dominion Water Power Branch,
Ottawa.

Robt. Bird, Engineer, $180.00
Maurice Grey, " 180.00
($15.00 per month, each)
Ottawa, November 8, 1934.

Sir:

Mr. L. G. Young, Auditor, who recently visited and inspected the books at the Brandon Indian Residential School, has drawn attention to the position of Engineer, which is now filled by two boys holding Technical School certificates. In this connection there are several points that should be considered, viz.: -

1. Do Provincial regulations permit the employment of boys with such certificates to take charge of a large heating plant?

2. Is it in the interests of the Department to allow boys to operate this plant? If they are not competent or properly qualified, serious damage to equipment and building may result, and the Department may be called upon to meet a rather large expenditure for repairs.

3. Should there be an accident due to improper handling of the heating plant, resulting in injuries or possibly loss of life to some of the inmates of the school, it would be rather embarrassing for Department.

4. Are these boys qualified to look after equipment other than the heating plant, such as pumping apparatus, laundry machinery, etc?

I should be pleased if, at your convenience, you will enquire into the services of the boys in operating the heating plant and other equipment at the school. If you consider that they are not competent, you should advise the Principal to arrange for the services of a fully qualified engineer.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

VERY POOR COPY
November 20, 1934.

Sir:

The work carried out at the Brandon Indian Residential School and involving the expenses being forwarded was for the purpose of securing additional inflow to the existing reservoir and increasing the water elevation sufficiently in the same so as to provide water supply to the upper stories of the houses used by staff members.

Preliminary investigation revealed that a certain amount of water was passing through the gravel strata and not accessible to the reservoir. Measurements taken showed this additional flow to be about 900 gallons daily and so it was decided to endeavour to block off this flow and force the same into the reservoir. It was also decided to endeavour to increase the water level in the reservoir by driving sheeting along the ends and the lower side of the reservoir. It was hoped to shut off all flow past the reservoir, increase the water table elevation and so secure the necessary increased head that has been lost during the past two years.

In placing and driving the lumber sheeting, great difficulty was experienced from the gravel cavities in quicksand was encountered at depth and it was impossible to effect a complete cut-off of the water. Accordingly, we did not succeed in materially increasing the water level in the reservoir. However, tile and piping was placed to convey the major portion of the 900 gallons per day spring to the vicinity of the reservoir. The reservoir itself was cleaned out to a depth of 1.5 feet and the outlet was lowered.

The work carried out will doubtless increase the water available for use in the school and it is hoped will ensure the school operating throughout the winter. The work apparently has resulted in increasing the elevation of the water level in the reservoir to provide continuous water supply to the second storey of the Principal's residence. The presence of quicksand at depth prevented the complete sealing up of the area around the reservoir, thus defeating our efforts to raise the water table.

While the work performed will, I believe, ensure a fairly adequate water supply to the school during this winter, I am of the opinion that should the dry cycle continue into 1936, it will be necessary to look to additional sources for water for this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau,
Ottawa, Ontario.

De B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.
Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a statement of disbursements, in quadruplicate, made by the writer for the Department of Indian Affairs in connection with work performed at the Brandon Indian Residential School. This statement of disbursements shows expenditures of $150.03.

I am also enclosing account from Wade & Sons Limited, Brandon, against the Department of Indian Affairs for materials supplied in connection with the work carried out at the Brandon Indian Residential School - the amount of the account being $65.81. I would recommend to the Department of Indian Affairs that this account be paid.

You will note that the writer has expended $150.03 of his own money in connection with the work at the Brandon Indian Residential School, whereas the standing advance from the Department of Indian Affairs only amounts to $60.00. Accordingly, I would request a cheque as early as possible from the Department of Indian Affairs, particularly as the writer has also had considerable expense in connection with the Lebret Indian School - an account for which will be submitted shortly.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) D. B. Gow,

ED WINNIPEG, MAN. November 20th, 1934.

Sir:

In reply to Department Letter 135-0-5 dated November 8th, concerning the engineers at the Brandon Residential School, I had occasion to be in Brandon last week and discussed this matter with the Principal.

Dr. Doyle informed me that the boys attended the Technical School for three years and both held certificates. However, he pointed out that although the boys were termed "engineers", they were under the supervision of Mr. Wood who has been at the school for some three years. Mr. Wood is very reliable, but neither does he hold an engineer's certificate. In order to meet with the Department's wish, Mr. Wood stated he would immediately write the examination for a Provisional Certificate which, I understand from the Bureau of Labour, Parliament Bldg., is equivalent to a fourth class engineer's certificate. Mr. Stewart, of this Department, states it is not necessary to hold a certificate unless one is operating a plant where it is necessary to carry thirty pounds of steam or over. I understand from Dr. Doyle and also from Mr. Wood that, even in the severe weather, they scarcely carry more than 10 or 15 lbs. of steam.

The vertical boiler which supplies the hot water for the laundry may occasionally have 30 lbs. of pressure, although I think the work could be carried on with from 20 to 25 lbs.

Dr. Doyle assured me that Mr. Wood would be left in charge and that he would immediately write the examination.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
He would like to know if this will be satisfactory to the Department as he is anxious in every way to co-operate and meet the Department's wishes. If this arrangement is satisfactory, I will advise the Department when Mr. Wood has obtained his Provisional Certificate.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Ottawa, December 1st, 1934.

Sir:

I have your 209-11A U., of the 20th ultime, with reference to the qualifications of the engineers who are operating the heating and mechanical equipment at the Brandon Indian Residential School. It is noted that the two boys are under the supervision of Mr. Wood, who does not hold an engineer's certificate. It is considered he should write his examination and obtain a certificate, as soon as possible.

If you believe the engineering services at this school are satisfactory and that Mr. Wood is fully competent, we would be prepared to accept your judgment in the matter. However, the Principal should understand that, if an accident occurs to the plant at the school, on account of not having a fully competent engineer, replacements of equipment will have to be undertaken by the school authorities - the expenses in connection with which will have to be met from school receipts.

You might advise the Department when Mr. Wood obtains his provisional certificate.

Your obedient servant,

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM REV. KENNETH J. BEATOR, B.A., ASSOCIATE SECRETARY, BOARD OF HOME MISSIONS, UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA, 299 Queen St. West, Toronto 2, Ont., dated November 30, 1934.

Brandon Residential School:

Electric refrigerator - Probably room at present used as cooler could be turned into walk-in frigidaire. If not, the installation of a large cabinet type electric refrigerator in one corner of the kitchen would be much better than the present system.

New water supply - It may be that some action on this matter has already been taken by the Department, as Mr. A. G. Hamilton, the Inspector, reported on it towards the end of September. For the first time in 76 years the spring, which was tapped to supply the school with water, is practically dry. Brandon School is at the moment without fire protection in that sense. There is another spring, 600 yards farther up the hill, which even in this especially dry summer, has maintained a steady flow of good water. It would be an inexpensive matter to extend the lines to tap this source.
Sir:

I have just been advised by Doctor Doyle, Principal of the Indian Residential School, Brandon, that the water situation there is worse now than it has ever been. It does not come up as fast and none has reached the hot water tank in his kitchen for ten days. Doctor Doyle states that if it does not get worse, they will try to carry on by conserving in every possible way. I will report any further developments in connection with the matter.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba

Brandon, Man., March 6, 1935.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In regard to the water situation here we are sending regular reports to Mr. D. D. Gow, of Winnipeg, who, I presume, is keeping you informed in regard to it.

The situation is getting gradually worse. We can just barely tide along by shutting it off at night and using as little as possible both for the building and the stock. They are spreading the bathing of the pupils over three days but as soon as this extra drain commences we are without water from this source. The well which supplies our pressure system is holding about the same and at the suggestion of the engineers who were here in the fall we are now tapping the pressure system pipes in order to get a supply from this source in the kitchen without having to carry it as we have been doing for some months from other parts of the building.

Apart from a few days we have had no water in the bathroom at our house for months and most of the time none in the hot water tank in the kitchen. The members of our family have to either go to town or to the school for a decent bath.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

JAD/W

Sir,

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of March 14th in connection with the water supply situation at the Brandon Indian School. It is noted that the Department of Indian Affairs have asked that a further inspection and report be made as to the best and most economical way of overcoming the present difficulties.

At the present time there is little or nothing that can be done to overcome the shortage of water being experienced at the Brandon Indian School. It is hoped that with the spring break-up period now approaching, some improvement in the conditions may be experienced.

Mr. Rose at the present time is in the Estevan district in connection with the establishment of hydrometric stations and coulds return to Winnipeg will stop off at Brandon and visit the Brandon Indian School. At that time he will make an examination of the flow of water in the spring which is situated about one-half a mile from the school and which it is proposed to connect up with the present water supply to the school. If the flow of water in this spring at the present time is insufficient to meet the requirements of the school, it will then be necessary to give consideration to other sources of supply for this school.

Sir,

With further reference to the subject matter of your letter of the 14th instant and my reply thereto under date of March 20th, I beg to advise that Mr. Rose has now returned from his west trip, during the course of which he visited the Brandon Indian School and investigated the water supply conditions at that Institution.

Mr. Rose reports that the water supply at the Institution, while inadequate to meet the demands of all services, is not now more serious than the conditions that have prevailed during the greater part of the winter. There is nothing that can be done at the present time to provide an adequate water supply for all services and it is anticipated that with the break-up period now about to take place, that conditions will not become more serious and will probably be somewhat alleviated.

Mr. Rose made an investigation of the spring which has been referred to in previous correspondence, and made an actual measurement of the flow as it emerges from underground. He reports that at the time of his visit the flow was averaging a rate of somewhat in excess of 4,000 gallons per day. In view of the fact that the other springs have shown a lessening discharge, the fact that this spring appears to be maintaining a fairly large flow is a favourable feature. It would appear that we would be warranted in creating a small reservoir at the point where this spring emerges from the ground and conveying the supply either direct to the school or to the existing reservoir. However, this work cannot be undertaken at the present time, but should be given further consideration should the run-off conditions throughout Manitoba continue at a rate below normal. In the meantime whenever our engineer is in that vicinity, he will make it a point to further inspect this spring to determine whether or not there is a decrease or increase in the discharge.

I would ask that you please convey this information to the Department of Indian Affairs.

Your obedient servant,

'SGD' D.B.Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer

J.T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau,
Ottawa, Ontario.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Funds are provided, in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, to carry out certain painting and miscellaneous repairs at the Brandon Indian Residential School. It is proposed to perform the following work in the interior of the building:

To paint auditorium, children's dining room, boys' and girls' study and waiting room, and to do some redecorating to a bungalow used by a member of the staff.

The labour will be performed by the school staff, without expense to the Department. It will be necessary to supply the material only, at a cost of approximately $127.

It is proposed, further, to overhaul and renew part of the electric wiring, poles, etc. The manager of the Manitoba Power Commission states this work is urgently required, and he gives an estimate of $442 as the amount necessary to place the wiring in good condition.

I would request your approval for having the above work carried out and would be pleased if you would advise the names of the firms from whom quotations should be obtained for the supplying of the paint, oils, etc., and also the name of an electrician to supply the materials required and perform the labour in overhauling the electrical wiring at this school.

Deputy Superintendent General.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

Funds are provided, in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, to carry out certain painting and miscellaneous repairs at the Brandon Indian Residential School. It is proposed to perform the following work in the interior of the building:

To paint auditorium, children's dining room, boys' and girls' study and waiting room, and to do some redecorating to a bungalow used by a member of the staff.

The labour will be performed by the school staff, without expense to the Department. It will be necessary to supply the material only, at a cost of approximately $127.

It is proposed, further, to overhaul and renew part of the electric wiring, poles, etc. The manager of the Manitoba Power Commission states this work is urgently required, and he gives an estimate of $442 as the amount necessary to place the wiring in good condition.

I would request your approval for having the above work carried out and would be pleased if you would advise the names of the firms from whom quotations should be obtained for the supplying of the paint, oils, etc., and also the name of an electrician to supply the materials required and perform the labour in overhauling the electrical wiring at this school.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Sir:

I have the honour to submit the following report on the Brandon Indian Residential School, recently inspected.

The classroom work is arranged as follows:

The junior room is in charge of Miss Mabel Farris, with 50 on the roll. Miss Farris is a qualified teacher and specially adapted to the training of juniors and kindergarten pupils. I consider her teaching ability of high standard and the children are making good progress.

The intermediate room has 66 on the roll and the grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade | IV   | V    | VI   |
|-------|------|------|------|
|       | 28   | 20   | 18   |

Mr. N. McEwen, who is in charge of this room, is a young man with good teaching ability. The pupils are all well advanced in their respective grades.

Miss M. C. Richardson has the senior room, with 35 enrolled. The grades are as follows:

| Grade | VII  | VIII | IX   | X    |
|-------|------|------|------|------|
|       | 18   | 13   | 2    | 2    |

Miss Richardson is a graduate in Arts and a capable teacher. The pupils appear to enjoy the work and are making good progress. They were all neatly dressed and clean. The teachers each have a carefully planned

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
planned timetable which, I understand, is closely followed.

The school building is kept clean and good discipline maintained. The laundry is supervised by Miss McLaren. The girls receive a thorough training in washing, ironing and pressing. The machinery appeared to be in good condition and is well cared for.

The kitchen is in charge of Miss H. Reader. The work is done on a large scale; nevertheless, the girls receive a fair training in plain cooking. The bread is purchased in the city, but I understand classes are held in bread making. The girls are also taught to make plain cakes, buns, and pastry.

A room was provided for a frigidaire, but this has not yet been installed. I would recommend that this be provided, if possible. A large amount of food is handled at an institution of this size and a frigidaire is really a necessity, especially during the summer months. I might mention that many of the pupils remain at the school during the summer months and I doubt if the number is ever below 90 or 100.

The sewing room is on the first floor. It is well lighted and well equipped. The girls are taught mending of all kinds and plain sewing. At present this department is supervised by Nurse Matchett, the regular sewing teacher being absent on sick leave. The aim of this department is to send the girls home thoroughly trained to mend, to do plain sewing, and make the ordinary housedresses and underclothes required.

Mrs. Fraser
Mrs. Fraser is boys' supervisor and does excellent work. This is a hard department and needs constant supervision. The boys' playroom was tidy, and the toilets and washroom clean and in working order.

Miss M. Wilson is girls' supervisor and assists Doctor Doyle in his office work. The girls' playroom, washroom, and dormitories were all in good condition. All were well aired and clean.

Nurse M. Matchett is in charge of the dispensary and infirmary. Although there has been very little serious sickness, there are always minor ailments. The trachoma cases receive daily treatment. The children are weighed at stated periods and, if not gaining, are given extra food.

Fire drill is observed and none of the doors leading to the exits are locked. Fire extinguishers are kept in prominent places on each floor. One fire hose should be renewed. The one on the hanger is useless as it has been damaged. I expected these hose to be in good condition and on the occasion of my last visit overlooked making a close check. I was unable to find out just what happened to the hose in question, but it undoubtedly has been used outside. I have instructed that the fire hose must not be removed. The one required for the top floor should be 75 or 80 ft. in length.

The school building is in need of the following interior decorating:

1. Chapel - Wall should be painted to the height of 6 ft., and burlap should be used along the back. This will protect the plaster from breaking when the chairs are piled at the rear.
2. Girls' Reading Room has been in constant use and the walls are smudged and dirty.

3. Waiting Room is at the main entrance and does not look well unless kept in good condition. The walls and ceiling should be painted.

4. Boys' Reading Room, like the girls', is in constant use and needs painting.

The material for the foregoing work would not entail much expense and Doctor Doyle states the work could be done by the staff and senior boys.

The Principal's residence is old and the foundation badly settled. The verandah needs repairing, but one hesitates to recommend much expense. The house is old and without a proper foundation. A new building is needed.

The Farming Instructor's house needs exterior painting, especially the verandah which, as yet, has never been painted. The dining room and bedroom in this house should also be painted. All the above work could be done by the staff and boys and the total cost of material should not exceed $150.00.

The stockman's house is in good repair, except that one room should be re-papered.

The cottage on the west hill needs the kitchen shingled. The roof leaks badly and the work should be carried out at once. The roof is 14x20 ft. The boys, with proper supervision, could do the work.

The large barns have not been painted for many years and present a neglected appearance. This work...
work should be carried out in order that the lumber be preserved. The school is situated adjacent to the Dominion Experimental Farm, which constitutes another reason why the buildings should be kept in good repair and not allowed to become run down and neglected in appearance.

The chicken house is located in a poor place, surrounded by scrub oak. The building and land is infested with disease, consequently no poultry has been kept since the new school opened. The building has been neglected and I would recommend that Doctor Boyle be allowed to dismantle it and re-build on a smaller scale. The only extra material needed would be some cement and nails. The new house should be erected west of the school and the yard properly fenced with chicken wire. This location is subject to closer supervision as the school is situated on one side and the farming instructor's house on the other. It would also give plenty of yard and sufficient trees for shelter. The building would not interfere or detract from the present building as the location is between the horse barn and what is known as the carpenter shop. Poultry keeping, I consider, is an important sideline and one that should be encouraged. If we can create in the boys some interest in this line of work, perhaps it would result in the keeping of more poultry on the reserves.

The present garage is built of cement. It would appear as if either insufficient cement or dirty gravel was used at the time of erection; the walls are crumbling down in places and the roof is propped by heavy...
heavy timbers. The structure is only held together by the reinforcements and even these have given away in places. I realize the building is not old and should have served many years, yet its usefulness is gone and I think the only solution is to take it down and build a new garage. A smaller building will meet all requirements.

The carpenter shop was also poorly constructed and is a very unattractive building. A coat of paint would greatly improve its appearance.

The retaining wall back of the school should be erected. It would protect the school foundation and retain the front of the root cellar, which is gradually moving forward from the main structure. It would also improve the yards which each spring are covered with mud washed down from the embankment. I feel this wall is absolutely necessary and trust it may be allowed.

We have had several complaints from the Hydro Electric re the condition of the electric wiring leading from the power line to the building. The distance is several hundred feet and we are responsible for the upkeep. A number of new poles are needed, as well as insulators. A quantity of new wire may also be required. Some of the wire in use is very old and the covering is gone. In places this exposed wire can easily be reached and is a danger to the children. I strongly recommend the necessary repair work be authorized. The cost will no doubt be in the neighbourhood of $250. or $300.

The water
The water supply remains at about the same level. The only change being a quicker return after a quantity has been used. The supply, in case of fire, would give little, if any, protection.

I shall be glad to be advised regarding the Department's intentions in connection with the various recommendations contained herein.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.
MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Referring to the second last paragraph of my memorandum of the 16th ultimo, relative to the need for overhauling and renewing part of the electric wiring, poles, etc., at the Brandon Indian Residential School, and in reply to your enquiry as to the necessity of having this work done, as the school was only built five years ago, I have to say that this wiring is outside the buildings and was installed a number of years ago. It was used in connection with the old school building. Mr. Inspector Macdonald, who recently visited the school, states that the work required is in connection with the wiring leading from the power line to the building—a distance of several hundred feet. A number of new poles are needed as well as insulators and a quantity of new wire. The Inspector states that some of the wire in use is very old, that the covering is gone and in places this exposed wire can easily be reached and is a danger to the children. He states, further, that there have been several complaints made by the Hydro Electric Company, regarding the condition of the electric wiring.

I would request your approval for having the work carried out and also your direction as to the name of the electrical firm who should supply the material and perform the labour.

I should also be pleased to receive your authority for incurring the expenditure in purchasing the paint required for the interior decorating of the school building, as mentioned in memorandum referred to above, and the names of the firms from whom quotations should be obtained for the supplying of the paint, oils, etc.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, June 8, 1935.

Sir:

I have your 209-11 of the 30th ultimo, submitting your report on your recent inspection of the Brandon Indian Residential School. The Department is pleased to note that conditions generally at this school are satisfactory, that the children are making progress in the classroom and that the school building is kept clean and good discipline maintained.

Regarding the painting, the repairs and the supplying of a cold storage plant, I would say that it is intended to carry out certain painting during the coming summer, as follows:

To paint auditorium, children's dining room, boys' and girls' study and waiting room, and do some redecorating to a bungalow used by a member of the staff.

It is understood the labour would be performed by the school staff, without expense to the Department and that it will be necessary to supply only the paint and other materials required.

Further, it is proposed to overhaul and renew part of the electric wiring, poles, etc. These matters are now before the Honourable the Minister, for his approval.

I regret there are no funds available this year to paint the exterior of the barns and other outbuildings or to erect a new chicken house and garage.

The need of building a retaining wall at the back of the school has been noted, but I regret that it will not be possible to authorize having the work done this year.

Regarding the installing of a cold storage system, in the room provided for the purpose, I would request that you inform the Department of the type of system required and the approximate cost. When this information is received, consideration will be given as to whether funds for the purpose can be provided.

With reference to the renewal of the fire hose, I would request that you will state the length and the dimension of the hose and whether any couplings or nozzles should be supplied. An order could be placed here for this equipment. It is noted that there has been an improvement in the water supply.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. Macimes,
Acting Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
WINNIPEG, Man.

MEMORANDUM

June 15th, 1935.

Dr. McGill,

Re your memorandum of the 7th instant, your file No. 183-0-5, the Boyd Electric Company, of Brandon, is available for the electrical work required at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

The paints and oil required for the interior decorating of the school building may be purchased from the Mitchell Hardware Company, of Brandon.

Private Secretary.
Ottawa, June 17, 1935.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th ultimo, enumerating the painting and miscellaneous repairs required to the interior of the main building and outbuildings at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of the supplying of the paint and other materials required in carrying out the following work during the summer holiday period:

To paint auditorium, children's dining room, boys' and girls' study, waiting room at main entrance, kitchen and bedrooms in bungalow, verandah of bungalow, front room in gate-house, verandah of Principal's residence, and to supply white gloss paint for gate-house kitchen and front hall woodwork.

It is noted, from your letter above referred to, that the total cost of the materials will be $127. You should make the purchase of the paints, oils, etc., required, from the Mitchell Hardware Company, of Brandon, obtaining itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost. These accounts, you should certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department for payment.

Regarding the overhauling and renewing of part of the electric wiring, poles, etc., leading from the power line to the building, I have to say that you may arrange with the Boyd Electric Company, Brandon, to supply the material and carry out the labour in renewing and repairing the electric wiring. The work should be completed to the satisfaction of the authorities of the Manitoba Power Commission. Mr. Inspector Hamilton, in a report regarding the condition of the wiring, states that he estimated the cost of supplying new poles, insulators, any new wire required, and the labour would not exceed the sum of approximately, $300. It is hoped that the work can be carried out satisfactorily at a cost not exceeding this amount. After the work has been completed, you should forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. These accounts should state in detail the materials supplied and the labour employed.

The Department will have no funds this year to cover the cost of painting the exterior of the barns and other outbuildings.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6257, file 576-5, part 6)
Sir,

In connection with the work which Mr. Gow has been looking after for the Department of Indian Affairs, he writes to us to enquire whether it is intended that he should make further investigations and recommendations as to additional water supply for the Brandon Indian Residential School.

He also wishes to know if it is the intention of the Indian Department that he should make any further investigations of the water supply and sewage disposal systems at the Lebret Indian Residential School.

The purpose of bringing these matters to your attention at this time is owing to the extra work which has been placed on Mr. Gow and his staff in connection with hydrometric investigations, and his desire to plan the whole of his work so that it may be carried out to the best advantage. I shall be obliged, therefore, if you will advise me as soon as possible what duties Mr. Gow may be able to undertake for the Department of Indian Affairs, so that he can plan to fit these duties in with his other responsibilities.

Your obedient servant,

J.T. Johnston,
Director.

A.F. Mackenzie, Esq.,
Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
June 21, 1935.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 17th instant, with reference to the work which Mr. Gow will be looking after for this department, I beg to say that you have already been advised with reference to the Qu'Appelle School at Lebret, Sask.

It is expected that a contract will be awarded within the next two weeks for the construction of the Indian Hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle. In the event of this contract being awarded it is the intention to ask Mr. Gow to prepare the necessary plans and specifications for the water supply and sewage disposal systems.

Regarding the Brandon School water supply I do not think it will be necessary to take any further action at the present time.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Dominion Water Power Branch,
Ottawa.

Sir:

With further reference to my report on the Brandon Indian Residential School dated May 30th, 1935, and Department Letter 133-0-5 dated June 8th, I wish to say that I have now received from Rev. Dr. Doyle a letter in which he states that the cost of material and work in connection with the upkeep of the electric wiring and poles leading from the power line to the school will be approximately $290.00. Dr. Doyle states he discussed this matter with Mr. Roy, an electrician with the Manitoba Power Commission, who felt that some replacements were very urgently needed and in other places actual danger existed where wires were too low and exposed. Mr. Roy also pointed out that there would be, in time of storm, considerable loss of current.

I feel this work is urgent and trust that authority may be granted for the necessary expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Sir:

I have your 209-11A. U. of the 19th instant, regarding the overhauling and renewing of the electric wiring, poles, etc., leading from the power line to the buildings at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

Dr. Doyle, was authorized to have this work carried out and to arrange with the Boyd Electric Company, Brandon, to supply the material and perform the labour. Sir:

During my inspection of the Brandon Indian Residential School, I complained to Dr. Doyle that the barns and outbuildings presented a very neglected appearance, due to the fact that a large number of windows had been broken and a number of the sash destroyed. Dr. Doyle pointed out that most of this occurred during the construction of the new school and prior to his taking charge. This may have been the case and yet I think a lot of the repair work necessary could have been carried out during the past two or three years instead of leaving it to accumulate as has been the case.

Dr. Doyle has submitted an estimate from Wade & Sons Limited, Brandon, covering the cost of the sash and glass necessary, which amounts to $104.50. This covers 41 sash with 71 lights, and 125 panes of glass.

Dr. Doyle feels that he is unable to finance this expense, which he claims occurred prior to his taking office, and yet he is anxious to have the work done. I would recommend that the sash and glass required be purchased, and shall be pleased to receive the Department's instructions in connection with the matter.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Referring to my memorandum of the 16th instant, regarding the supplying and installing of cold storage equipment in a room in the basement of the Brandon Indian Residential School, and your request to be informed if the Department recommend the expenditure and the reasons therefor, I would say that, when the school was erected, a room was provided in the basement for cold storage purposes. The Principal and the United Church authorities, under whose auspices the school is conducted, have been requesting, during the past three years, to have this equipment installed. Mr. Inspector Hamilton, also, has recommended the installation. A large amount of food is handled at an institution of this size, and cold storage equipment is really necessary, especially during the summer months.

At present, there is a building located behind the main building, which is used as storage for coal and vegetables and has a space partitioned off for the storage of ice, in which the meat and milk supplies are kept. This is an unsatisfactory arrangement.

In the interests of the health of the children and in order to save a considerable amount of inconvenience to the staff, I beg to strongly recommend the expenditure required, of approximately $650.00, in supplying and installing cold storage equipment in the basement of the school. Funds for the purpose are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education. I would respectfully submit for your approval that you authorize the expenditure and furnish the names of the firms from whom prices should be obtained.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.
