INSPECTOR'S OFFICE

WINNIPEG, MAN., October 1st, 1935

EC

Dear Sir:

In reply to Department letter 133-0-5 dated August 10th. As instructed I have endeavored to obtain quotations from the three firms in connection with a frigidaire required for the Brandon Indian Residential School.

Mr. S. H. Brown replied that he was unable to quote due to the fact that his source of supply was now in U. S. A., and he could not tender on American goods.

The Brandon Heating and Plumbing Company were asked to quote at the same time around the 15th of August, and to date I have received no quotation. I have had Dr. Doyle, Principal of the School, call on them, and have written them on two occasions, my last letter being on September 17th, in which I asked them to submit their quotation not latter than September 20th. On September 26th I called in person and was told that Mr. Webber from Ashdowns, Winnipeg would submit the quotation. I since phoned this man who appears to know nothing of the business.

Mr. F. G. Collins has submitted a quotation of $639.00 for Kelvinator Commercial Equipment suitable for the school. The company's guarantee is as follows:-

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
October 7, 1935.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

I have to refer to my memorandum of July 24th, last, and your reply thereto of August 8th, regarding the installation of cold storage equipment in the Brandon Indian Residential School. Mr. Inspector Hamilton, Winnipeg, was instructed to obtain quotations from the firms mentioned in your memorandum referred to above. He now writes the Department as follows:

"Mr. S. H. Brown replied that he was unable to quote, due to the fact that his source of supply was now in U. S. A., and he could not tender on American goods.

"The Brandon Heating and Plumbing Company were asked to quote at the same time around the 16th of August, and to date I have received no quotation. I have had Dr. Doyle, Principal of the School, call on them, and have written them on two occasions, my last letter being on September 17th, in which I asked them to submit their quotation not later than September 26th. On September 26th I called in person and was told that Mr. Webber from Ashdowne, Winnipeg, would submit the quotation. I since phoned this man, who appears to know nothing of the business."

Mr. F. C. Collins submitted a quotation of $630.00 for Kelvinator commercial equipment, suitable for the school. The Company guarantees that the equipment which they will supply will do the work in a successful manner and will, at its own expense, correct any defects of labour and material which may develop under normal and proper use within one year after installation.

I would recommend, for your approval, that Mr. Hamilton be authorized to place the order for the installation of the cold storage equipment with Mr. F. C. Collins, Brandon, at the price quoted by him, viz.: $630.00. Funds for the purpose are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education.

Deputy Superintendent General.
October 7, 1935.

Memorandum

MR. BUSKARD,

I have to refer to my memorandum of July 24th, last, and your reply thereto of August 8th, regarding the installation of cold storage equipment in the Brandon Indian Residential School. Mr. Inspector Hamilton, Winnipeg, was instructed to obtain quotations from the firms mentioned in your memorandum referred to above. He now writes the Department as follows:

"Mr. S. H. Brown replied that he was unable to quote, due to the fact that his source of supply was now in U. S. A., and he could not tender on American goods.

"The Brandon Heating and Plumbing Company were asked to quote at the same time around the 15th of August, and to date I have received no quotation. I have had Dr. Doyle, Principal of the School, call on them, and have written them on two occasions, my last letter being on September 17th, in which I asked them to submit their quotation not later than September 20th. On September 26th I called in person and was told that Mr. Webber from Ashdowns, Winnipeg, would submit the quotation. I since phoned this man, who appears to know nothing of the business."

Mr. F. C. Collins submitted a quotation of $639. for Kelvinator commercial equipment, suitable for the school. The Company guarantees that the equipment which they will supply will do the work in a successful manner and will, at its own expense, correct any defects of labour and material which may develop under normal and proper use within one year after installation.

I would recommend, for your approval, that Mr. Hamilton be authorized to place the order for the installing of the cold storage equipment with Mr. F. C. Collins, Brandon, at the price quoted by him, viz.: $639.00. Funds for the purpose are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, October 10, 1935.

Sir:

I have your 209-11A of the first instant, submitting a quotation for the installing of cold storage equipment at the Brandon Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that you may place the order for the supplying and installing of this equipment with Mr. F. C. Collins, at the price quoted by him, viz.: $639.00, for Kelvinator Commercial equipment, suitable for the needs of the school. It is noted that Mr. Collins guarantees that the apparatus which he will supply will do its work in a successful manner, provided it is operated under normal conditions, and also that the Company will, at its own expense, correct any defects of labour and material in the apparatus which may develop within one year after the starting thereof.

You should arrange to have the equipment installed at an early date. When the Principal and yourself are satisfied that the work has been satisfactorily completed and the equipment is in good working condition, you should obtain an account, in triplicate, covering the cost. This, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Winnipeg, Man.

Sir:

I have received a letter from Rev. J. A. Doyle, Principal of the Indian Residential School, Brandon, in which he requests that provision be made in the Estimates of 1936-37 for the following improvements:

1. A retaining wall to prevent flooding and washing down of the bank at the rear of the school. $500.

2. A new garage and the tearing down of the present one. 1500.

Doctor Doyle states the situation in connection with the present garage continues to become more serious. He does not think there is any immediate danger of the roof caving in, but the cracks in the cement beams are getting larger and he has no idea how much reinforcement they contain, adding that we might meet a disaster any time. The present building is constructed of cement and should be entirely demolished.

3. Paint for the barns and other outbuildings $300.

4. Paint for interior decoration 100.

5. The erection of a new chicken house 350.

The repairs and upkeep, as outlined, should certainly be carried out and I would urge that every effort be made to provide the necessary funds.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Brandon, Man., Nov. 22, 1935.

Inspector A. G. Hamilton,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Commercial Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Inspector Hamilton:

As stated in our conversation we appreciate very much the paint which the Department provided for painting certain rooms in the school building here. By the use of a good deal of oil in the first coat and turpentine in the second coat we were able to extend this paint over a good deal more surface than was planned in our estimate. The contrast now between the walls that have been done and those which have not is seriously noticeable. The two playrooms in the basement and the two hospital wards together with children's bathrooms and toilet rooms, also locker rooms in the basement, are very much in need of paint.

For the painting already done we engaged a painter from town, Mr. Moore, at a cost of over $60.00, but he gave much instruction and help to the boys so that they are now able to go forward and do very good work. If the Department will purchase the paint for the rooms specified we will have it put on and it will certainly make a great improvement to the appearance of the building. It will require approximately 20 gallons of paint, 2 gallons of oil and one of turpentine. The best price I could secure here for good reliable paint is from Johnson Hardware at $2.95 per gallon.

We will appreciate it very much if the above material can be furnished by the Dept. for this work. We appreciate your kind offices in this connection.

I am,

Yours sincerely

(Sgd) J. A. Doyle
Sir:

Attached is a copy of a letter received from Rev. Dr. Doyle, Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School, in which he requests a further supply of paint.

I was at the Brandon School last week and can assure the Department that the paint supplied has greatly improved the condition of the school. The work has indeed been very well done. The contrast between the rooms painted and those left undone is very apparent. The hospital wards certainly should be painted in order that the walls may be washed down and kept clean. I might say that at the time of my visit, there were over thirty children sick with the 'flu and, some days prior to that, over sixty were in bed.

The material to cover the work mentioned in Doctor Doyle's letter will cost approximately $55.00 and I would appreciate being advised if funds are available to have the necessary work carried out.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Sir:

Referring to Department Letter 133-0-5 dated October 10th, 1935, I am today forwarding Voucher No. 278, in favour of the Ace Service Station, Brandon, amounting to $639.00, covering the installation of Kelvinator Refrigerator Equipment in the Brandon Indian Residential School.

For your information, I quote hereunder an excerpt from Rev. Dr. Doyle's letter dated the 11th instant:

"The plant is working splendidly. It requires occasional adjustment but they are very prompt in attending to it.

Manitoba

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Details of Material Supplied for Kelvinator Refrigerator Installed at Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man.

One WG132H Water Cooled Kelvinator Condensing Unit, single phase, 110 volts, 60 cycles.
One 56 DS Kelvinator Double Section Dry System, Cross Fin Cooling Unit.
One Thermostatic Expansion Valve.
One Galvanized Drip Tray complete with copper drain pipe.
Two Hand Valves.
One Kerostat Control Valve.
All tubing, fittings, adaptors, plumbing and electrical work necessary for complete installation.

One Service Box, size 4'6" x 2'4" x 22", capacity seven (7) cubic feet, constructed of Kiln dried lumber, insulated with 2" cork lined with sheet metal and finished with three coats white enamel, fitted with one shelf of slatted wood, two shelves of rustle's wire mesh; outside finished with three coats of clear varnish.

Above box is equipped with:
One C 40 Multiple Cooling Unit containing four trays, 27 ice cubes per tray. Grids and trays are of satin finished aluminum and unit is faced with white porcelain.
Two Hand Valves for emergency shut-off.
One Two Temperature Valve to control difference in temperature between boxes.
All piping, fittings, adaptors, etc. necessary for complete installation.

Above equipment duly installed and tested.

Complete cost $659.00

NOTE: Kerostat Control Valve and one Hand Valve not included in original specifications were included to insure greater efficiency.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith Voucher No. 51 in favor of Reliance Machine & Motor Company for $20.00.

This has been the most severe winter for frost in the history of the county. Water pipes have been freezing everywhere, and, strange to say, that although the severity of the frost has abated, the frost continues to penetrate. Our water pipes supplying both the cow barn and the pig barn froze up on the dates indicated and as it was much cheaper and much safer to have them thawed out by electrical appliances, we had this done.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir:

Referring to your No. 208-11 A.U., of October 19th, last, relative to the request of the Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School, that an item to provide for certain improvements mentioned by you be included in the Estimates for the fiscal year 1936-37; I now have to inform you that provision has been made to carry out the following work:-

1. Building retaining wall, to prevent flooding and washing down of the bank at the rear of school - $500.
2. Paint for barns and other outbuildings - 300.
3. Paint for interior decoration - 100.
4. Erecting new chicken house - 350.

I would request that you take up the above matters with the Principal and forward a recommendation regarding the carrying out of the work in building the retaining wall. Would you recommend that prices be obtained and the work done by contract, or could it be done by day labour, in charge of a competent foreman - you to purchase any materials. You should also state how you consider the work in the erection of the new chicken house should be carried out.

I shall be pleased to have as full information as possible regarding the best means of carrying out the above mentioned work. After your reply is received, the matter will be taken up with the Honourable the Minister for approval, and you will be advised.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Winnipeg, Man.

Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., May 12, 1936.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

On Saturday morning, when I came across from the house to the school at a few minutes after six, I noticed a hole, about two feet square, in the east end of the horse barn at the point where the loft floor joins the wall. On investigation we found that a fire was burning just inside the wall. We immediately called the Fire Department and established a bucket line of boys and before the fire engine arrived we had the fire under control.

I had the fire chief and one of his men go over the situation very carefully and in view of the fact that the fire had commenced right against the wall and that it had evidently been smoldering for some hours, also in view of the fact that the loft is inaccessible except to the bigger boys, and the entrance to it comes up through a feed chute, which is difficult to find, and that no sign of any tramp's bed was in evidence, the men of the fire department were quite satisfied that it was commenced by spontaneous combustion. Sweet clover and oat sheaves were run through the cutting box and blown in from the west gable last fall for winter feed. The floor of the loft at the east end had a thick covering of very fine sweet clover dust. This was about three inches deep at the wall. There was quite a heavy rain from the east during Thursday. The dampness from this had, no doubt, gone in through the cracks in the siding. Then, Friday was a very hot day, the sun beating in on that end of the barn, and while spontaneous combustion is a very rare occurrence, those who examined the situation think it quite possible and probable that this is the explanation of the fire.
Ottawa, May 18, 1936.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, informing the Department regarding a fire that occurred in the horse barn at the Brandon Indian Residential School and the action taken in extinguishing the fire. The Department is pleased that no extensive damage was incurred. It is noted that you had an investigation made by the Fire Chief and one of his men and they are of the opinion that the fire was caused by spontaneous combustion.

In order to prevent any recurrence from a similar cause, would it not be possible, after the hay and feed in the barn are used, to have the floors of the loft cleaned and all dust, seed and other rubbish removed? The lumber required for repairs can be included with the other repairs necessary before the barn is painted.

Mr. Inspector Hamilton was informed of the funds available in carrying out certain work, painting, etc., at your school. He was requested to interview you and forward a recommendation concerning the work to be done, how it should be carried out, and the purchase of materials.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.
Ottawa, May 18, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School reports that a fire occurred at the east end of the horse barn and that, on investigation by the Fire Chief and one of his men, they are of opinion it occurred through spontaneous combustion. He states it will require approximately 200 ft. of lumber, including siding, flooring, joists and studs, to repair the damage and this can be cared for in connection with other repairs, before the barn is painted.

In this connection I would refer you to official letter of the first instant, informing you of the amount available in our Appropriation for this school.

The Department is pleased that no extensive damage was incurred by the fire.

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., May 16, 1936.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

In the late summer and fall last year the septic tank in the principal's residence was giving some trouble. We had it thoroughly cleaned out but the trouble continued during the winter. I have just had Messrs. Yates, Neale & Company examine it and they find that the tile in the field had become entirely plugged with earth. The whole field will have to be dug up, re-laid, and fresh gravel put in. It is nineteen or twenty years since this tank was put in and they claim that in soil like this the present condition is what might be expected. They assure me that the cost of this will not be more than $75.00 and probably somewhat less.

We have opened up the main pipe running through the field so that the water overflowing from the tank comes out on the open ground below the field. This, naturally, can only continue for a short while without becoming seriously objectionable both from the standpoint of appearance and odor.

Awaiting your authority and direction in this matter,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal.
Ottawa, May 20, 1936.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, reporting on the condition of the septic tank in the Principal's residence at the Brandon Indian Residential School. It is noted that the tile in the field has become plugged with earth and that the whole field will have to be dug up, relaid and fresh gravel put in.

The Department will approve of an expenditure, not exceeding the sum of $75.00, for the purpose of carrying out the work required in placing the septic tank in good condition. When the work has been completed, to your satisfaction, please obtain an itemized account, in triplicate, covering the cost of any materials supplied and for the labour. Regarding the labour, the account should state the number of days or hours employed and the rate paid. You should certify the account in the usual manner and forward for payment.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.
Sir:

In reply to Department Letter 133-0-5 dated May 1st, I visited the Brandon Residential School last week and discussed with Dr. Doyle the work as outlined in the above letter. We are both of the opinion that the retaining wall should be built by day labour, having a competent foreman in charge. Dr. Doyle is anxious to have this work well done and the Department can count on his hearty co-operation. In doing the work with a competent foreman, some of the labour can be carried out by the senior boys and possibly most of the gravel could be hauled with the school teams.

The chicken house should also be built by day labour with a competent foreman in charge. A number of the senior boys could be used for this work and in this way the cost would be greatly reduced.

In connection with painting the barns and outbuildings, Dr. Doyle feels that an experienced painter and helper should be employed and they could do all the high parts of the buildings. The cost of this labour, of course, would be deducted from the $300 allowed.

I trust the above recommendations will meet with the Department's approval. I would like to obtain instructions in connection with this work as soon as possible as Dr. Doyle is anxious to have some of it completed before the pupils are discharged for their summer holidays. An immediate reply will therefore be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
May 23, 1936.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

Funds are provided, in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, to carry out the following work at the Indian Residential School, Brandon, Man. (Electoral District of Brandon):-

Building retaining wall to prevent flooding and washing down of bank at rear of main building - $500.

Purchasing paint for barns and other outbuildings and for interior decoration - 400. (main building)

Erecting new chicken house - 350.

Mr. Inspector Hamilton, Winnipeg, discussed with the Principal the work outlined above. They are of opinion that the retaining wall should be built by day labour, having a competent foreman in charge. By doing the work under a competent foreman, some of the labour can be carried out by the senior boys of the school and most of the gravel hauled with school teams. The chicken house, also, could be built by day labour, with

- a competent
a competent foreman in charge. A number of the senior boys could be used for this work, and, in this way, the cost would be reduced. In connection with painting the barns and outbuildings, an experienced painter and helper is required, as they would have to do all the high parts of the building. Mr. Inspector Hamilton would arrange for the purchase of the materials, paint, etc., and the Principal would oversee the work.

I would request your approval to incur the expenditure required in carrying out the above work. I would request, also, that you will submit the name of the foreman to be employed in the work of building the retaining wall and the name of a foreman-carpenter to have charge of the work in building the chicken house. Further, I shall be pleased to receive the name of the firm from whom the paint, oil, etc., for the painting of the barns and outbuildings should be purchased and the name of an experienced painter to do the work.

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.
Sir:

With further reference to my letter dated May 19th and Department letter just received, No. 133-0-5, dated May 18th, I wish to advise that before the outbuildings at the Brandon Indian Residential School are painted, it will be necessary to have considerable repair work carried out. A quantity of shingles, siding and common lumber will be required, as well as some rubberoid roofing for use in connection with the silo. There are also some repairs necessary in connection with the fire reported by Dr. Doyle. In regard to this, I cannot yet understand how we escaped losing the barn. The origin of the fire, of course, is not known, but is believed to have been caused by spontaneous combustion.

There are three large barns and two silos to be painted and I do not think it is possible to do more than supply paint and labour for the $300.

I would like authority to purchase the repair material necessary. The approximate cost should not exceed $40. I hope the Department will see fit to allow this as Dr. Doyle will be obliged to hire a carpenter to carry out some of the repair work. An early reply will be appreciate.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your 209-11A U of the 19th ultimo, regarding the work required at the Brandon Indian Residential School, in building a retaining wall, a chicken house and painting and repairing barns and outbuildings, I have to say that the Honourable the Minister has approved of the work being done.

The work of building the retaining wall should be carried out by day labour. The name of the foreman to be employed on this work is Mr. G. W. Epton, and, failing him, Mr. Ed. Fulcher, both of Brandon. As much of the labour as possible should be performed by the senior boys and the members of the staff. It is understood that the gravel will be hauled with school teams.

In connection with the painting of the barns and outbuildings, Mr. George Hickling, and, failing him, Mr. A. Bryan, both of Brandon, is to be employed, as foreman on the work.

You are to arrange for the purchase of all materials required, and the firms recommended for the

Dear Sir:

While attending a conference of Indian School Principles and others in Winnipeg on June 11th I received long distance notice that the septic tank at the school had ceased to function and that the basement had flooded during the night. I told them to secure the services of Messrs. Yates, Neale and Co. and have the necessary work done. It was found that one of the siphons had ceased to function and all three chambers of the tank were filled up. Our boys helped in the work as much as possible but the bill which I enclose herewith as Voucher 61 amounted to $121.69¢. Trusting that this can be met by your department.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

Form No. 101
Sir:

I am attaching hereto three vouchers covering labour in connection with painting the barns at the Brandon Indian Residential School, totalling $183.45. Under separate cover, I am also forwarding Voucher No. 220 in favour of the Johnson Hardware Co., Ltd.

The total of these vouchers exceeds the authority by $39.75. In sending the accounts, Doctor Doyle points out the desperate condition the buildings were in and stated it took 25 gals. more of red paint than Mr. Hickling estimated and 20 gals. more of oil. He adds that they have made a splendid job of it. Doctor Doyle regrets very much having exceeded the authority, but felt the work should be completed and expressed the hope that the Department will approve of his action.

I saw these buildings the other day and must admit that they present a very fine appearance. I trust the Department will see fit to pay the vouchers as submitted.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

"D" Brandon. Brandon.

Manitoba. August 21st, 1936.

Dr DOYLE, Supt. Indian School, Brandon, Man.
Compl. of: Theft of Potato Digger. Sec.586 C.C.

21-8-36.

1. Reference the above I beg to report that Dr Doyle telephoned this office this date to say a potato digger had been stolen from in front of the implement shed at the Indian School sometime within the past three weeks but the exact time could not be stated.

2. Acting upon instructions received, the writer patrolled to the Indian School in Pol. Car Code #3202, and interviewed Dr DOYLE in this connection. A description of the potato digger is as follows:

International make, about 10 years old but paint still in tact, possibility tongue has been spliced, grease cups removed and ZEEK fittings put on in place of cups, kicker for carrying vines to one side has been removed, six foot chain carrier with about 50 out of 70 links in chain replaced by links built up by welding nickel steel on to old original links.

While at the Indian School, the writer interviewed C.H.WALDRON, Supervisor of Farming operations, since Dr DOYLE is not very well acquainted with the facts in this case. WALDRON stated he had taken this digger out of the implement shed about July 1st, 1926, to allow the binders in and out and the digger was left at the east end of the shed. He could not state definitely when he last saw this digger but believed it has not been since about three weeks ago. He stated he had never seen any marks in the farm yard that would show the digger had been hauled away and had any such marks been made he would certainly have seen them since the digger was equipped with lugs on the rear wheels.

There are two roads leading to the Indian School and farm, one leading from the valley road directly in front of the school and the other road leads up from the valley road directly along back of the barns, this latter road is the one most likely used by the person who loaded the digger into a truck. Both roads are gravelled and it is impossible to see any tracks. Dr DOYLE stated he was quite sure a car or truck could come to the barns without anyone seeing them since there is no watchman at the school. There are no suspects in this theft.

I would respectfully request that the above description be circularized in the next circular memorandum. Further enquiries will be made in this connection throughout this district and a report submitted at a later date.

S.U.I.
N.R.I.

C.H. WALDRON
Cst.
(G.N.MacRee) Reg.No.11127.
Brandon Det.

Sir: Forwarded 21-8-36.

A/DG.
Ottawa, September 21, 1936.

Reverend Sir:

The Department has received reports from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, regarding the theft of a potato digger from the Brandon Indian Residential School. It appears they received a report from you on the 21st ultimo, that a potato digger had been stolen from the front of the implement shed. It now appears that, upon investigation, the police were informed, by the farm instructor, that the potato digger had been returned to the school and that it had been borrowed by a farmer, named A. M. McPherson, of the Brandon district.

The Department considers it strange that this machine should be taken without a request being made for use of same by the party who moved it from the school premises. Is there any likelihood of any other farm machinery being taken? The Department does not desire that farm machinery be loaned to outside parties.

I would request that you furnish a report regarding the potato digger. Is there not a shed, where all machinery could be stored when not in use?

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Brandon, Man.

the Mounted Police. Some days later in the course of our own inquiry we found that the potato digger had not been brought back from A. M. McPherson's last fall. It is quite impossible to explain how both the farm instructor and stockman could be so confident that they saw this implement there but they were confident and we took the course we thought best under the circumstances.

A year ago, during threshing, an important part was taken off our tractor, during the night and as far as I know this is the only theft of any machinery or implement that has taken place here since I have been in charge.

I appreciate very much having your definite expression that farm machinery shall not be loaned to outside parties and will be glad to conform to this desire.

Brandon, Man., Sept. 29, 1936.

EXD.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of September 21st, 133-0-5, in regard to the potato digger, which was reported stolen on the premises here and in regard to which you wish a report.

Mr. Ritchie McPherson, of McPherson & Bedford, of Brandon, who has always been a warm and helpful friend of the school, has two sons, A.M. and Robert, farmers a few miles west of here. We have had a good deal of business transactions with these men in regard to livestock, etc., and we have occasionally accommodated them with the use of a trailer and the potato digger. Last fall they were late with their potatoes and borrowed our digger, stating that they would return it as soon as they were finished with the potato digger. We were all quite under the impression that it had been duly returned.

We keep as many of the implements as we can in an open shed west of the barns. We put the binders in at the back, the smaller implements, such as corn planter, corn binder, scuppers, etc., packed in the best we can. Then the seed drills come last. Before the binders were needed this year and while I was on my holidays the farm instructor had the boys take the smaller implements out so that the binders could be used. When I returned from holidays about the middle of July they told me very confidently that the potato digger had been removed from the shed with the other implements but that it was now missing. They were so absolutely sure of the matter that I thought it better to put the affair in the hands of

Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

During the past month a number of emergency repairs were found necessary in connection with our heating plant and water and sewerage system. I beg, therefore, to enclose herewith Voucher No. 70 in favor of Yates, Neale & Company for Sixty-four Dollars and Seventy Cents ($64.70).

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

REV. J. A DOYLE, D.D.,
Principal.

JAD/W
enc.
Sir:

I have just received a request from Rev. Dr. Doyle, Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School, for permission to purchase four combination doors, with windows and screens, at an approximate cost of $46.00. These doors are for the rooms leading on to the fire escapes. The openings are on the north side of the building and there is no outside door. Dr. Doyle states that the only light entering these rooms is through the windows in the doors, consequently an outside door should be provided as the rooms are altogether too cold.

Dr. Doyle points out that the $350 allowed for the erection of a chicken house will not all be required and states that the doors can be supplied without exceeding the authority. I would like to have the Department's approval to make the purchase.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
EX'D.

Ottawa, October 27, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your 209-11A U., of the 23rd instant, you may authorize the Principal of the Brandon Residential School to incur an expenditure, not exceeding $46.00, in purchasing four combination doors, with windows and screens. It is noted that the cost of these doors can be obtained from the amount of $350.00 allowed for the erection of the chicken house and which amount has not been totally expended.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Winnipeg, Man.

Sir:

I wish to refer to Department Letter No. 133-0-5 dated October 27th, and to say that I have just received a letter from Dr. Doyle in which he states the amount of $350 allowed for the erection of the chicken house would not permit of supplying all the doors for the north side of the school. One door is yet required, which will cost $11.50. This is for the cold side of the school and certainly should be supplied.

Further in his letter Dr. Doyle points out that the roof of the kitchen on the stockman's residence needs re-shingling. The roof leaks badly and, in the interests of economy and usefulness, new shingles should be supplied. Dr. Doyle is willing to do the work if the Department will supply the shingles. These will cost approximately $25.

The above are necessary repairs and I would appreciate having authority to arrange for the purchases.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, December 1st, 1936.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 28th ultimo, the Department approves the purchase of a door for the chicken house at the Brandon Indian Residential School at a cost of $11.50.

You may, also, authorize the Principal to purchase shingles at a cost of approximately $25.00 in order to repair the roof of the kitchen of the stockman's residence at the school. It is noted that the labour will be performed by the school staff.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., Feb. 23, 1937.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

A short while ago we ran a stack of sweet clover through the cutting box into the feed loft in the horse barn. We shortly noticed that the inside beam over the drive floor was sagging. This beam covers a space of 26 ft. and is supported by truss rods. A few days ago one of the turn-buckles broke on one side and the beam, which is just 10 inches square, began to crack. We relieved the strain by temporary posts and, as quickly as we could, secured the necessary posts and timber to make it safe.

As this was an emergency we were unable to consult you in regard to this expenditure and I am now enclosing the bill for Ten Dollars, Ninety Cents as Voucher #90 in favor of A. R. McDiarmid Limited.

Trusting that you approve of this expenditure,

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE
538 Dominion Public Bldg.,
WINNIPEG, MAN., March 24th, 1937.

Dear Sir:

Dr. Doyle, Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School, is anxious to get started at his spring cleaning and wishes to paint the following rooms:

- Walls and ceilings for 3 classrooms
- Walls for Office and 5 staff rooms
- Walls and ceilings for main living room
- And 1 bedroom in bungalow
- Doors and general woodwork in school (varnish)
- One floor and some woodwork in gate house

The paint required will cost $139.73 according to a quotation submitted by Johnson's Hardware Co. Ltd., Brandon.

Dr. Doyle states,
"We got an estimate from Mr. Hickling for the work in the bungalow which was $40.00. This seems high to us and if the Department would allow $10.00 we could hire a man and with the aid of the boys could get this work done satisfactorily."

The boys need the training and I would recommend that they do the work and that $12.00 be allowed to hire a foreman. The total expense will be $151.73.

Parts of the buildings are in need of paint and if some work is carried out each year, we will be able to keep them in good condition. I would recommend that this expense be allowed and would appreciate having the necessary authority.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, March 30th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your 209-11A U. of the 24th instant, with reference to a request received from the Principal of the Brandon Indian Residential School for paint valued at $139.75.

It will be necessary for you to let me have definite information regarding the quantities and colours of paint necessary, also the quantity and quality of the varnish. When this is received, the request will be placed before our Purchasing Agent. Incidentally, I might point out that, when applying in future, you should give complete information regarding what is required in order to save correspondence.

It is noted that Dr. Doyle mentions that the painting could be done by the boys under the charge of a foreman. Do you consider a foreman really necessary for the painting mentioned? It is felt that some member of the school staff should be able to supervise the boys when painting these rooms.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
538 Dominion Public Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

Brandon, Man., April 9, 1937.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith Voucher #95 in favor of Messrs. Yates, Neale & Company for Twenty-three Dollars, Sixty Cents ($23.60), for clearing drain pipe to septic tank in connection with residence of Principal.

Before New Year the water supply here became inadequate and it did not rise in the house to the bathroom all winter and for the past two months or more it only occasionally came into the hot water tap in the kitchen. This meant that all our washing had to be done at the school and practically no hot water was turned into the sewer. The result was that the pipe froze up, commencing, no doubt, at the trap just before it enters the septic tank and backing up from there to the cellar. This accounts for the bill enclosed.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE
538 Dom. Public Bldg.
WINNIPEG, MAN., May 4th, 1937.

Dear Sir:

In reply to Department Letter 133-0-5 dated March 30th, I wish to advise that the following paint etc. is required in connection with the Brandon Indian Residential School:

12 gals. Flat Wall Paint, White
12 " " " " Paint, Cream
1 " " Gloss White Paint
1½ " " Floor Paint, Light Dust
1 pint Flat Wall Paint, Light Blue
4 gals. G.P. Varnish, Quick Drying, Clear
3 lbs. Powdered Glue
8 gals. Linseed Oil
5 " " Turpentine
4 only Paint Brushes, 4"
2 " " " " 1½"

Doctor Doyle would like very much to have the allowance of $12. to engage the painter to help with the first room and bedrooms at the Farming Instructor's house in order that it might be decorated in a manner consistent with the furnishing of the room. If funds are not available for this purpose, I am quite sure, if the paint is supplied, Doctor Doyle will be able to have the work satisfactorily performed by members of the staff and some of the school pupils.

I would appreciate knowing if the paint is being purchased.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, May 7th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 4th instant, you may arrange for the purchase from a firm on the approved list of the following paint required at the Brandon Indian Residential School:

- 12 gals. flat wall paint, white
- 12 " " " " " cream
- 1 gal. gloss white paint
- 1½ gals. floor paint, light dust
- 1 pint flat wall paint, light blue
- 4 gals. G. P. Varnish, quick drying, clear
- 3 lbs. Powdered Glue
- 8 gals. linseed oil
- 5 " turpentine
- 4 only paint brushes 4"
- 2 " " " " 1½"

It is understood from your letter of the 24th ultimo that the above will cost, approximately, $140.00.

The Department will, also, allow the $12.00 for the employment of a painter.

In our appropriation for the current fiscal year, the sum of $500 was provided for general repairs at the Brandon Indian Residential School. As $152.00 of this amount is being authorized in this letter, there will only be a balance of $348.00 available if you consider other repairs are necessary.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
538 Dominion Public Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Indian Residential School

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.
PRINCIPAL

EX'D.

Brandon, Man., May 4, 1937.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith Voucher #97 in favor of Yates, Neale & Company for $9.10 in connection with thawing the sewerage pipes at the principal's residence.

The frost in this country continues to penetrate until well on in May. The city gives warning to householders to keep taps running to avoid as far as possible pipes freezing during that period when we naturally think the danger is over. Till within a few days ago we have been very short of water in our residence, not receiving any through our hot water taps. This, as before, gave the frost an opportunity to close up the pipes again which are not as deep in the ground as they should be.

I am,

Yours respectfully,

J. A. Doyle.

Rev. J. A. Doyle, D.D.,
Principal.
